PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provisions of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Button (from 25 citizens) and Short (from 193 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide independent radio and television service;
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia;
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Gareth Evans (from 187 citizens) and Vanstone (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in spite of many petitions and other communications, we are dismayed and disgusted at the lack of will on the part of the Parliament to restore to retired Commonwealth Public Servants and Defence Force Personnel, pension benchmarks which were affected by a two percent discount as part of the budget brought down in 1986.

Having regard to assurances given by the Government that the base will be restored, your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, act to ensure that this is done without further delay so as to remove the permanent and compounding effects of this discriminatory action taken under the guise of the entire community sharing the economic burden.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his answer to me last week, in the context of the Quadrant building site dispute in Canberra, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: If a criminal action is involved and the allegations are ones of criminality, the fact that it is alleged to have the character of an industrial dispute by some people has nothing to do with it. It is a criminal action.

I ask: If it is true that some Robe River Iron Associates employees commandeered the company's tugs to prevent the company from using them as part of industrial action two weeks ago, does he agree that Robe River is perfectly within its rights to initiate legal action against those involved? If it is, will the Government use whatever influence it may have to persuade the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the unions directly involved and the Dowding Government to refrain from retaliatory action against a company which is doing no more than exercising its rights within the law of the land?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is using its good offices to try to bring about a sensible resolution of the Robe River dispute. I do not think it appropriate or profitable to detail what action the Government is taking, but it is directed towards that end.

—I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's response that he does not think it is appropriate or profitable, but I draw his attention to the fact that the Dowding Government in Western Australia has apparently seen it as both appropriate and profitable to enter the dispute in a very strong way. In light of that, is the Minister prepared to affirm that the rule of law should apply in this circumstance as in other circumstances and that the commandeering of tugs is not legitimate just because it is part of an industrial dispute?

—Whatever statements were made by members of the Dowding Government, including by Mr Dowding himself, I understand that a meeting will take place between the Government and the parties concerned this week and I would not want to say anything which could prejudice any discussions that might take place at that meeting.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What are the implications for television viewers of the shadow Cabinet's decision to oppose an increase in commercial television audience reach limits and, in particular, what implications will this have for the aggregation of regional television services, particularly in the southern New South Wales region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it has already been widely acknowledged that the decision of the Opposition shadow Cabinet-if it does in fact prove to be the final position of the Opposition parties on this matter-puts seriously at risk two things. The first is the capacity for the present network owners, or anyone who might replace them, to build the kinds of economies of scale and the capacity for cross-subsidy which make it possible for there to be not only more and higher quality Australian television production but also, in particular, more and better quality local content, particularly in those smaller State capitals where, in the absence of a strong economic network base, the economic realities are that those sorts of benefits tend not to flow. The second risk that is extremely evident and has been widely remarked upon is the implication for the achievement-as fast as television viewers would obviously like-of aggregation in the areas that are presently being identified to create a situation of three commercial channels where at present only one exists, which will in effect provide two additional commercial services to more than four million Australians in eastern mainland regions.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that point is worth spelling out in a little more detail. The retention of a 60 per cent limit provides a very significant disincentive to the Northern Star and Bond networks to accelerate this process, quite apart from its implications, along with all the other difficulties for Mr Skase with his regional interests. For example, the Northern Star and Bond networks would in fact go over the 60 per cent limit if they were to step down the aggregation route and, as a result, place themselves in a position of requiring forced divestiture of a significant portion of their assets.

The southern New South Wales region, approved market C, to which Senator McMullan's question immediately relates, is perhaps the clearest of all the examples. It is due, under the Government's indicative timetable, to aggregate by the end of 1989. The Government has been involved in discussions with the networks with a view to bringing this start-up date forward to the beginning of next year-in other words, 12 months earlier. The Opposition decision-if it is the one that ultimately prevails-will make it extremely unlikely that viewers in this region will be able to enjoy the benefits of that accelerated aggregation process. If this proves to be the case, viewers in Wollongong, Canberra, Orange and Bathurst and all the surrounding areas will know very well who to blame.

I do not think it very gentlemanly of me to dwell on the comprehensive way in which the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, and his shadow communications spokesman, Senator Messner, were comprehensively rolled on this particular matter. It happens to all of us on occasion in our respective parties. I appreciate that that is the exigency of the political process, but let not the sea of confusion which has emanated from these two and others in recent days conceal the fact that comprehensively rolled they were, as nobody who was on the receiving end-as almost anyone in the country who chose to ask was-could be in any doubt at all of various confident assurances, predictions and commitments to achieving the more rational result which I have just described.

The more important point to make is not so much the nature of the assurances and the confident predictions that were made and the way in which they were countermanded by the reality of the shadow Cabinet decision, with all the loss of authority and credibility to the leadership that that implies, but, as Mr Keating described it, the total intellectual dishevelment of the Opposition when it comes to articulating why the position is as is currently being described. Intellectual dishevelment it undoubtedly is, if one cannot put any kind of understandable substance to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Jump!

—I will come to Senator Chaney in a moment. One cannot put any kind of substance to the extraordinary series of statements that have been made by Senator Messner and his own leader in describing what their optimal or preferred outcome would be as a result of this extraordinary saga. We had Senator Messner clearly saying on numberless occasions that his preferred position would be in fact 100 per cent, or something close to it, provided that there was a greater degree of access, a greater degree of competition, within the commercial television market. We had Mr Howard saying exactly the same thing in his doorstop on 22 April when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I think the ideal that all of us see, and I certainly see, and I think this is widely known-
indeed it is, as he made it widely known-
would be 100 per cent and far greater freedom of entry.

I think it needs to be appreciated just how comprehensively idiotic that kind of assertion is and how incomprehensible it is to make any substantive sense of it in the context of the present television environment. There are no barriers to entry, there are no barriers standing in the way of anyone's access to the three existing commercial channels and the various groupings of related channels that exist around the country. There are no inhibitions to access; there is no obstacle to commercial freedom in this area. The only obstacle that is posed is the 60 per cent constraint which is there presently in the legislation. That is the only relevant obstacle. It is the very obstacle-the arbitrary obstacle-that the Liberal national council decided two or three weeks ago should be removed because it had no credible content.

It is just impossible to work out what on earth the Opposition is talking about. The only way that one could possibly get more competition or more access is if one opened up a fourth commercial channel. Is that what the Opposition is proposing-a fourth commercial channel, which everyone knows, but which honourable senators opposite would probably be the last to know, is commercially wholly unfeasible in the present environment? Is it the concept of access to pay television, which has been uttered by Senator Messner on a couple of occasions in the last few days, even though he knows, as everybody else who has had anything to do with this well knows, that the Government is looking at the policy implications of that, that it is a totally different technology involving a totally different entertainment mode and is in no way comparable to the delivery of broadcasting television which they are suggesting should be exposed to greater access and greater competition?

I just make the point, Mr President-and I make it very shortly-that what we have here is a performance on the part of the Opposition which involves talking in tongues as it is incomprehensible babble, it makes no intellectual sense, it certainly makes no policy sense and it ought not to be regarded as successfully concealing the total shambles the Opposition policy-making process has got itself into.

Whatever the babble in fact means, it certainly has not impressed other Liberal leaders across the nation. I think one cannot let the occasion pass without referring to the way in which the present leadership, the present shadow Minister and those who voted against them, have been made to look thoroughly foolish by the response of their own spokesmen. Mr Greiner said, as reported in the Age today, that the shadow Cabinet decision was neither philosophically correct nor in the interests of the viewers. The Western Australian Opposition Leader, Mr MacKinnon, is quoted again in today's papers as saying:
It would be ridiculous if Western Australia were to be disadvantaged by having TVW7 excluded from the benefits of being part of the national network.

Even the Victorian Liberal leader, Mr Kennett, who needs this kind of recognition because I think this is the first time he has been acknowledged by the other side of the chamber-in fact, he has not been; honourable senators opposite have been very quiet-since he has been in that job, said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning that he opposed the shadow Cabinet's decision on the grounds that it was against the philosophy of the Liberal Party, would not increase competition, would not help regional viewers and would not help encourage greater locally produced programming. That is the environment in which the Opposition leadership has got itself on this occasion. It is one that ought to be fully appreciated for the monumental idiocy that it is. Its own Party right around the nation and television viewers have been giving it the message. One only hopes that that message is still capable of being heeded.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications and follows his extensive demonstration of the devil quoting scripture of a few minutes ago. I ask: If reducing the number of owners in the industry has all the advantages that he has just outlined, why does the Government not propose to increase the audience reach to 100 per cent rather than 75 per cent? Does he agree that, with the restricted number of licences which are available because of the licensing arrangement, the Government's proposal would reduce even more the number of companies which are presently in the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been acknowledged from the outset of this debate in the middle of last year that there is no logical stopping place short of 100 per cent once one recognises the realities of the argument in terms of the economic base and the need for a substantial financial base with the capacity to cross-subsidise. Once one moves beyond the 43 per cent limitation that is implied in so far as the previous two-station rule with Sydney and Melbourne is concerned, there is no logical stopping place in the argument about building the economic base and there is no logical reason for choosing any particular point between 43 and 100, save the important qualification which led the Government to choose the 75 per cent one last year and to regard that as an acceptable compromise subsequently. The relevant discriminating point--
—They were just your instructions at the time.

—No. I have made the point previously and it is very simply this: it is a percentage figure which accommodates the five mainland capital cities-the five most substantial individual viewing areas. It would accommodate Hobart as well, but Tasmania is a special case. It is a percentage figure which accommodates that and, I repeat, allows a firm network base to be built to allow economies of scale and cross-subsidies. It is high enough to allow for that. It satisfies the hurdle requirement that there is enough of an economic base, which no lesser figure does, and enables that economic base to be built. On the other hand, it is not so high that it rules out the likelihood, indeed the probability, that smaller players will continue to have an ownership role in a significant number of the regional television stations around the country. It allows a diversity of players, if you like, to take their place in the television provision environment in those lesser markets-the less capital intensive; the less capital expensive to build up-and, as a result, gives some acknowledgment to the argument, which is very widely shared, and which obviously has some force in Senator Chaney's Party, that there ought to be more than just three individual owners in the game. I acknowledge that.

ANSWER.PARA: Seventy-five per cent is a compromise figure, acknowledged and articulated as such, which satisfies those two equal and opposite concerns. It satisfies the concern to enable a broad economic base to be built in a way that 60 per cent does not. It also satisfies the concerns of those who do want to see the opportunity retained for niche players, as it were, to have a continuing role, particularly in the regions. One could argue, of course, about 5 per cent or 10 per cent either way of that particular figure as probably being capable of satisfying equally well those two aspirations. But the 75 per cent figure was chosen for that reason. There is no pretence at scientific exactitude about it. There has not been by Mr Duffy, by Mr Keating, by the Prime Minister or by me. I make no such pretence now. It is an appropriate compromise figure which draws a satisfactory policy balance between the concerns that exist. That is why the Labor Party in government chose the figure originally and has remained consistently with it throughout. It satisfies all the concerns that I have articulated today, plus others as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his admission that the 75 per cent has no logical basis. I simply ask him, by way of supplementary question: Why not move now to 100 per cent? Why wait until one of the present owners buys some more stations which take him over the 75 per cent to get his instructions to move the limit?
—I reject wholly the sort of undertone of contempt which runs through Senator Chaney's--
—That was an overtone of contempt.
—Well, the overtone. I reject wholly the quite explicit offensiveness of that question.
—Those over there were the only government to amend the legislation to protect one proprietor.
—And who was that, Senator Button?
—The Fraser Government, to protect one man.

—That is right; of course it did, and that ought to be acknowledged for the record. If the 75 per cent limit were legislated into effect, there would be no question of that being subject to any further change in the future. There was always the prospect that the 60 per cent limit would be the subject of change in the future because there was a clearly articulated and rational economic foundation for going to a higher figure. That was said at the time. It was said that the 60 per cent figure was forced upon us much against our inclination and against the best policy interests of the nation, that if the opportunity arose we would certainly reconsider it. That was a point made by me and other spokesmen on a number of occasions during the last few months. I have also made the point, and I do so again now, that if the 75 per cent figure were to be seized upon, were to be enacted as the appropriate figure, consistent with the stance we took last year, there would be no question in the foreseeable future of that figure being further amended. All the concerns that we have articulated-the concerns about, to repeat, the necessity for a sound economic base to get levels of production up and local production in the smaller States, and the concerns we have expressed simultaneously about aggregation-manifestly could be thoroughly satisfied under the 75 per cent limit, and there would be no justification, accordingly, for changing it in the future, and I make that commitment on the part of the Government.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that some Australian companies with major operations overseas have been calling for the Government's foreign tax credit system to be discontinued? Is it the Government's intention to accede to those calls?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —To my knowledge, the most vociferous of the people who have been calling for the abolition of the foreign tax credit system is, of course, John Elliott, who is equally vociferous and adamant about a number of other policy matters, including a consumption tax and, I understand, telling his mates at the footie how John Howard got it all wrong about television reach and a number of other matters. The Government has no intention of acceding to the sort of self-serving, self-promoting whingeing that Mr Elliott, among others, has been indulging in. I am confident that we have the support of almost every objective observer of the tax scene. One of those observers-or newspaper columnists, as he was at the time-who some would regard as a tax expert, quite explicitly stated in the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 September 1985, in a review of the then recently announced tax package:

ANSWER.PARA: The proposed foreign tax credit system will be opposed by those Australian companies with major operations in countries where profits are relatively lightly taxed.
Nevertheless, it will make our own taxation system more coherent and should be welcomed as such. So should most of the proposals to reduce or remove existing tax shelters.

That is from an article written by Mr Stone, as he was then, and published in the Sydney Morning Herald on 25 September 1985. I entirely agree with him. I hope he still holds those views and is willing to put them forcefully to Mr Elliott. I also hope that he, or at least his Party, is as successful in rolling over the Liberal Party of Australia as the National Party of Australia was in rolling over the Liberal Party last week on the question of television audience reach.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer the Minister to his answer to my question last week. When talking about the process of consultation on tariff cuts he said that views of the Business Council of Australia (BCA) had been heard and the unions would be heard. He also said:

QUESTION.PARA: The views of the Australian Manufacturing Council will be expressed to the Government on those issues. I regard that as a worthwhile process.

In view of the reported abusive reception afforded members of the Australian Manufacturing Council (AMC) by the Prime Minister, by Mr Dawkins and by Senator Evans, but apparently not by this Minister, who once again appears to have distanced himself from his less temperate colleagues-at least according to the leak to the Age, which reported that he was embarrassed by the outburst-would he describe last week's meeting with the AMC as a worthwhile process? Will the Government release the Council's submission presented at the meeting with Ministers? In view of the flood of leaks, winks and nudges emanating from the Government on this issue, can the Minister blame the AMC for having based its submission on a belief that the Government had already decided its direction? What role, if any, has been played by the officers of the Minister's Department who staff the AMC secretariat, and the head of his Department, who is a Council member, in contributing to this belief? Does the Government's instruction to the AMC to go away and rewrite its submission raise serious questions about the independence of the Council and the quality of its advice?

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a number of parts to that question. I can probably answer them in a general way, perhaps not to the satisfaction of Senator Lewis. As I understand it, the Manufacturing Council had a general discussion about tariffs at its February meeting. Those views expressed at that meeting were conveyed to me. It is also true that last week the three representatives of the Manufacturing Council met a number of Cabinet Ministers, the Manufacturing Council having sought that meeting but having been given relatively short notice of it. I concede that at that meeting there was something of what I would regard as a communications gap. It may have been my fault in the sense that I did not fully identify to the members of the Manufacturing Council who were coming to that meeting what was expected of them in translating at least the preliminary views they had formed at their February meeting. I have not read the report in today's Age. Let me make it clear that I have heard about it but I have not read it. Senator Lewis's reference to my distancing myself from--
—You did not tell Michelle that you were involved?

—I have had no discussion with Michelle Grattan or any other journalist about what took place last Wednesday night. If the Age wants to report that I was embarrassed or otherwise, I would expect it to have the courtesy to ask me whether I was embarrassed, because embarrassment is a fairly subjective sort of thing.
—Were you embarrassed?

—I was no more embarrassed last Wednesday night than I am at Question Time by Opposition questions-and I can tell honourable senators that that is not very much. There were a number of other points in the question which Senator Lewis asked. The BCA has expressed views to the Government about tariffs, there has been a meeting with the manufacturing unions about tariffs, there was a meeting last Wednesday with the Australian Manufacturing Council to which Senator Lewis particularly referred. The Manufacturing Council will come back to the Government with some further views as a result of last Wednesday's meeting. Senator Lewis's question was in a number of bits. I think that I have picked up most of them, and if there are any I have missed please let me know.

—I will now, by way of a supplementary question. I ask the Minister the last part of the question which he has not yet addressed: Does the Government's instruction to the Council to go away and rewrite its submission raise serious questions about the independence of the Council and the quality of its advice. Arising out of the answer itself, does the Minister agree that today's reports, involving two of the three groups he mentioned in his answer to me last week, indicate that the so-called consultation process is nothing more than farcical window dressing?

—That may be a description which suits Senator Lewis's purposes, but I do not think it is correct. It is a lot more than window dressing. I have spent quite a bit of time involved in consultations with various organisations about this issue. But ultimately the Government has to make a decision about it, and the Government will do so. If one tries to form a view based on the collective wisdom of everybody in this country who is interested in tariffs, one will not get a very informed or progressive view, I am afraid. I am sorry, but there was another part of Senator Lewis's question. Perhaps by way of interjection, which he is normally good at, he will tell me the other part of his supplementary question.
—About the independence of the Council's advice.
—There is no question about the independence of the Australian Manufacturing Council, which has said a number of things which are critical--
—The Prime Minister has told it to go away and rewrite its submission.

—I am not a nuclear medicine expert or anything like that, and I do not have a deep insight into the mind of the person who wrote that article. I take it that there is only one article to which Senator Lewis refers.
—So you are not distancing yourself from the Prime Minister?

—No, I am not doing any of those things, Senator. The fact was that the Australian Manufacturing Council did not come to meet with the Government last Wednesday with a submission on the issues. It was certainly asked to come back with its views.
—With another draft, like the FitzGerald report.

—No, Senator Stone, it was not that at all, there was no question of that. It was asked to come back with a paper which addressed the issues in some detail. That is the important thing to do. What it came with on Wednesday night was a view about the process of consultation itself, not the issues which were intended to be the subject of that consultation. The next time, hopefully, it will come back with views about the issues. If some journalist wants to interpret that as meaning that it has been told to go away and rethink its position or something like that, that is not true. That is a very misleading piece of information.
—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It relates to the ongoing work of the Hawke Government in repairing the nation's public finances from the shambles inherited in 1983.

—Does the Minister agree that a major part of this task of repair has to lie in improving community attitudes regarding the requirement on the part of corporations and individual citizens of honesty in their pecuniary dealings with the Government? What progress has the Commonwealth Government made in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gather from the hoots and jeers that came from the other side while Senator Giles was asking the question that the Opposition has either forgotten the shambles that the nation's finances were in in 1983, or it is denying that the nation's finances were in a shambles. So, I think I should remind the Opposition, and anybody else who may have forgotten about it, what shambles the finances were in in 1983. Firstly, we were facing a prospective Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion, which, as Senator Stone pointed out in the first week of March 1983, was the biggest Budget deficit ever recorded in peacetime, and outlays had been increased by more than at any previous time since the Second World War as well. Unfortunately, I do not have the precise quotations with me right now, but Senator Stone told Mr Howard in the first week of March 1983 essentially that he was presiding over financial chaos which he himself had engineered. That was the essential message of Senator Stone's note to Mr Howard. We were also experiencing unemployment at above 10 per cent, inflation at above 11 per cent, as well as the $10 billion deficit. We had the big double digit trifecta: $10 billion deficit, more than 10 per cent unemployment, and more than 10 per cent inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I was really asked about the Government's repair of that financial shambles. On the Commonwealth side it has been entirely repaired. It has taken us five years to fix up the mess that John Howard left behind him; but finally, it has been done. On the revenue side of the Budget, it is also true that the loopholes in the taxation laws which John Howard, as Treasurer, allowed to be exploited, right up until 1982, without serious fear of any effective government action being taken, have been repaired. At that time, of course, when tax evaders plumbed the depths of depravity with the benign approval of the then Federal Government, a state of mind developed among a number of otherwise honest Australians that the successful tax avoider was a person to be admired and the honest tax complier was regarded as a bit of a mug. I believe that those days are gone, but there are still some elements around who would like to return to the bad old days when tax avoidance and evasion were rampant, when there was apparently, right up until 1982, no sign that the Federal Government intended to take serious action to stamp them out.

One of those people who want to return to the bad old days is the Federal President of the Liberal Party, who is forever threatening to take his business offshore unless the taxation system is perverted again in the way in which it was in the early 1980s and the late 1970s. Indeed, he gave a speech in London recently in which he boasted of how proud he was of his grandmother because she had never drawn a government pension. I wonder whether his grandmother would have been as proud of him, a man who revels in being referred to in the public Press as being an Olympic-class tax avoider.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. If an economy is to remain healthy and viable over time, is it not the case that interest must grow no more rapidly than does total national income? If interest grows more rapidly than national income, will not the rentiers come to consume a larger and larger portion of the national cake? What instruments are available to the Federal Government to hold interest rates to the rate of growth of national income?

—I think that that would probably make the subject for a PhD thesis. I would not like to try to answer it off the top of my head in about 30 seconds. The first problem is that I cannot see what the point of the question is. Perhaps I had better read it carefully later to see whether in the oral presentation something quickly slipped past me. I do not know whether Senator Coulter is referring to interest payable abroad or interest payable within Australia. He has failed to realise that interest is a form of property income. There are other forms of property income such as rents received from real estate and dividends received on shares. Other things being equal, it is obvious that if there were a change in the distribution of corporate financing from equities to debt-that is, were the income on property paid in the form of interest rather than dividends-there would be an increase in interest as a proportion of property income as against non-interest forms of property income. I do not know what fundamental or important changes that implies. Indeed, it does not seem to me to imply very much at all. In other words, I think it is a fairly silly question, which is fairly predictable coming from the `fairies at the bottom of the garden' party.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade whether he has seen the article in the Weekend Australian on 16 April by D. D. McNicoll relating to drug war lord Khun Sa or whether he saw the subsequent program on A Current Affair in which an Australian television reporter, Stephen Rice, interviewed Khun Sa at his headquarters in eastern Burma. What is the Government's reaction to Khun Sa's offer to destroy up to half the world's annual heroin supply in return for $50m in cash or agricultural aid for the next eight years, given that this year there was a record crop of opium which will soon be hitting the streets of Sydney and other centres in Australia with a devastating effect on the lives of many Australians? Given that the problem is essentially political, as Khun Sa uses the money from opium sales to finance the struggle for independence by the Shan people in eastern Burma, has the Government been approached about the possibility of acting as a mediator between the rebel hill people around the borders of Burma, including the Shans, and the central government of General Ne Win in Rangoon? If so, what is our position and, if not, would the Government seriously consider acting in such a role, given that these wars have been going on for 40 years and opium is the main source of finance for many of the rebel armies?

—It does seem to be the case that the Burmese opium war lord-I think he is properly so described-Khun Sa is said to have offered to eliminate all drug trafficking and production in his territory if the Australian Government will provide him with aid to the value of $50m a year for eight years. Needless to say, this is not an offer which the Government would seriously consider. In fact, I think it involves a degree of breathtaking naivety to take any of this at face value. Khun Sa has a record of 25 years of violence and narcotics trafficking. He is not a revolutionary leader but a major drug trafficker. The Australian Government is simply not in the business of paying criminals to refrain from criminal activity. Of course, the Government cooperates with regional governments in fighting drug production and trafficking. It is also closely involved in action within the United Nations system to counter drug problems. We have not been approached to act as a mediator between the Burmese Government and insurgent groups within Burma. In the circumstances there is no advantage in speculating on what our response to such an approach might be.

—I ask the Minister for Finance whether, firstly, he has seen reports of the views put forward in an address to the Young Labor National Conference last weekend by his colleague the Minister for Employment and Education Services regarding policies of what I think Mr Duncan called `the rational Left'. Secondly, does the Minister regard the term `the rational Left' as being itself a non sequitur? Thirdly, specifically does the Minister share his colleague's view that policies of the so-called rational Left involving an increase in spending and therefore, of course, an increase in taxing, should be seen `as an investment in our future, not as a cost'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about seven months since Senator Stone first sat in the Senate, so he is not a very experienced politician; but I will give him credit for one thing. It is now about 20 minutes to three. I thought Senator Stone's question would be the first question in Question Time today. From any half competent Opposition this question, or a question along the lines of it, would have been the first question. It took the Opposition over 40 minutes before one of its newest members finally had enough political nous to stand up and ask what was obviously, I would have thought, out there in arc lights, the question of the day-at least according to the newspaper reports.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked whether I think `rational Left' is a non sequitur. I have never known for certain what `Left' means, other than to make the fairly obvious point that it means different things to different people. I suppose that one can be a bit more confident about what is rational. Certainly, one can be more confident still about what is not rational. For example, it is not rational to believe that one can put a fusion reactor into the boot of a motor car and generate electricity to hydrolyse water to produce hydrogen on which to run an internal combustion engine-as a good friend of Senator Stone believes can be done. Even if one could overcome the technical problems of fitting a fusion reactor into the boot of a Volkswagen, if one had already generated electricity it would raise the question of why one would not have an electric car instead of going through another couple of processes of hydrolysing water and then having an internal combustion engine powered by hydrogen. That is certainly not rational. Nor, for the information of Senator Stone, is it rational to believe that one can make water run uphill and generate electricity while it is doing so. His National Party colleagues from north Queensland obviously believe it can be done and continue to demand that the Commonwealth Government should put good taxpayers' money into funding feasibility studies-whether studies on how to make water run uphill while generating electricity or engineering studies for the construction of dams, I do not know.

However, I return to the substance of the question. As I said, I give Senator Stone faint praise for apparently being the only person in the whole Opposition with enough political nous to realise that it would not be a bad idea to fly with a question like this. But it is not going to be as good as Senator Stone might have thought. I do not blame him for that. The plain fact is that I have not read the transcript of what Mr Duncan said. I do not know whether there is a transcript or a text. Regardless of whether there is one or both, I have not read anything from Mr Duncan. I have read, rather hastily I may say, some newspaper reports of what Mr Duncan is alleged to have said. In fact, I think I have a copy of it here. He is alleged to have said-I can quite believe that he did say this:
I believe we must face up to the hard issue of increasing tax revenue, particularly by further reducing avoidance through loopholes in business-tax collection.

I think that this Government has certainly gone a very long way to achieving that objective. I agree with Mr Duncan that that is an objective that should be pursued. Tax avoidance, whether it be by corporations or by individuals, is something which governments should not tolerate if they can stamp it out. As we know, this Government has taken major measures which have raised by now probably billions of dollars of additional revenue produced by income that previously was escaping untaxed. I am certainly entirely with Mr Duncan on that. I agree with him. I only wish that the Opposition would take such an enlightened view instead of continuing to provide succour and assistance to tax avoiders and evaders, as it has in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his response. I thank him for his remarks about the nature of any increases in taxes as recommended by his colleague Mr Duncan, but I want him to respond to the second part of my question, which is whether he agrees with Mr Duncan's reported views, which the Minister has not denied, that the policies involving an increase in spending, which of course those forms of increased taxes would be required to pay for, should be seen-I quote again:

QUESTION.PARA: as an investment in our future, not as a cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The alleged statement to which Senator Stone refers is also in this newspaper clipping that I have and it refers to more education. I do not think that Mr Duncan would be alone in believing that expenditure on education should, to a significant extent, be regarded as an investment. Indeed, I think Senator Stone would agree with that. He may not agree with some people on the proportion which should be ascribed as investment and the proportion which should be ascribed as consumption by the individual, but I do not think he would deny that certainly some component of education expenditure ought to be regarded as an investment. Indeed, some types of industry assistance ought to be regarded as an investment.
—I am talking about increases in it, not the proportion of it.

—I was coming to that; do not be so impatient. Whether the proportion of whatever level of Government expenditure is devoted to those activities should be increased vis-a-vis all the other claims on Government expenditure is a matter for both economic and, in my view, value judgment, as indeed is the proportion within quite a wide band of gross domestic product (GDP) which should be public sector expenditure. —My judgment, which is not just a judgment-I would claim that it is a rational belief, a tautology actually-is that in the long term the level of expenditure is determined by the level of taxation. In a note he wrote in the first week of March 1983, Senator Stone very properly chided Mr Howard for his fiscal irresponsibility in leaving that sort of mess behind him. While, in the short term, irresponsible Treasurers-of which Mr Howard was one-can maintain a level of expenditure well in excess of the level of government revenue, in the long term it cannot be done.

The answer read as follows-

The offsets program allows overseas suppliers to undertake activities to generate offsets credits to be applied to future obligations. Such credits may, with the approval of my Department, be transferred to another overseas supplier.

Conversely offsets obligations may also be transferred where this approach will be beneficial to Australian industry but ultimately the offsets obligation remains the responsibility of the overseas supplier which made the original sale to the Government and incurred the obligation.

Both of these forms of offsets transfer are described in the published guidelines for Australian civil offsets program and appropriate procedures described. An essential feature of these procedures is that the approval of the offsets authority must be obtained for any transfer.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BRAIN TRANSPLANTS: USE OF ABORTED FOETUSES

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 April I had a question without notice from Senator Harradine concerning brain transplants and the use of aborted foetuses. I am now in a position to answer that question.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the clinical treatment of Parkinson's disease sufferers in the United Kingdom by the utilisation of foetal brain cells. While this procedure is essentially clinical treatment rather than research, I am, however, aware that the Medical Research Ethics Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) has addressed the use of foetal tissue in its report entitled Ethics in Medical Research Involving the Human Foetus and Human Foetal Tissue. The report states inter alia that:
dissection of the foetus should not be carried out while a heart beat is still apparent or there are other obvious signs of life.
The consent of the mother and wherever practicable that of the father, should be obtained before research is undertaken.
Under these research guidelines the obtaining of brain tissue from live foetuses would be unethical and not condoned in this country.

In so far as Dr Kuhse's statements are concerned on this issue, neither the NHMRC nor, indeed, the Government is necessarily influenced by the personal views of particular researchers. Professor Singer's NHMRC supported project, on which Dr Kuhse is a co-investigator, is monitoring the development of techniques in the field of human foetal tissue, in-vitro fertilisation and embryos and is conducting research into the ethical, social and legal aspects of these techniques.

I am advised that members of Professor Singer's research team are highly regarded in their fields and that the NHMRC considers their work of major importance in Australia at the present time. Dr Kuhse's viewpoint on this issue does not justify the withdrawal of NHMRC funds from this project.

Finally, on the issue of foetal tissue transplantation, I believe that this throws up many questions of an ethical, legal and social nature. It would be a very foolish Minister who could pretend to answer all these issues without receiving considered and thoughtful advice on the matter. I would point out that the issue has already been considered in part by the Australian Health Ministers Conference in 1987, which has recommended that commercial exploitation of human foetal tissue should be prevented, and that jurisdictions introduce appropriate legislation.

Further to this, the Commonwealth and State Health Ministers, Attorneys-General and Social Welfare Ministers have supported the establishment of the National Bioethics Consultative Committee. This Committee will provide advice to governments and this issue may be a suitable one for the Australian Health Ministers Conference to refer to the National Bioethics Consultative Committee.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL SITUATION OF AUSSAT PTY LTD

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The precarious financial situation confronting Aussat and the need for the Government to take urgent action to ensure its viability.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The precarious financial situation of Aussat Pty Ltd should be addressed urgently by the Australian public because it is quite clear that the present Government proposes to do nothing at all about it or a whole range of public trading enterprises until at least the Australian Labor Party (ALP) National Conference. The tragedy is that, in the meantime, Aussat will be bleeding to death. Australia's national satellite system was established by the previous Government in the early 1980s in the fond belief that, by making available 49 per cent of its share capital to the private sector, there would be sufficient funds available to establish a national satellite system. Aussat, with enormous start-up costs and, understandably, very little by way of operating profits, has reached the situation where it now faces some very serious financial decisions. Yet the Government, for its own political reasons, refuses to do anything about that crisis and has effectively washed its hands of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are these: Aussat was established finally by the present Government with a $75m injection of funds from the Government and $25m from Telecom Australia. Since then it has accumulated losses of $96.2m. It is expected that in the current financial year it will return a loss of $10.2m. Originally it was granted $455m worth of borrowings. It has drawn down and expended in excess of $430m. So its financial position is fairly clear: it is gravely short of funds. Because of the limited life of the first two of the three first generation satellites which have been in orbit, it will be necessary for some crunch decisions to be made. There is to be a board meeting of Aussat tomorrow which will have to address this vital question. The board will be confronted with a choice as to whether to embark on a $600m, at least, contract for second generation satellites or a scaled down option, allowing the third first generation satellite to stay in orbit for the rest of its natural life, which would perhaps take it through to 1995, and then launching one second generation satellite and leasing some space on Intelsat VII. If that is done, Aussat will be looking at only a mere $350m.

Those sums of money are very large indeed. They are not sums that can be appropriated lightly by government. The present Government has shown a massive disinclination to make funds available to a whole range of public trading enterprises-for example, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia which, on one view, needs $1.6 billion; Qantas Airways Ltd, which needs probably $600m to $1 billion over the next three years; or Australian Airlines, which already has had to defer the purchase of A320s at a cost of $650m. A whole range of enterprises are pressing the Government for additional funding.

The crisis that confronts Aussat will come to a head in a most unsatisfactory manner because the Government, with its blinkered ideology, will not take the only rational course available to it, and that is to put the risk of capital fund-raising into the private sector where it belongs. That decision will have to be made against the background and with the knowledge that Aussat's prospects of being able to fund borrowings of $280m-if one goes for the $600m contract-let alone finance the balance out of accumulated earnings over the next five years, are minimal. Therefore, it stands to reason that if Aussat were to operate in accordance with its charter under the Satellite Communications Act, it would not be able to operate on sound commercial principles. It simply does not have the capacity to raise those funds in the marketplace. Yet what will happen, one suspects, is that the Government will be forced to underwrite that first set of borrowings and guarantee implicitly the fulfilment of the contract. That very disturbing situation has come about because of the massive inertia and inaction on the part of the Government over the years it has been in office.

One very disturbing matter which is not known in the public arena is that in 1982, when Aussat was being put onto a commercial basis, it was necessary to borrow a significant quantity of funds in addition to the $100m from the Government and Telecom. In order to obtain that bridging finance, which was of the order of $455m, the commercial bank consortia insisted on a letter of comfort from the Commonwealth to make it clear that the banks were concerned about the debt-equity ratio, which then stood at about 5 : 1. It insisted that a letter of comfort be provided in the following terms: that the Government give an explicit assurance that the debt-equity ratio would not fall below 350 : 75 during the term of the bridging finance. That is what the Government did. In June 1982 it provided that guarantee.

That guarantee in relation to the bridging finance continued for the life of those loans-until April 1985. Yet it is quite clear, from all we know from the annual reports and elsewhere, that there has been a significant deterioration in the gearing of Aussat, to the point where the debt-equity ratio, on one view, could be regarded as 117 : 1, if one simply takes the accumulated losses and sets them off against the extent of the borrowings. Yet this Government has not honoured that letter of comfort. It has allowed it to be ignored. It has allowed Aussat's financial situation to deteriorate to a point where the commercial banks would not have a bar of providing any funds whatsoever for Aussat unless they were assured of an explicit guarantee. That is what will be put upon the Government in the near future. The proposal at the moment, from a board which is deeply divided about Aussat's future prospects and future investment strategies, is likely to involve asking the Government to sanction the entering into of the contract to purchase the second generation satellites next month. That will then confront the Government with a very serious capital funding decision.

Where that decision is fundamentally wrong and unnecessary is that it does not need to be taken by the Government at all, and the Government does not need to become a guarantor. The taxpayers of this country should not be put into a position where there is a very real likelihood that they will have to cough up some hundreds of millions of dollars in due course. That is a risk that should be taken by the commercial sector. It is quite clear that there are many in the private sector who would be prepared to take that risk. To the extent that they are not, that is the consequence of not having a commercial enterprise.

We would propose that Aussat should be wholly privatised, that it should be the responsibility of the private sector to make those crunch decisions, to put it into a profitable situation where it can generate earnings that will be sufficient to fund its debts, otherwise it will go to the wall. If it is not to go to the wall, it could be taken over by or merged with the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) (OTC), which I suggest is a very rational approach, but again one that is highly unlikely to be contemplated by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe OTC should be privatised?

—Certainly, OTC should be 100 per cent privatised. If there were a merger between the two, OTC, which does have significant profits, would be able to make decisions which would be compatible with the future of the national satellite system, which would be able to take account of OTC's long held expertise in negotiating with Intelsat. It would then be able to provide domestic tails for international calls and we would have end to end service, which would be much more efficient and effective than the present competitive arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways there is a very serious conflict of interest in the present situation, and not simply because, as a result of its injection of funds, Telecom has two directors on the board of Aussat who undoubtedly would have a different view of the world and who would prefer that Aussat not expand its operations and that it remain an indigent relative, that it work in close association with and probably under the aegis of Telecom, and that ultimately it be restricted in its range of activities. Certainly Telecom would take the view-and I am sure this Government will too, in its frantic endeavours to protect the monopoly situation of the basic network and all that hangs off it-that Aussat should not be allowed to compete on the switched network, that Aussat should not be able to make available resale capacity for those who lease or buy transponder space, that Aussat should not be able to provide a range of services by way of direct broadcast or otherwise that would obviously be available to it if the Government were prepared to face up to real marketplace decisions.

I suspect that Alan Ramsay, who made a point of characterising the unfortunate and hapless Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in terms which could have him described only as a badly bruised Biggles, blames him for almost all of the privatisation foul-ups that have taken place to date. But it is clear that whoever is at fault, the fact remains that there are going to be virtually no real privatisation initiatives from this Government. It has been kicked to death from all sides, by Caucus, by the State organisations and by the left wing of the Labor Party and, in due course, by the National Conference. That means that the Government and this Minister will be in no position to take those decisions which they know, in their heart of hearts, are not only rational and desirable but also put the risk where it ought to be-and that is not confronting the taxpayers of Australia but confronting those in the marketplace who are prepared to make those decisions and to put the money up front. If the money is not there and if the market is not there, they will not put it up. That, of course, is part of the major problem. This Government has a conflict of interest in its present ownership of Aussat, because it is not prepared to jeopardise Telecom's monopoly and it is not prepared to give Aussat those--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support privatisation of Telecom?
—I will deal with that on another occasion. There is a lot to be said for making Telecom a lot more competitive than it is at the moment, and I know that the honourable senator knows that too.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with what the Auditor-General had to say about Aussat's current financial position in his certificate issued in September last year, because I think on close examination it becomes rather dated and gives rise to a particular concern. As a result of the accumulated losses, one would have thought at first blush that Aussat had virtually nothing left by way of shareholders' funds, but by a cute accounting trick we have a situation where the Board, aided and abetted by the Auditor-General, has put forward in the annual report that Aussat has accumulated losses of only about $59m. That is achieved by the following device: by the application of accounting standard 3, future tax benefits are able to be carried forward if the ability of the company to realise that benefit is virtually certain. The standard goes on:
This test of virtual certainty will only be met in rare and exceptional circumstances.

Bear in mind that the Auditor-General is the only one who has had access to contracts with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), which has currently in excess of one-third of the transponder space, and Bond, who has a strategic overholding at the moment, a position taken no doubt in anticipation of a deregulation of the market, and perhaps the sale of Aussat, but undoubtedly Bond will be sadly disappointed and will need to scale down the extent of the demand for Aussat's transponder usage. If that is the case-and no-one else has seen those contracts-one has very serious questions about how one can be virtually certain that future income streams are going to be able to fund that acute debt service problem that will undoubtedly arise if the second generation contracts are approved.

I would like to quote from one rather odd source-odd for my purposes-and that is a document recently released by the H. V. Evatt Research Centre on the capital funding of public enterprises in Australia. It states that in 1985-86 and 1986-87, the stated future financial objectives, including improving gearing ratios through accumulation of reserves, were an Aussat objective. That has certainly not come about. It goes on to state that there has been an obvious lack of available information on pricing policy and there exists some grounds for concern on overall marketing performance. But most importantly, the report states that in the absence of a further injection of equity by government, the debt-equity ratio will be higher than management considers appropriate. Then it recites that Aussat currently forecasts post-tax profits of $20m by 1990, rising to $30m by 1995. That is very small beer indeed.

It is quite clear that on those figures Aussat will not be in a position to meet its debt funding obligations, and it will need to call upon the guarantees that the Government will no doubt in due course provide. That will be an outrage. It will be totally unnecessary and a reflection of the Government's ideological commitment, its blinkered approach to the whole question of privatisation, its refusal to allow the marketplace to operate in this area and its refusal to give Aussat the market space that it so desperately needs. I have to say that Aussat is doing its best, but it is so encumbered by such restrictions that it is in very real danger of bleeding to death. It is now close to bankruptcy and, through the fault of the Government, those funds, if funds are to be made available, will be ones that the taxpayer will, in due course, be asked to provide. That is a very sad situation, because it is unnecessary. The Board will no doubt be confronted with that decision about whether to suggest a large or small second generation purchase, but ultimately, of course, the question is whether future borrowings can be justified at all.

There is a lot to be said for the proposition that, given the way the market is structured-and Telecom very quickly is getting its optical fibre network into place-there may well not be a great deal of demand for Aussat services, unless it is able to provide a multipoint service, direct broadcasting to remote areas and elsewhere and extensions of its recently launched Starnet arrangement. Aussat's viability will depend largely on Telecom's pricing of broadband services and that will be very much a function of Telecom's optical fibre capacity. As that expands, Aussat undoubtedly will lose business. It will not be allowed to compete because of the Government's refusal to put Telecom at risk and its refusal to deregulate the telecommunications industry-and we will hear about that, no doubt, over the next month or so. Honourable senators can rest assured that this Government has utterly capitulated to the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association and others and that there will be perhaps a few cosmetic concessions, but essentially it will be the status quo. We will not see any competition in the telecommunications industry. That will be a function of a desire to protect Telecom at all costs and, as a consequence, to send Aussat down the drain.

It is against that background that taxpayers are entitled to ask: Why should we be expected to underwrite borrowings and future streams of income, up to $600m, and why should we be expected to allow these conflicts of interest to continue? Why should OTC want to expand its use of Intelsat when Aussat would like to expand into the South Pacific through Fiji, the Solomon Islands and New Zealand? The answer is that that does not have to take place if there is a merger, but because of the Government's conflict of interest and its craven support for the Telecom position, it will ensure that Aussat does not have that capacity to compete.

Aussat is desperately hoping it will be able to create new demand, especially amongst outback truck drivers and remote rural property holders. But the market is likely to be very competitive and there will be long lead times. If that is the case, one can well understand why no commercial bank would be remotely interested in taking the sorts of risks that would be necessary to provide those funds. Ultimately, the reality is that Aussat faces a grave financial situation. It is in a position of crisis because of the inability of this Government to act, because of its pusillanimous response to all of the pressures upon it on all sides, its craven capitulation to the forces of antirationalism and a Minister who is very much under threat, even from such staunch ALP journalists as Alan Ramsey. I can understand why it has all become too hard for him-but it is a bit unfair for the rest of the community who will be asked to pick up the tab and it is very unfair on Aussat when it is not being given room to expand and develop or given the ability to raise funds in the private sector which it so desperately needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects absolutely the terms of this matter and the supporting argument that Senator Alston, that scourge of cross-subsidy and of rural Australia, that fierce deregulator and maniacally pro-private sector competition person, has put before us today. His credentials ought to be well understood because they misinform every aspect of his contribution to this debate. Let me say right at the outset, in dealing with the question of Aussat Pty Ltd, that it has always been recognised that a national satellite system was a high risk venture. I make no apologies for that; nor does the Government; nor do our predecessors. We knew that and we entered into it on that basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make very strongly today is that the major risks associated with the first generation of satellites are now behind us with, first, the successful launch and now the continued operation and increasing utilisation of the total system. An increasing utilisation is fully expected of the Aussat satellite, albeit perhaps in not quite the way that was originally predicted. With the development of technology that continues to occur, the character of Aussat services has evolved and developed. The Aussat system was always directed towards broadcasting and telecommunications. While that dual purpose remains, the truth is, as Senator Alston has indicated, the development of fibre optic technology will alter in a quite significant way the telecommunications side of the market, meaning that Aussat will need to rely increasingly, comparatively speaking, on broadcasting and specialised services which are emerging in response to the specific opportunities and unique capabilities of satellites, such as point to multipoint services and communications links to remote areas.

Notwithstanding this development and evolution of the concept of what a satellite system might bring to this country, there is no doubt that utilisation patterns are increasing and that Aussat is perfectly capable of remaining viable. Before we get into the detailed questions of finance that have been raised, it ought to be appreciated just what an extraordinarily diverse range of services are already being provided through the satellite system. So far as people living in remote parts of Australia, who have been the primary beneficiaries, are concerned, the list really is substantial. There are the Australian homestead and community broadcasting satellite services (HACBSS); the remote commercial television service, which is operational in Western Australia and central Australia, and which came into operation in north-eastern Australia just yesterday; Telecom Australia's service providing communications to customers in remote areas, the Itevra service; the State specific government communications network, Q-Net, which has been operating in Queensland. There are also specialised networks in the provision of data and other communications links for remote mining and construction sites.

Other services that Aussat provides include the distribution by the Special Broadcasting Service of its television programs to reach most capital cities and a large number of provincial and regional areas; the national satellite based commercial radio news gathering and distribution network, Macsat, run by the Macquarie Broadcasting outfit. Other satellite distribution systems are either in the process of implementation or planning in the commercial radio scene. There is the distribution of newsagency information and other data services run by Australian Associated Press; also the establishment of a range of private video, voice and data services for a wide range of governmental and corporate sector users. There is the distribution to hotels and clubs of video entertainment and information services on a subscription basis-Sky Channel-and there is the Starnet corporate data service. That is a pretty formidable list when those bodies are put together. It can be said with some confidence and accuracy that Aussat obviously is providing a range of communication services with a very great deal of value, covering the whole domestic, commercial and industrial range of needs of the Australian population.

What then of Aussat's finances and financial prospects, against that background? Let me lay to rest right at the outset the suggestion that Aussat is in a precarious financial position and heading rapidly towards eventual bankruptcy-unless and until Senator Alston's preferred scenario eventuates and massive new opportunities can be created for Aussat in its service delivery and marketing arrangements and, in particular, the capacity to make major inroads into Telecom's present monopoly provision of basic network services. I simply say that none of that is necessary-quite apart from its desirability, and we do not share Senator Alston's view of the world in that respect. None of it is necessary to guarantee in any way Aussat's financial situation in the future. On the contrary, Aussat is steadily and deliberately heading into a profit situation.

While present revenues of Aussat are slightly below original plans, as I have acknowledged in papers I have distributed, so, on the other side of the coin, are some of the costs. It is still fully expected that Aussat will move into a position where it will be able to pay dividends to its shareholders-that is, the Government directly-and to Telecom. Aussat has healthy cash flow, currently running at around $64m a year, which is more than sufficient to meet its commitments. The Aussat balance sheet, which has been fully approved by the Auditor-General without qualification, showed net shareholder funds of $59.2m at 30 June last year. The current figure is $54.4m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it as at September last year?

—I am telling the honourable senator what the current figure is. It is $54.4m at the moment. To my mind, that does not represent a significant run-down in the total environment that we are presently living in and evaluating. It should be recognised when all this is put into context that Aussat is still properly described as a new company. It came into existence only in November 1981 for the purpose of establishing, owning and operating a national satellite system with ownership that now comprises 75 per cent Commonwealth, 25 per cent Commonwealth indirectly through Telecom. From 1981 to 1985 Aussat's principal activity was just that: the design, construction and installation of the satellite system-not its operation, because obviously it had to be put in place. During this time Aussat could have no revenue simply because it had no services to market, but it did incur heavy expenditure to commission the satellites and earth stations that were necessary for its operations. That heavy up-front expenditure, and the lack of revenue early in its operations, of course meant that Aussat had to bite deeply into shareholders' capital. The initial equity of $100m that was vested in it took that into account. The up-front cost was judged to be acceptable in the wider national interests such as remote broadcasting and so on of the kind I have described.

SPEECH.PARA: Aussat's financial forecasts have always been that it would start to show a profit in 1989-90. In fact, my latest understanding is that Aussat could produce a small profit in 1988-89, a year earlier that has been expected. Revenue has increased rapidly over the period of its operations, while expenditure has tapered off with the launch and commissioning of the third satellite in September last year. The revenues for the last three financial years have been as follows: for 1985-86, $28.6m; for 1986-87, $73.7m; and for 1987-88 an estimated $93.4m. That increasing revenue has itself been directly translated into decreasing losses. The net operating losses for the same period have been-if one tabulates them side by side one will see the force of what I am saying-for 1985-86, $42.6m; for 1986-87, down to $35m; and for 1987-88 an estimated $12.1m only. Next year, 1988-89, will be the first year in which all three satellites will be operating and as a result Aussat will be able to benefit fully from the market provided by the substantial investments involved.

I am told that at present Aussat has contracts covering 75 per cent of all its available transponders and is actively marketing its remaining capacity. I am also told that by international standards that involves very high utilisation of available capacity. In this context it should be mentioned that the delay of some 13 months in launching Aussat III which was caused by a failure of the Ariane rocket in early 1986, quite naturally delayed the start of a number of services. But in accounting terms Aussat remains in a relatively sound position for a new venture in a previously untested market. It has undertaken the bulk of its initial capital investment and is moving towards generating sufficient profits to repay its loans and produce a dividend for its shareholders. Management accounts, which will be considered by the Aussat board at its next meeting, show that in March 1988 the company recorded its first monthly accounting profit, of some $3m. In cost terms Aussat is already sustaining itself. It is generating sufficient revenue to more than cover its operating expenditure and its loan commitments. What that simply means is that, short of a disaster, no additional equity injections will be required by shareholders to support Aussat's activities.

I turn to the suggestion that Aussat is somehow masking its true financial position by offsetting its operating losses with future tax benefits, the bit of scuttlebutt that had a run in a couple of newspaper reports and was seized upon assiduously, as one might expect, by Senator Alston. Whether he was inspired by it or whether in turn he inspired the newspaper comment in question must remain a matter of speculation. I would remind honourable senators that Aussat is a public company registered under the Companies Act and is legally required to pursue the accounting practices expected of all public companies. Its treatment of past losses is a perfectly proper accounting practice. It has been accepted by the Auditor-General in his approval on an unqualified basis, as I have already indicated, of Aussat's accounts.

Having said that, and indeed having said everything that I have put on the record, it cannot be denied that there are risks involved with Aussat's business. It has to maintain a high usage of its available capacity to ensure that a higher level of revenue continues. There is also the possibility, although remote, of an unexpected failure in the system, once launched, but that would be most unusual. In short, Aussat is performing as would any new company which has made a very large capital investment, and is now moving to a position where its revenue will start to yield operating profits and dividends to its shareholders.

I have not touched on Aussat's proposal for the next generation of satellites, and I do not propose to do so. The Aussat Board will be deliberating in the very near future on tenders before forwarding its recommendations to the Government. It would be quite inappropriate for me to address that in any detail at the moment. All I say is that the Government will give very careful consideration to Aussat's proposals. It will scrutinise in minute detail the future financial prospects and the returns to the community from the new generation satellites before giving any go-ahead. No-one can assume that those decisions have already been made. They remain to be made, and will be made on the basis, as I have said, of the most minute scrutiny of the costs and risks involved.

In the meantime, there seems to be little reason objectively, whatever might be the case politically, to doubt Aussat's current financial position. It certainly does not require any intervention by shareholders to support its continued operations. It certainly does not require any of the fundamental upheaval of the telecommunications delivery system of the kind that is so dear to the Opposition, or more particularly to Senator Alston, in order to secure its financial viability. On that basis the defence rests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are discussing a matter of public importance relating to the precarious financial situation confronting Aussat Pty Ltd and the need for the Government to take urgent action to ensure its viability. A good argument can be made that Aussat should never have got, shall we say, off the ground and that it was started for the benefit of Bond Media Ltd primarily.
—Packer.

—I am sorry-Packer. But we should also remember in this context that it did get off the ground in the period of a former coalition government. That having been said, we had better address the future. It is an issue that is of concern to a great many Australians. I certainly welcome the opportunity to be involved in this debate today on behalf of the Australian Democrats. However, while Aussat has sustained some large losses-and it will be recalled that its after-tax loss last year was $18m-it has also dramatically increased its revenue. Although Aussat may or may not be profitable within the life of the first generation, it has begun to address the fact that the Government may not continue to devote large amounts of finance to it. Perhaps today's debate is, as much as anything, a result of speculation caused by the general trend of this Government towards privatisation, a trend away from the support of public institutions and authorities. Therefore, the Government cannot have any strong objection to the fact that these sorts of debates are raised and that they raise broader concerns in the community in as much as they arise out of that trend which we are seeing with this Government. This debate and some of its consequences are raised by considerations which appear to be taking place within the Government. Issues such as potential mergers of Aussat, Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) and Telecom Australia and the prospects of privatisation or deregulation, or both, of any or all of those organisations are part of this broader debate.
