SPEECH.PARA: It has been pointed out by industry sources that, although the Hawke Government was prepared to make a commitment not to sell OTC-Aussat following any merger, it would, of course-and after today's contribution from the Opposition it becomes clearer and clearer-be first in line for privatisation if a Liberal-National Government were to come into power. However, I shall say more about that later.

Aussat is addressing the whole question of its financial viability and its future. That is a current matter for Aussat. It has looked at scaling down the second stage of new satellites, as part of that process, reducing potentially the cost by $600m for the new satellites. This proposal would involve a downgrading of transponder power from 50 to 30 watts and by the possible launching of the Chinese `Long March' rocket. These sorts of considerations are quite appropriate, as indeed is perhaps the possibility of abandoning, at least for now, the second generation altogether, as part of the deliberations of Aussat in the current situation.

Certainly, in commenting on that part of the debate which raises questions of merger, coordination and cooperation between the various telecommunications institutions, Telecom, Aussat and OTC, the Australian Democrats acknowledge that, greater coordination is needed. This need has been acknowledged by the Telecom Chief General Manager, Mr Bob McKinnon, I refer to an item published in the Australian of 18 November last year, where, through Mr McKinnon, Telecom called on the Federal Government to allow it to work more closely with Aussat and OTC to ensure that Australia maintains its position in the increasingly competitive world telecommunications market. Quoting from the report, Mr McKinnon pointed out, quite rightly, that:

With the rapid changes in the global scene, as well as our own local scene, we now have to look with more imagination than in the past to achieving a result which is good for the country and good for all our consumers.

One question that needs to be kept firmly in mind in debates such as this is the matter of obtaining a result that will be good for our country and for the consumers of products services by Telecom, Aussat and OTC. In a debate like this it is not helpful to take entrenched ideological positions which, in the end, are not really concerned about the fundamental good of the nation and its people who depend on these services, and who need these services to be up-to-date, well coordinated and able to provide the best possible service, in the context of new technologies, and so on.

There is no doubt that there are potential benefits of administrative rationalisation. While the Government has ruled out a merger between Telecom, OTC and Aussat, as I have said, the possibility of an OTC-Aussat merger has been, and I believe ought to be, looked at quite seriously. In the context of this debate, it could also help in fulfilling the capital needs of Aussat. However, one very important point that I would make here is that the Democrats reject the proposition put by Senator Alston in his contribution to this debate that Aussat should be privatised. In that scenario, there would be a need to make Aussat attractive enough to a buyer, and that would involve giving Aussat access to the lucrative Sydney-Melbourne telecommunications network. That, of course, would destroy straight away Telecom's cross-subsidising price structure, and therefore it should be rejected outright.

Of course, the most likely buyer of Aussat would be none other than Bond Media, and if the Bond organisation owned Aussat it could swing the satellites around in order to cover its interests in Chile and other parts of the Pacific. As with a number of other debates that are current at the moment, I find it interesting that the view from within the coalition Opposition does not seem to be a terribly unanimous one, because the very points that I have made about the likely purchaser of a privatised Aussat and about the likely result of the purchase of Aussat by Bond Media have been made constantly by Ian Macphee, a prominent member of the Liberal Party. At this stage I shall make a couple of additional points, which were also made by Ian Macphee as recently as 2 March this year in relation to this issue. I refer to some comments that he made on the ABC PM program of 2 March 1988, when he said:
Well, if it was simply sold as it now is, nobody would buy it. It's so heavily in debt and another $600 million has to be allocated to it.

He then went on to express the concerns that I have also expressed. I think that is really the crunch issue when it comes to questions of privatising, especially in the context of an instrumentality which is looking for further capitalisation. The worry, however, for the Democrats is that both sides of parliament seem at the moment to be obsessed with staying on Bondy's Christmas card list. We do not feel too secure hearing Senator Alston being very upfront on the issue of privatisation, with perhaps the Government so far being not quite so upfront, because the Government, having destroyed television ownership to accommodate Bond and others and having turned a blind eye to Bond's monopoly on the television in pubs and clubs, is now looking at inviting Bond into the telecommunications arena here in this country. The Democrats believe that that proposal should be knocked on the head.

The Opposition's policy of complete deregulation of communications has got it in rather a mess, too. As well, the Government's devotion to its mates over and above the interests of ordinary Australians has landed it in hot water with its back bench and, of course, most notably, with its voters. On the question of privatisation of Aussat, or indeed more generally, it seems that there is this rather knee jerk reaction involved, a sort of what I call Animal Farm mentality, where the notion of the pigs in Animal Farm was `four legs good, two legs bad'-a knee jerk reaction to an issue. I think in the case of privatisation the point is put this way: Investment by private sector, good, but investment by public sector bad. This, of course, is something that the Australian Democrats consistently question.

In relation to the argument concerning the investment that needs to go into Aussat from the private sector, that is, money that comes from Bond et al, where is the inherent good in that? Are we not suffering at the moment from a foreign debt substantially in place because of the foreign borrowings that are taken to make such investments, with many of them highly unproductive and negatively geared within the corporate structure, and to the detriment, to the extent of at least $2 billion, of the Australian taxpaying public? I cannot see where the good is in that. On the other hand, there is the matter of a commitment by the Government to support, and to underwrite wherever it is necessary, the injections of funds that are necessary. Possibly some thought could even be given to the question of who it is that creates credit in our economy. That is an issue that perhaps ought to be looked at.

Of course, there is a body of thinking very much against the view that public sector investment is necessarily bad. Apart from negative gearing, there are other issues involved with the reflex action that investment from the private sector is necessarily good. What about the public interest, and what about issues such as diversity, particularly in relation to media and communication, which is what we are discussing at the moment? Surely there is a role for government to ensure that diversity and in particular access apply in such industries. What about conflict of interest within the corporate sector, because in the telecommunications industry in particular that issue should be addressed? What about issues of national interest, to which I referred earlier? What about the point that decisions which are made in telecommunications generally must be made in the national interest? When one thinks about the Bond connection with Chile, that is perhaps an area where questions should be asked.

In relation to the developing international links in telecommunications, which of course are inevitable, I believe, as do the Democrats, that the Government has a responsibility to overview that general area in the community interest to see whether hotel channels should bring us, for example, mud wrestling from Indiana, or whether the Government still has a large role to play and can provide Australians with something just a little bit different and a little more significant. However, on all sides of politics it is important to become serious and ensure the long term viability of Australia's telecommunications and satellite industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —In his opening remarks I think Senator Alston set the scene very well, that is, that the matter is serious and that Aussat Pty Ltd is truly at risk. He then outlined the type of action that needs to be taken. In response, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, said that he may not share Senator Alston's view of the world, but he then failed to share with us what his view is. In response he gave one of the better examples of his woolly words, to which we have become so accustomed, to evade and talk around the issue and pad out the time; in fact he gave us no indication as to what the Government is truly attempting to do. I was looking for an argument of substance during the entire time that he spoke to justify the apparent deliberate strategy being pursued by the Government to place Aussat's financial viability in trouble. The Minister's only positive statement in favour of Aussat was that it was viable in accounting terms. That was the only time that the Minister made a statement to the effect that Aussat had a definite future. The Minister stressed the riskiness of the very nature of Aussat's business. I refer to a Caucus discussion paper prepared by the Minister, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Aussat will have substantial requirements for financing the proposed replacement satellites which are scheduled to be launched in 1991-92. The estimated capital cost is approximately $600m. The program is planned to be funded from retained earnings and from additional borrowings of up to $280m for which Loan Council approval will be required.
However, at no stage today did Senator Evans say that Aussat had any real prospect, without subsequent Government action, of keeping to its game plan and, indeed, becoming financially viable.

Aussat faces many problems, and among them is its inability to compete fairly against Telecom Australia. Indeed, it could be said that the high hopes with which Aussat began in 1981 have been considerably reduced as a result of the operating restrictions which prevent it from competing fairly with Telecom and because it is under-capitalised. Both of those reasons can be regarded as flowing from the Government's lack of honest commitment to the future of Aussat.

When Aussat was established by the Fraser Government in 1981 the intention was that 49 per cent of its shareholding would be offered to the general public and that 51 per cent would be retained by the Government. When this Government came to power, it changed the way that Aussat was to operate when it introduced the Satellite Communications Act of 1984. In so doing it took 100 per cent ownership of Aussat and allowed Telecom to own 25 per cent and have two members on the Board. In fact, the Satellite Communications Act provides:
. . . primary object [of Aussat] is the carrying on of the business, in accordance with sound commercial principles, of providing-
(a) a telecommunications system for Australia by the use of space satellites; and
(b) space satellite facilities for use in telecommunications systems for neighbouring regions.

By placing Telecom directors on the Aussat Board and giving Telecom a 25 per cent holding in Aussat, the Government has placed tremendous restrictions on Aussat's ability to operate. The potential conflict of interest that must be continually faced by those Telecom directors cannot be overstressed. It is no secret that Telecom strenuously opposed the establishment of Aussat, and one can seriously ask whether all the actions which have resulted in Telecom striving to maintain its monopoly have been devised by Telecom itself simply to protect that monopoly.

The other day I asked a question about telecommunications and telephone link-ups to central Australia and the outback. In his reply Senator Evans used the sort of rhetoric with which we have all become very familiar when we get into an argument with Telecom. In fact, does any senator know anyone who has ever won an argument with Telecom? Telecom, very simply, has a monopoly, and it continually wins all arguments. If you say that your telephone bill is wrong, Telecom simply tells you to pay up or it will take away the service.

So we come to the argument of Telecom versus Aussat and that of competing technologies. We also come to the up-to-date technology possessed by Aussat, the use of satellites and the ability to provide communications not only Australia-wide but right throughout the important Pacific region. We then see Telecom's response to that technology. Telecom was not content with owning 25 per cent of Aussat, and it was not even content to set up its own arm to sell earth stations to compete with Aussat. Instead, to compete with the new satellite technology, Telecom wanted to establish a digital radio concentrator system. One might well ask what that is. Basically, it is a system of lines which every 40 kilometres across Australia has a microwave tower to continue the signal. The cost of such a system is in the vicinity of $400m. Interestingly enough, Australia is the only country in the world to have such a system. Telecom would probably say that it is having discussions with China and that it is hopeful that China might think that this is a good system too. Where on earth is the rhyme or the reason that allows a monopoly such as Telecom to take a decision in an untested manner to set up an alternative system to Aussat's satellite system? Very simply, the answer is if it did not do so it would lose its monopoly.

In the whole argument about telecommunications and the need for us to provide services to the outback of Australia, again and again the flaws in the argument which show up come right back to the point that it is always Telecom's protection of its own monopoly that is the guiding force. Let us take a good example. Let us take the example of the sale of private networks. Under the legislation Aussat is committed to provide private networks. However, Telecom is the regulator that says to whom and with whom they may be set up. All who are engaged in the industry want an independent regulator. They want that function taken away from Telecom.

Let us look a little more at this. Suppose that Aussat goes out into a mining town in outback rural Australia-a town such as the ones about which we are always hearing from people who attempt to oppose privatisation of services on the basis that cost subsidisation can be maintained only with government owned services. Let us try the example of private services provided by Aussat. Such services could also be provided by Telecom. However, in the event that one buys such a service from Aussat one is required to pay an annual interconnect fee of $2,000 per line, which is by way of a social contribution because one will be avoiding subscriber trunk dialling charges. This is so outback communications can be subsidised. In other words, an outback company or system of subscribers will be told that they have to pay a subsidy to subsidise themselves. Where is the logic or the sense in the argument, unless it is very simply to enable Telecom to maintain the monopoly which it regards as so precious? Last year in an article in the Bulletin entitled `Aussat launches a space industry' Laurel Allen wrote:
The threat that satellite technology posed to the established order in Australia was one reason why institutions and their loyal outriders put up a battle to block what became Aussat.

They did not block its formation, but they are certainly blocking its efficient operation. What Aussat needs is the opportunity to compete fairly. I suggest that if one looks at the Telecommunications Act 1975 and reads the duties of the Commission one will realise that Telecom needs to read its Act a little more closely as well. Section 6 of that Act says:
The Commission shall perform-
not may perform but shall perform-
its functions in such a manner as will best meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian people for telecommunications services and shall-
not `may'-
so far as it is, in its opinion, reasonably practicable to do so, make its telecommunication services available throughout Australia for all people who reasonably require those services.
It goes on to say in subsection (2) of that section:
. . . the intention of the Parliament expressed in section 7 of the Satellite Communications Act 1984-
it is so important that it is set out in the Act itself-

namely, the intention that the telecommunications systems provided by the Commission and the telecommunications system provided by the company AUSSAT Pty Ltd (being the company described in the definition of `Aussat' in section 3 of that Act) by the use of space satellites within the meaning of the Act will-
not `may'-
provide the national communications network for Australia.

Therefore, even in the legislation itself we see that there is an intention that Aussat shall provide an important part of our telecommunications system. Yet the unfair restrictions placed on it do not enable it to do just that. As Senator Alston said earlier, recently Aussat has introduced its new Starnet system which provides a private communications network to organisations with a large number of geographically dispersed locations requiring links to a central point. It is a viable alternative to dedicated closed data and telephone networks currently used by Telecom. Indeed, again it threatens the Telecom monopoly. Let us see how that will fare.

If we are also going to examine in a fair way the effects that overrestrictions and regulations have on the business of Aussat let us look at the following curious pattern of restriction. Aussat competes with Telecom in the provision of private network services, which I have already outlined. Private networks such as Q-Net have diverted some revenue from Telecom to Aussat. Telecom has lost revenue to Aussat because its carriage of broadcasting services which were previously used by Telecom's network has now been dispensed with. We are now familiar with the use by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation of Aussat including for School of the Air and the use by the Department of Aviation of VHF phones out of aeroplanes with the result that they no longer have to fly to set patterns, which saves costs on avgas. Aussat is used by all commercial television and some commercial radio networks. It is used for video conferencing and voice and data links. A myriad of other uses can fairly be said to be on the horizon.

The question is whether the attitude of this Government to allow restrictions on Aussat's operations means that it will have to be, I think the term is, `gobbled up' by its major competitor. The interests of the Australian people are served by deregulation in this area. They are served by Aussat being able to trade fairly and not being inhibited by the monopolistic practices and the clear strategy which Telecom, backed by up by this Government, is presently embarked upon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Gareth Evans, oppose this matter of public importance brought on by Senator Alston. I must say that I could not think of a more inconsequential matter of public importance to be proposed today in view of the fact that in the last four or five days the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia in coalition have made such a mess of their own communications policy. I would have thought that any aspect of communications would be the last matter which the coalition would want to expose to any discussion. (Quorum formed) I thank Senator Puplick for drawing attention to the discomfiture of the Liberal Party about its present communications policy. It has been quite a remarkable effort in the last four or five days. Various spokespeople from the Liberal Party have said that they support 25 per cent, 60 per cent and 75 per cent for the audience reach in commercial television. We now have Senator Messner saying that he opposed going from 60 per cent to 75 per cent because he supported 100 per cent. It really is a remarkable effort. After all this confusion in the last few days, the leadership of the Liberal Party is in tatters, and four State leaders of the Liberal Party are disagreeing with the shadow Cabinet's position. I understand that today in the Party room the Liberal Party decided to adjourn the discussion and to try to work out some further policy that might be acceptable to all the conflicting views within the Party over the communications policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have it: A debate has been instigated condemning the Government for its attitude towards the funding and operation of Aussat. I suppose that this topic was chosen because it is the only thing that all members of the Liberal Party can agree on. It is the lowest common denominator-attack the Australian Labor Party and the Labor Government over its policy on Aussat. Having heard Senator Bishop's speech about Aussat's history one should remember how Aussat started. It started in the late 1970s when Kerry Packer, then a media baron in Australia owning a number of television stations, decided that one way to improve his company's profitability would be to get hold of satellite communications. He convinced the Liberal Party in government that it would be a good idea. The hares were set running about establishing a satellite communications system. Quite rightly, many people in the community were not too enamoured of the idea that a person such as Kerry Packer, or anybody in a substantial media ownership position, would then control a satellite communications system. Fortunately, in March 1983 the Australian people elected a Labor Government which, within a year of its election, ensured that Aussat-as it was being called-would be retained in public ownership rather than being allowed to be owned by private or vested interests. I think that before Senator Bishop and Senator Alston get too carried away with criticising the Government over Aussat policy, they should have a good look at the record of how this country came to have a satellite communications policy. It started off with the Liberals' ham-fisted attitude in responding to the pressure from Kerry Packer.

Why has Senator Alston raised the need for Aussat and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) to be privatised and sold off? In response to an interjection of mine, he refused to commit himself about the future of Telecom Australia but he made it clear that Aussat, OTC and Telecom should all be deregulated. Why would one want to deregulate Aussat? Why would one want it to be able to move into areas to compete against Telecom? Because the Liberal Party wants to get into the profitable areas. It would then ultimately leave Telecom and even OTC with the least profitable areas and the taxpayer would have to pick them up. It would then use the argument, `Well, they're not running at a profit. We may as well sell them off'. So we would end up with a totally privatised telecommunications system in Australia.

It may suit the ideologues in the Liberal Party, such as Senator Alston, to promote that cause but when one looks at what has happened in the United Kingdom and the United States of America-in the United States the private company, ATT, which had a government-controlled overview of its monopoly, was broken up into several private companies and in the UK the telecommunications system was privatised-one finds that there have been endless complaints from the consuming public. Why? Because the prices have gone up and services have been cut back, particularly in those areas which are not profitable.

I find it really remarkable that Senator Alston, from the Victorian Liberal Party, which claims and wants to represent a number of rural electorates, which has many political dog fights with the National Party in trying to win State and Federal seats in that area and which claims that it knows what is best for the rural areas, would openly proclaim a system whereby rural people-the people in regional Australia-would end up paying more. If they do not pay more, a direct subsidy will be required from the Australian taxpayer. Those are the very people in the Liberal Party who call themselves `dries' and who want to cut government expenditure anyway. I do not accept the fact that, as Senator Alston proposes, one can get away with privatising and selling off the profitable areas to the private sector and having the taxpayer pick up the cost for the private area.

In December of last year Senator Alston put this issue on the record-and I suppose in a sense he should be congratulated-in a speech in the Senate which was reported in a number of newspapers around Australia on 7 December 1987. One of these newspapers stated:
An Opposition backbencher called yesterday for an end to cross-subsidisation of uneconomic services such as remote-area mail delivery and country telephone services.
It went on to say:
Subsidies were only made possible by Telecom's indefensible monopoly in many areas and this was damaging Australia's international competitiveness.

`If the Government needs to continue providing discount services, all beneficiaries should be means-tested and funded either by a direct government grant to Telecom or by an explicit levy on all other users of Telecom's services,' he said.

Senator Alston made it pretty clear what he was after. I only hope that he does not worry or complain too much during the next Federal election campaign when we in the Labor Party go around Australia-including regional and rural Australia-belling the cat on the Liberal Party that it wants people in the non-metropolitan areas to pay more for telecommunications services and, if they do not pay more, it wants the general Australian taxpayer to pick up the difference. I believe that that will be an issue that the Liberal Party will wish it had not raised for the next election.

The Labor Party policy on telecommunications has to be supported by the general community because it is in the best interests of the community. We want a telecommunications system which is well planned, well balanced and efficient. We will not get that by allowing the various segments of the telecommunications system to be privatised and to compete against each other, because they will compete only for the profitable areas, particularly for the services provided in Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra and Brisbane and in the other major capital cities. They will not compete in the non-profitable areas-and that includes Aussat. If Aussat is used to destroy a balanced telecommunications system when it is privatised, the Australian community will be the loser.

In any discussion on telecommunications policy the basic assumption must be that there is a balanced system where the community is served first, no matter where it is. We will not have an efficient economy in Australia if we have an inefficient telecommunications system and it will be inefficient if rip-roaring competitiveness is allowed to take place only in those areas which are profitable. We will not have a profitable farming sector if we have an inefficient telecommunications system serving it, and we will have an inefficient telecommunications system if we allow privatisation to occur and Aussat to be used as a device to destroy the well balanced telecommunications system in Australia.

This matter of public importance introduced by Senator Alston should be rejected by the Senate. It will be overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian people because they can see a fraud being foisted upon them. They can see that they will have to pay more for a system that will be inefficient and will not serve their needs. I look forward to future debate in the Senate when wider issues about telecommunications policy and the public good are discussed. The Australian Labor Party in government will put the case to the Australian people that we have an efficient and effective telecommunications system based on the needs of the Australian people and not on the needs of a few capitalists who wish to rip off the system for their own profitable gain. I again welcome the opportunity to speak against this inane matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), I seek leave to make a statement relating to international trade and to move a motion that the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The news has recently been filled with the emergence of conflicts in our international trade relationships, particularly over the future of our coal and beef exports to North Asia.

Honourable senators have heard of the very significant efforts this Government is making to deal with those problems and to ensure that Australia's key primary commodity industries receive fair treatment in world markets.

Every opportunity has been taken to drive home to our trading partners the message that Australia expects non-discriminatory treatment for its competitively priced exports, not just because it is in our interest to get a fair deal, but also because it is in their own interests to make one.
International trade is a business where both sides, producers and consumers, have to come out ahead or, in the end, no one will.
Making deals that narrowly favour one side will lead to smaller trade gains, reduced investment and lost export sales on both sides of a trading relationship.

The pressures for these discriminatory trade deals arise in large measure from the persistent international trade imbalances which plague the relationships between the world's major trading countries. These imbalances while overshadowing the international economic environment have thrown into sharp relief the cracks and imperfections in the international trading system itself.

Such cracks can be seen in the inadequate GATT rules for agriculture, the unsatisfactory GATT dispute settlement record, the tendency of the majors to operate outside the GATT provisions relating to the use of temporary trade protection, the lack of direction in the GATT institution itself and its inability to guarantee fair trade in the fast growing services trades.
All of these have become areas of intense discussion in the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations which is now some 20 months old.

It is timely therefore, I believe, for me to step back a little from the issues occupying the headlines today and to review for Parliament the progress that has been made in the Uruguay Round. In particular I wish to give senators a sense of where I think the negotiations are headed and of the prospects for some agreements on some of these issues by the mid-point of the negotiations late this year. In doing so I will outline for members the results of the Cairns Group ministerial meeting in Bariloche in February and the informal meeting of world trade Ministers at Lake Constance in March this year.

Progress in the Uruguay Round remains an essential ingredient for sustained world trade and economic growth. While the results for growth in 1987 were sound, if not spectacular, expectations for 1988 are more modest. Large current account imbalances remain in the major developed countries, contributing to uncertainty and to pressure for protectionist action. In this environment, trade reform as a means of increasing stability has top priority.

The House should not need to be reminded how important overseas trade is to our own economic health. Around 14 per cent of our GDP in 1987 was exported: for some products in our agricultural sector three-quarters or more of our output is sold overseas; the same is true for minerals and energy products; and as a result of the Government's policies we have seen gratifying growth in the export performance of the manufacturing and services sectors.
Australia's trading prospects are clearly constrained by the present uncertainties, not least because the pace of necessary reform by the major traders-the US, the EC and Japan-is so slow.

Over the last year or so, we have had to contemplate the possibility of a major increase in United States protectionist legislation, as the Congress discussed options for a new trade Bill. Some of the proposed statutes directly threatened Australia's interests and they and others had the potential to create enormous disruption in the world trading system.

Australia has mounted a major effort to ensure US legislators were made aware of our concerns. I pay tribute to the work done by ministerial colleagues and parliamentarians, and in particular to the efforts of the all-party delegation led by Mr Barry Cunningham. Included in that delegation from the major parties were the Hon. Wal Fife from the Liberal Party and the Hon. Ralph Hunt from the National Party. I pay tribute also to the work done by Australian industry associations, in particular the National Farmers Federation and the AMLC, and by the Australian Embassy in Washington. As I indicated in my Press conference on 11 April 1988 we have welcomed the emergence of a more responsible Bill than existed in earlier versions.

Although there remain elements of the current draft Bill which are of concern to Australia, it is pleasing that proposals which would have been most harmful to our trade in sugar and lamb have been dropped, and that improvements have been made in other areas of interest to Australia.

We can also take some comfort that protectionist options are not as prominent now as they were in the earlier stages of the US presidential campaigns. There remains the danger however that the massive trade imbalances to which I referred earlier could lead to bilateral accommodations between the US and Japan, which could severely damage the world trading system.

A similar danger exists in the trade conflicts between the US and the EC, especially in agricultural products, where the fallout of their subsidy war continues to adversely affect efficient exporters like Australia. I know the good news is that world commodity prices have improved of late: but that must not reduce the pressure for agricultural trade reform. The structural deficiencies which led to the crises of 1985 and 1986 remain, thus ensuring that the periodic crises that have plagued agricultural markets will recur, even if commodity prices have, for now, risen above the despairing limits of recent years. The recovery should be regarded as a breathing space to take action rather than a turning point.

The Uruguay Round provides perhaps the only opportunity open to the international community to strengthen and secure the framework for multilateral trade, and thereby to deal decisively with a number of current uncertainties.

Past such rounds could point to specific achievements in trade liberalisation. for example, in the Tokyo Round tariffs negotiations led average tariffs on manufactured products in industrial countries to fall from 7 per cent to below 5 per cent. Codes were negotiated which were successful in regulating the use of non-tariff measures, at least in some circumstances.

But the Tokyo Round did not deal adequately with the agriculture sector, and did not address the area of trade in services at all. Countries found ways of using non-tariff measures which were outside the ambit of the codes, and some of the codes themselves-especially the one on the use of subsidies-proved deficient.

The Uruguay Round was launched in 1986 with the clear intention to deal with all these issues. The launching declaration speaks about the reduction or elimination of tariffs and non-tariff measures, and has as one objective the improvement of GATT disciplines relating to all subsidies and countervailing measures that affect international trade.

You will be familiar with the successful efforts by Australia and its colleagues in the Cairns Group to ensure that the mandate given for negotiations on agriculture addressed the real problems underlying the crisis we faced at that time. And for the first time, the GATT is looking at the kind of rules which might be applied to bring trade in the fast-growing services sector under international disciplines. The declaration acknowledges also the special need to secure trade liberalisation and expansion which will benefit less-developed countries, with an eye also to the particular problems of the least developed countries.

Australia attaches great importance to the Uruguay Round. We of course continue our efforts to secure improved bilateral trading opportunities and relationships, but even there our best prospects for success arise in an open and predictable multilateral trading environment. We have therefore taken a most active role across a broad spectrum of negotiating issues.

This represents a major long term effort. The Uruguay Round is a four-year undertaking due to conclude in 1990, so 1988 is the second year of actual negotiations. Participating countries have agreed however that a mid-term review at ministerial level should be held in Montreal in December this year. This is a welcome development. It gives negotiations an early focus, so they will not drift towards 1990. It also provides the opportunity to achieve early agreements in a number of areas where good progress has been made. If this is done, it will not only make available benefits which would otherwise not appear until 1990, but give a boost to confidence in the capacity of the GATT to take the world trading system into the next century.
The first year of negotiations in the Uruguay Round saw good progress.

The technical and information base for negotiations was consolidated, specific negotiating proposals were tabled on a wide range of subjects, and a smooth procedural transition was made to the substantive negotiating phase which began in January this year.

In terms of the breadth of our interests and the initiatives we have taken, Australia has been the most active player in the negotiations to date. In addition to our leadership of the Cairns Group, we have advanced proposals in negotiations on services, tariffs and non-tariff measures, natural resource based products (where we are making a particular attack on subsidies and other measures which distort trade in coal), dispute settlement procedures, emergency protection measures (commonly called safeguards), and arrangements to improve the functioning of the GATT system. It has been made abundantly clear that Australia is not a single issue country but has trading interests across the board.

Despite the promising start to the Round, we must recognise the hard bargaining has yet to begin. The pace of negotiations this year will depend in large part on the attitude of the major trading powers, some of which have important domestic political preoccupations: for example, the elections in France and the United States. It is essential that the pressure be kept on the majors to ensure that what could be achieved by December 1988 will not be put off until 1990.

I attended the recent meeting hosted by the FRG at Lake Constance which provided an opportunity for informal discussions amongst trade Ministers from a broadly representative group of developed and developing countries, including the trade majors. At the meeting, we reviewed progress in the Round and discussed prospects for agreements being reached in some areas at the mid-term review.

Discussion suggested that there are prospects for early results in the so-called framework areas of the negotiations. These are dispute settlement, institutionalised monitoring and/or surveillance of trade policies, and provisions for greater ministerial involvement in oversighting the work of the GATT.

This is encouraging, in that it at least signifies that countries want the GATT to stay, and to work better. They may not yet have applied this insight to their domestic policy-making as rigorously as we would wish, but it is an important step forward nevertheless.

Tropical products were identified as a priority area for negotiations in the Punta Del Este declaration, with specific reference made to achieving early agreements. Developing country exporters of these products are anxious to see early results in this area, which will represent an important test of the major players' commitment to the Round. Australia also has significant trading interests in tropical products, and we are advancing our own ideas for trade liberalisation in this area which call for extensive improvements in access to all markets.

I was most disappointed to note at Lake Constance the strong disinclination of the EC and the US to give any ground at this stage in their negotiating positions on agriculture. The EC has placed emphasis in its proposal on the need for short term actions to underpin improvements in commodity markets, but has been vague on the extent to which it would be prepared to see agricultural supports dismantled over the longer term.

Moreover, the Community is currently basking in self-acclaim following the February European Council which set new limits and disciplines on agricultural expenditure. While a significant agreement for the Community, it represents no more than a small step along the path of agricultural trade reform which we wish to secure in the Uruguay Round. Even modest domestic reforms need to be locked in through international commitments to ensure that they are not lost.

The U.S. has tabled a most ambitious negotiating proposal which envisages the phased elimination of all agricultural subsidies and trade barriers by the year 2000. Regrettably, it makes no provision at this stage for early relief measures and U.S. negotiators maintain that if agreement cannot be reached on satisfactory objectives for the longer term, we can expect `more of the same' in world agricultural trade. This would mean continued aggressive export subsidisation by the US, and formulation of a tough Farm Bill to replace that which expires in 1989.

Japan has tabled an agricultural proposal which has only limited appeal. While it supports the phased elimination of export subsidies (which Japan does not apply) it offers a minimal prospect of trade liberalisation and advances `food security' arguments in defence of supporting highly inefficient domestic production.

It is against this background that the Cairns Group, at the meeting which I chaired in Bariloche, Argentina in late February, established a work program and strategy relating to objectives which members wish to see achieved at the mid-term review in December. It was significant that the meeting was held in a developing country, because a number of Cairns Group members are developing countries. They recognise the importance of agricultural trade reform to the achievement of their national ambitions, and Australia has valued their participation. The Group believes that the time has come to narrow the gap between rhetoric and practice in the positions of the majors on international agricultural reform. Its members will be working to achieve commitments from the mid-term review covering both the long term framework, and immediate implementation of substantive interim results.

In this regard, the Group has decided to press for results in the mid-term review encompassing a freeze followed by a reduction in global support for agriculture in 1989-90. As a down payment towards longer term agricultural reform, this would include reductions in production and export subsidies and increases in market access opportunities.

Members of the Cairns Group will be pressing their views on the `early action' concept at every opportunity, including meetings of the agricultural negotiating group in Geneva, and at high level political gatherings such as the May OECD Ministerial Council and the Toronto Economic Summit in June.

Given the widely divergent positions of the majors, it is clear that the Cairns Group has a vital role to play in the negotiations. It is clear also from our meeting in Bariloche and the further opportunity which a number of Cairns Group Ministers had to meet informally in the margins of the Lake Constance meeting, that there is a strong current of cohesion and unity of purpose within the Group. Cairns Group Ministers envisage holding a meeting in Hungary towards the end of the year to co-ordinate our approach to the mid-term review of the GATT negotiations.

While I am not in a position at this stage to suggest grounds for optimism that a process of fundamental international agricultural reform will be agreed to as early as December 1988, I can indicate that the Cairns Group is determined to continue with its active role.

If early agreements are not reached in this area, it will more likely be as a result of the failure of the majors to display the political resolve and political flexibility needed to establish the basis for meaningful compromise.

There are some grounds for optimism in the new areas of the negotiations, particularly on services. Despite the complexity of this area, broad principles have been identified as appropriate for a framework agreement, and there is a reasonable prospect that the core principles of a future agreement could be settled by the end of 1988.

In other areas, widely divergent views remain, and the difficult negotiations may continue to the end of the Round. We are hopeful that agreement on the methods by which countries are to go about reducing their tariffs and non-tariff measures will not be delayed that long, and these particular negotiations are showing hopeful signs. Greater difficulty is evident in achieving progress on natural resource-based products, where there is resistance to focusing on distortions in trade especially in energy products and ferrous metals. Australia has been actively exploring the interests we share with a number of developing countries, to which this sector is also important.

Another very difficult area is the safeguards negotiations: the achievement of an effective set of disciplines for the use of emergency protective measures. Because of deficiencies in the present rules, countries have turned to the `grey area measures': voluntary export restraints and other practices which are contrary to the spirit of and threaten the future role of the GATT. It is not likely that early agreement will be achieved here, but Australia has co-sponsored with a number of Pacific countries a proposal for a comprehensive safeguards agreement.

Those are the broad outlines of progress in the trade negotiations to this point. The Uruguay Round is an enormous enterprise which is seeking to throw light on some of the fundamental problems of the world economy. It requires intense preparation and negotiation, increasingly between Ministers themselves as the discussions begin to touch on the most sensitive areas of policy. Already, plans have been made for another informal meeting of Ministers in Pakistan next October to attempt to bring different points of view closer together before the December mid-term review meeting.

Throughout the negotiations to date, Australia has sought to take an active and constructive role. We have worked to maximise our influence wherever possible through co-operation with like-minded countries. We have worked within our traditional alliances and outside them, and have sought and found shared interests among both developed and developing countries.

The Government recognises that a sustained and carefully focused effort will be needed to achieve tangible benefits for Australia in the mid term review. Indeed, this effort must and will be maintained throughout the Round. We can nevertheless welcome the achievements so far made and capitalise wherever possible on the potential for progress which has been created in a number of areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the statement by the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) on the status of the multilateral trade negotiations (MTN) talks. It is certainly the case that the welfare of all Australians is closely linked to our capacity to produce, provide and manufacture commodities, services and products which are competitive, attractive and capable of gaining access to overseas markets. My party is currently reviewing its trade policies. We are committed to promoting external trade and commercial policies which will foster the best possible conditions, both domestic and international, to enable Australian industries to expand and develop.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that any trade policy review serves a useful purpose to sensitise participants to the need to ensure that policies provide the resources, imagination and governmental structure to help ensure that this country is capable of earning its way in a global economy. Having noted this, it is with particular interest that I read the Minister's statement on the Government's vision for Australia and its strategy for ensuring that Australia stays afloat in an international trading environment characterised by beggar thy neighbour policies, particularly among the Western nations, the gradual breakdown of important international trade institutions such as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and a decline, unfortunately, in the consensus among Western states on the need and the means of achieving trading reforms.

A very good example of this breakdown is the domestic consensus on the desirability of a liberal trading regime in the United States of America. In the early 1970s that country began to run trade deficits in a number of politically sensitive industrial areas, starting with textiles in the early 1970s, steel and motor vehicles in the mid to late 1970s and machine tools and semi-conductor chips in the early 1980s. The large current account deficit and the political and electoral pressures that this is applying on a legislative branch increasingly unable to deal with or handle complex trading issues has undermined the capacity of that country to play a major leadership role in world trade. Certainly, it is no longer capable of playing the type of role it did until the early 1970s.

Unfortunately, there still does not appear to be an appreciation within the United States Government of the macro-economic effects that the $160 billion budget deficit is going to have on the trade balance. Hence, there is a situation where Congress is resorting to micro-economic reforms through attempts at tariffs and quota barriers. The political significance of the trade deficit is that while America's healthy trade performance during the 1950s and 1960s served to reinforce the liberal trading regime, the present trading deficit serves as a symbol to the American public that liberal trading regimes are bad for America.

A closely related and equally worrying development in international trade is the build-up in the Third World debt and the effect that this is having on the stability of global financial markets. There is, of course, the associated and very depressing effect which high debt levels are having on the living standards of developing countries and, in turn, the pressure that this is exerting on those countries' democratic institutions.

In the context of these remarks, the MTN talks are absolutely vital. The Democrats wish the Government and the Minister well in their endeavours to obtain a fairer deal for Australia. It is without doubt that Australia as a trading nation has not had a fair deal. That is easily demonstrable, and in fact has been demonstrated by a number of very important documents-for example, the paper which deals with European Community trading operations and the soon to be released paper in respect of United States trading policies and the effect that those policies have had on our country. Only last week I spent some considerable time commenting on the latest problem we have had with regard to malt sales to Peru. A $8m market which has been developed and supplied by Australians is now to be the target of the American export enhancement program (EEP). The difficulty, of course, with the export enhancement program is that the Americans say that it is being aimed at the European Community. Their aim may well be the European Community, but the people who are getting shot are the Australian producers.

Probably very few Australians know much about our trading relationships with countries such as Peru. But our trade in a number of items to these countries has been innovative, effective and, more than anything else, efficient. The way in which the international trading regime is currently being conducted really sticks in the craw of Australians, bearing in mind the efficiency of our trading operations. Half of the total income of United States farmers comes from consolidated revenue. The Russian Ambassador was quite staggered when I raised this point with him recently. He said, `We do not do anything like that in the Soviet Union'. The United States is probably the best example of a socialised agricultural economy anywhere in the world outside of Queensland. It is also a rather interesting fact that the Soviet Union is now the fourth largest recipient of United States aid on the basis of cheap wheat and other commodities that the United States sells to that country under various support programs.

On any comparable figures, Australian agricultural producers are twice as efficient, if not three times as efficient-I think that they are three times more efficient, but on the available figures the Americans will accept that we are twice as efficient-as those in the United States. When one suffers under such circumstances and sees the United States, for internal political purposes, going into more of our markets, one cannot be other than extremely angry at the fact that efficient Australian producers are being forced out of the international market, not by efficient American producers but by the massive size of the US Treasury.

International trade is of vital importance to Australia. With international protectionism on the increase, the Minister has chaired a number of meetings around the world. The previous Minister was responsible for the creation of the Cairns Group-a group that has been very effective in the international trading arena in putting the point of view of a number of countries such as Australia. Australia is not the only country involved. For example, Thailand has had a massive attack on its economy by the United States, again because the United States has targeted basic agricultural products that the Thais produce very efficiently.

What has gone on to date is pretty tame stuff. When one looks at this paper, one considers that it is probably even tamer stuff. We are not told of the Government's strategy; that is completely missing. There is no vision of where the Government is going, let alone a detailed point by point plan. Nor, interestingly enough, does the document say anything about proposals in the United States to increase funding for the export enhancement program to $2.5 billion. According to the former Trade Minister, in 1986 EEP alone cost Australia $1 billion in lost income. It is very odd that in a paper canvassing these trading relations there is no mention of EEP nor of the tortuous route that the current omnibus Trade Bill is taking through the US Congress. As honourable senators realise, the Bill has passed through the United States House of Representatives and currently is on the floor of the Senate. There is some discussion as to whether the President will veto the omnibus Trade Bill. If he does that it is unlikely, given all its myriad attachments, that another Trade Bill will be brought before the current Congress. So the action of President Reagan in either vetoing the Bill or sustaining his veto to it is unlikely to go very far. I think that we are in for an even worse scenario in the short period ahead.

Recently a comment was made by a representative of the US Embassy regarding malt-some newspaper reports also mentioned wheat-suggesting that Australia is selling more on the world market since the introduction of EEP. The difficulty with that whole silly exercise-unfortunately, it was swallowed by many people in our media who ought to have known better-is that, while we sold more grain over that period, we produced more grain. Of course, in the last couple of years total grain production has gone back. This is probably the only country in the world in which that has occurred. As a result, we have been getting much less for it. We started off by getting a world price of $140 a tonne. The price went down to $120, $100 and $93 or $94. The silly comment, `You can sell as much as you like provided you sell it at a rock bottom price', which, unfortunately, was not picked up by our journalists who ought to have known better, is the type of thing we get from embassies which, after all, are only doing their job.

It was interesting to note that when the last all-party trade delegation, which I had the opportunity to be among, went to the United States and lobbied members of the House of Representatives and the Senate, it was fairly clear that, to start off with, they knew very little about Australia and about our trading relations. The fact that we have been in deficit to the US in our trading relations since 1954 seemed to come as a complete shock to them. The fact that we are the second largest cash purchaser in the world of military equipment from the US-most of the others trundle round with their hand held out and do not pay a brass razoo, while we pay money up-front, on the knocker-has not deterred this so-called ally of ours from engaging in some of the most predatory trading operations that this country has ever had to endure. It is not good enough to have this type of ministerial statement trotted out to us. It is a bland rehearsal of what is going on. We are in trouble. Our producers are in trouble. We need a firm and strong stance.

While many people in the Government feel that we should back off from taking a strong stance with the United States, I am of a completely different view. It came across very strongly to me in that trade delegation that one of the things US Congressmen like is a bit of straight talking. When we closed the doors and excluded staff, we got down to some plain talking. Rather than the mealy-mouthed exercises which often go on under the name of diplomacy, they relished that. That is one of the useful things that came out of a visit by politicians. At least we were able to get down to some of the nitty-gritty operations affecting the relationships between our two countries. I see no reason to kowtow to the United States while it engages in a most extraordinary operation against our trade.

What types of things should one look at? I wish to repeat nine points raised in a program that I put out last week because they go to the heart of the problem we face currently. The first, which I have already rehearsed, is the establishment of a broad Australian attack on US agricultural policies. This program should be aimed at developing a coalition of foreign and American domestic interest groups to fight the high cost and trade friction associated with EEP. Those groups would include, for example, the firm that we have just spent over $1 billion with, buying steering and other types of equipment for our submarine purchases. Such firms have a very real interest in whether Australia has the cash to purchase anything from the United States. I for one believe that our trading relationships with other countries would be enhanced enormously if we started sourcing a large number of our materials from countries which have purchased from us. We could get our trade balance with those countries back into some reasonable shape instead of continuing with a trade deficit exercise with the United States for which we are thanked not at all.

I think that there needs to be a convening by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) of our Australian consular and embassy officials, based in Australia and the US, to review the situation regarding representations in the United States. We need to harness US defence contractors, such as McDonnell Douglas and Sikorsky, which have access to Congress, so that those massive cash purchases about which I spoke earlier can be brought to bear and used in our trading exercises. We should establish an Australian-United States business round table, patterned on the very successful Australia- Japan model, that would report directly to the American President and the Australian Prime Minister on ways to improve understanding between our two countries and to reduce the trade conflict. I think prominent Australians and Americans-a person whose name comes to mind is Rupert Murdoch, who presumably still has an affinity for this country, having once been an Australian citizen-are the kinds of people who could serve on such a body which would seek to widen Australia's approach to trade and commercial issues beyond the political and diplomatic levels.

Fifthly, I think the data and arguments from the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, particularly from the item which I raised a little while ago, the soon to be published Blue Book on American agriculture, could then be used to demonstrate to urban based American Congressmen that their projects are being massively squeezed by cuts to Federal spending because of the inefficiencies of the US farm programs. Those inefficiencies are accepted by Americans and Australians alike. It is not something one has to argue; they know they are massively inefficient. I hope that the Blue Book will be able to have the same useful effect for both parliamentarians, when they visit that country, and for our embassies, as the 1985 Red Book on European agricultural policy had.

The aim here is unashamedly to drive a wedge between the urban and rural interests within the Congress, so that there is greater scrutiny within the budgetary process of the massive and open-ended expenditures of some $30 billion, $40 billion or possibly $50 billion-nobody seems to know-on that agricultural support.

Sixthly, Ministers should be more assertive in selling their message to the United States. I believe that Ministers whose responsibility covers trade should testify before the relevant congressional committees when our interests are threatened. It is no good their coming along afterwards. We should be in there, up front, at the beginning. After all, if it is good enough for George Shultz to sell his message on Capital Hill, surely it is good enough for our Prime Minister or our Trade Minister to do so on such a vital issue. I believe Bill Hayden ought to appear before the Congress, as should Minister Duffy. I think that would be a very up-front way for us to make the point that Australia is suffering, and suffering badly, from the predatory policies of the United States.

Seventhly, I think the Australian commodities undermined by EEP should be used in counter trade deals between the Australian Government, where Canberra is the buyer, and American firms, so that we can protect our foreign exchange earnings and sensitise American businesses to the costs of EEP. I admit that counter trade has its problems, but I believe that in this circumstance counter trade is one of the exercises we ought to engage in. If we are going to purchase that massive one billion dollars worth of defence equipment, that seller simply has to find a billion dollars of Australian goods to purchase to offset it. What he does with those goods afterwards is his business. Let him try to sell them on a market that has been glutted by the extraordinary trading policies of the United States. It has certainly become very sensitive to the exercise of the disruption of international trade that the United States and the European Community are engaging in. I think it is that type of tough policy that we should be starting to follow when we talk to the United States.

Eighthly, Despite two recent parliamentary delegations to the US, of which I was a member, which brought greater contact between the American and Australian politicians, little has been done. I think the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should use his forthcoming visit to Washington in June to establish a formal parliamentary congressional exchange program involving legislatures and staff on both sides of the Pacific. Over time I think this would create a pool of expertise on each other's political system, which could then be used to good effect to reduce misunderstandings between our countries and certainly to help Australians tap more efficiently into the American political process-knowledge coming before action. I believe there are many capable members of staff in the offices of Ministers, shadow Ministers, party leaders and backbenchers who could well benefit from a sensitisation operation with regard to the United States, and likewise there are many good staffers who would have the same effect if they came here and looked at our legislative process. Having them in the system, I think, is a vital and important item. It is one which I believe we have neglected in the past and which we ought now to take up with a vengeance if we are going to try to get inside the citadel.

Lastly, I think we should be reviewing the staff, resources and strategy of the Congressional Liaison Unit within the Washington embassy. That unit at the moment consists of one Australian who has the task of liaising with over 70 congressional committees, departments and agencies. In fact the number of people there who could possibly have any effect on any of those types of trading policies could be over 1,000. We have one person engaged in that exercise. How important is our trade to this country? Everybody says that it is vitally important, but I think the proof of the pudding has to be in the eating. When one looks at that type of exercise, particularly in the United States, one cannot but be dismayed.

The last point I wish to make is that we are in a trade surplus situation with a number of countries, and one of those is China. We have currently a massive trade surplus with China. The Chinese economy is expanding rapidly. It is the market of the future and it is a very important market for us. But the Chinese have everybody knocking on their door. At the moment Australia's standing with China could not be higher. The Chinese are very open to Australia, and Australia has been very helpful in terms of a number of items. For example, there was the inspired educational exercise of sending English teachers over there to teach their English teachers the latest techniques in English. Since about 98 per cent of foreign language learning in China at the moment is in English, we are in exactly the right spot. It is a brilliant idea and the Government is to be congratulated on following it through with such vigour.

But having established ourselves in China and having created a very warm climate between our two countries over a reasonable time, now that China has come through the Cultural Revolution stage and is expanding its economy, we have to be seen to be trading on reasonably fair terms, and we are not. We have got to purchase more from China. How can we do that with our current trade imbalance? Will we have to cut back on purchases from other countries? I would like to nominate one: the United States. The reason for choosing the United States is that that country has done so little for us and has had such little regard for us, and in fact it cannot be seen as an area in which we would have much of a future, and it is now, within the next 12 months, about to kill off our entire sales of sugar into that country. In fact, we were the largest exporter of sugar to that market a little over five years ago. That is the type of turnaround we have had within a short time.

I believe that if we are talking about allies, they cannot be the countries which are undermining our economy. We cannot call a country which is systematically undermining our economy an ally. I believe we should look to the future and look intensely at those countries which have shown that they are willing to buy from us and in great quantities and we should start sourcing our purchases within those countries to bring those bilateral trade relations back into some balance. I think then the United States might come to the talking table. I think we can still do a lot of trading together, but we cannot do it under these insufferable circumstances that we are subjected to at the moment. I think it is a pity that in a statement of this kind we should have more blancmange. We need a bit more tough talking in this exercise. I think the Americans appreciate us when we get down to brass tacks. I think it is about time we did that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

As Senator Macklin has indicated, the statement by the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) was couched in very diplomatic language. I must admit that Senator Macklin's speech was of such a wide-ranging nature that I had to have another look at the statement to see whether we were both responding to the same statement. The Minister points out that the problems that Senator Macklin initially referred to have become areas of intense discussion in the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) negotiations which are now some 20 months old. The Minister goes on to explain the reasons for his statement. He says:
It is timely therefore, I believe, for me to step back a little from the issues occupying the headlines today and to review for Parliament the progress that has been made in the Uruguay Round.

So the purpose of the statement is to step back and review what progress has been made, whereas towards the end of Senator Macklin's speech we ultimately found out what he was on about. Clearly he has had prepared for some time a speech which attacks the United States of America. This was the vehicle he used for it today. The coalition parties welcome the tabling of the report of progress, although some of the Government's claims that its policies are responsible for the gratifying growth are questionable. What is beyond question is that within the Cairns Group of nations there are principles and objectives which are endorsed by the coalition parties. We are concerned about-and I list them-trade imbalances, discriminatory treatment against competitively priced exports, the build-up of protection in the developed world and the financial consequences of major nations operating outside the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

There is no doubt that Australia is seriously disadvantaged by non-tariff barriers. We have adhered to the principles of GATT but in the jungle of international trade, many nations and significant trading partners of Australia find it necessary to resolve their problems outside GATT. For example, there are the bilateral arrangements between Japan and the United States. The coalition parties support the Cairns Group and the Government's attempts to break down the restrictions in trade-services, manufactured goods and minerals. The coalition parties have reservations as to whether GATT, in its present form, is achieving the purpose for which it was first constituted-and it seems that some changes may have to be made. Certainly, GATT lacks muscle. The sanctions under GATT are limited and Australia is too small a market for reduced levels of protection to make much of a bargaining point. In fact, we lack the muscle to have much impact on the major nations of the world. While we commend the concept of the Uruguay Round, which adds a little muscle, we have to accept that there are fundamental problems for Australian negotiators because of special relations which exist between other countries. Warren Lavorel, who is the US coordinator for multilateral negotiations, said:

If you want to talk about trade problems, GATT can do nothing about the most serious problems of all-trade imbalances between nations. The trade imbalances are a question of macro-economics and have to be solved by the individual governments involved, not GATT.

That is a very interesting observation. The coalition is also concerned about the relationships between GATT, world currencies and investment. The relative value of most of our major exports is sensitive to currency changes and the movement of money worldwide. Countertrade is also sought by Eastern bloc countries which are desperately short of foreign currency. In the communique of the ministerial meeting of the Cairns Group on 20 February 1988, the Minister said:

While encouraged by the thrust of international debate which continues to recognise the need to address agricultural trade problems and to focus on the reform of domestic support policies, Ministers expressed disappointment at the significant and growing gap between rhetoric and practice. They noted that actions to reduce subsidies and increase access by the most trade distorting countries fell well short of what is required for sustained reform. Since their last meeting, Ministers noted that competitive subsidy practices have intensified and reductions in market access opportunities have occurred or are currently threatened for some commodities, including vegetable oils, apples, beef, sheepmeat, grains, flour, dairy products and poultry.

So, in effect, the situation is getting worse, not better. We must look at Australia's overseas indebtedness. It is now in excess of $110 billion and servicing our foreign debt now requires 64c in every dollar of export income. The structural adjustment necessary to address this is a major cause for concern.

Last week the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) said that real benefits from structural adjustment would be better achieved by reducing impediments to competitiveness such as the high cost of coastal shipping, land freight and labour and the costs of regulation and government charges. The benefits of reducing these would be three times that gained by tariff reductions. The CAI went on to warn that if the Government cut tariffs without addressing these issues it would reduce the competitiveness of Australian industry and could force some to close. They are the very things that the coalition parties have been saying to this Government for some considerable time-that it is just not a question of reducing tariffs, although clearly an opportunity exists at present for a cut in tariffs, and I will come to that in due course. We have a very substantial number of impediments to competitiveness and those are various things the Government has to look at. They include coastal shipping, land freight, the costs of regulation, and government charges. We are concerned that the Government is not adjusting those matters quickly enough. Moody's Investor Services has raised doubts about the pace of structural adjustment in the Australian economy. I quote from a report in the Australian Financial Review of 10 March this year:

The pace of adjustment since 1983 has been steady but slow relative to several other OECD countries that have faced similar debt problems . . . A pertinent question is whether this gradualist approach to reform will succeed rapidly enough to prevent external borrowing requirements from reaching unacceptably high levels.
I take the Government back to what I read earlier by Warren Lavorel:
The trade imbalances are a question of macro-economics and have to be solved by the individual governments involved, not GATT.

So it is up to us, and in particular this Government, to advance the restructuring of such matters as I have raised in such a way as to make this country more competitive. In fact, if it had not been for strong commodity prices, the current deficit would have been much worse than the $110m-plus that I mentioned earlier. But I say to the Government that it has perhaps a very short term opportunity, as a result of strong world commodity prices at the moment, to take many actions which will be of assistance to this nation in overcoming this major deficit problem. It is not just a question of trade barriers, currency and investment; it is a matter of improving competitiveness. It is in this area that the actions of the Government are perceived as being inadequate. The very substantial devaluation of the Australian dollar and the current perception in the community have given the Government the opportunity for substantially lower protection assistance.

The comments by Mr Hawke, Mr Keating and Mr Dawkins about across the board cuts, ranging from some 25 per cent a few months ago, around Christmas, to 20 per cent early this year, to 15 per cent a couple of weeks ago and 10 per cent last week, have been very damaging. They have created speculation and deferral of investment plans. Treasurer Keating's comments about the dollar and its value over this weekend will no doubt involve further deferral of investment plans. Apparently, industry has to wait until the May statement before it learns what, if anything, the Government will do in regard to tariff cuts, and we shall have to wait and see what will be the consequences for the dollar.

In summary, therefore, we say that Australia needs trade access, that GATT has a role, albeit a limited one, due to its lack of muscle, that the Government has an important role to play in ensuring that Australia is not shut out of markets, but that the major solution to Australia's trade problems lies not with others but with what Australia does itself to ensure competitive exports.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
