TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the Government's policy of increasing its ownership of office accommodation and thereby reducing rental outlays from high priced central city locations, the Public Works Committee has recommended the construction and fitout of two new Commonwealth office buildings-one in Melbourne on the corner of Spring and Lonsdale Streets at an estimated cost of $118m for construction and $18m for fitout, and the other in Sydney at the Haymarket on the corner of Pitt and Hay Streets at an estimated cost of $143m for construction and $20m for fitout, all at April 1987 prices.

SPEECH.PARA: The new Commonwealth offices in Melbourne will be a 42-storey building consisting of a nine-storey podium, and a 33-storey tower. The building will provide 60,000 square metres net of office space to accommodate some 4,000 staff and include shop-front accommodation for departments with a high level of public contact. The site for the building is portion of a larger Commonwealth owned block bound by Spring, La Trobe, Exhibition and Lonsdale Streets. Other developments proposed for this block are stage two of the Commonwealth offices building and new offices for Telecom Australia. The block is being developed as an integrated whole, even though development is planned in stages. As the block has not been redeveloped since it was acquired by the Commonwealth in 1948, an archaeological investigation was undertaken on the block. The Department of Administrative Services and Telecom each provided $50,000 for the archaeological salvage project on the block. A number of heritage buildings located on the perimeter of the new Commonwealth offices site will be retained and preserved by the Commonwealth. However, none of the heritage buildings form part of the development proposal. The Committee has recommended further consultation between the Department of Administrative Services and the Victorian Ministry for Planning and Environment concerning the future of the heritage buildings.

The design solution for the new Commonwealth offices at the Haymarket, Sydney, has evolved from complex site conditions and planning criteria. The design solution incorporates a 31-storey office tower to the south of the site, a nine-storey wing to the west of the site with a two-storey podium to the north-east. The building will provide 50,000 square metres net of office space to accommodate some 3,000 staff and approximately 1,600 square metres net of retail-commercial space, including shop-front space for the Commonwealth. Three historic buildings and an underground gasholder base will be restored and have been integrated into the development. The building has been designed specifically in harmony with the heritage character of the Haymarket area and the scale of the surrounding streetscape, particularly along Hay and Pitt Streets. The Department of Administrative Services has consulted with the Australian Heritage Commission on heritage issues and will continue to do so as conservation work is documented in detail. The National Trust of Australia and the Heritage Council of New South Wales will also be involved in those consultations to take advantage of their particular expertise.

During the Committee's investigation of the proposal, planning and heritage groups expressed concern about the overshadowing of Belmore Park and Eddy Avenue to the east of the site by the tower development. After examining all the issues, the Committee concluded that the Department of Administrative Services had examined a range of design options and that almost any viable building on the Haymarket site would produce some overshadowing of Belmore Park and Eddy Avenue, irrespective of the design solution. The Public Works Committee is satisfied that the Department of Administrative Services has developed a design that keeps overshadowing to a minimum while providing an economically viable building for the Commonwealth. The proposed office buildings will generate savings on Commonwealth office accommodation rental and lead to an improved overall standard of Commonwealth office accommodation with consequent improvements in operational efficiency and a reduction in operating costs.

HONEY MARKETING BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to reconstitute the Australian Honey Board with revised functions and powers, a changed membership structure, and enhanced accountability to the honey industry which provides the Board's funds through levies and an export charge. The legislative changes required to this end involve also repeal of the Honey Industry Act 1962, which is the Board's present charter, and appropriate amendments to the Honey Levy Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1962 as well as to the Honey Export Charge Act 1973. These amendments are being introduced by separate Bills, so that a legislative package of four Bills is involved.

In seeking to reform the Australian Honey Board, the Government wishes to apply to this body the policy principles which are being progressively applied to all primary industry statutory marketing authorities. These principles were enunciated in January 1986 in a White Paper on the reform of the authorities in question. Their aim is to make these bodies more effective, improve their accountability and enlarge their autonomy while ensuring Ministerial oversight at the strategic level.

In applying this policy to the Australian Honey Board, the Government has taken care to do so in a way appropriate to the circumstances of the honey industry. This industry is of modest size compared with our major rural industries, but it supplies virtually all domestic honey requirements and also exports a substantial part of its annual output. In 1986-87, honey exports contributed $16.6m to Australia's export income.

The proposed changes to the structure and charter of the Honey Board were decided on after a detailed review of the Board's operations since its establishment some 25 years ago under the Honey Industry Act 1962. In the course of this review, extensive discussions took place with honey industry organisations in which the options discussed ranged from abolishing the Board to leaving it unchanged.

The Government has concluded that there is still a role for a statutory marketing authority for the Australian honey industry, but believes that the present structure and charter of the Australian Honey Board are not conducive to fulfilment of that role with optimal results. The Board's current charter is too broad, as evidenced by the fact that some specific powers of the Board have seen little or no use in recent years. Its current membership of 10 is too large for an authority with a small budget, while the fact that Board members are elected or nominated to represent sectional interests limits the range of professional skills available to the Board. Moreover, the Board's operational autonomy is unduly restricted by requirements for ministerial approval in matters of relative detail.

All of these shortcomings have been addressed in the changes proposed by the Bill. Under these changes, the new Board's role will be focused solely on two defined objectives. These are to maximise returns to the honey industry from exports, and to generate a greater demand for Australian honey both in Australia and overseas.

In practical terms, this means that the restructured Board will be required to direct its attention and resources to promotional activity, and to support of the export marketing activities of the industry by assistance to honey exporters and a judicious regulation of their operations to prevent undesirable trading conduct.

In the latter regard, it is the wish of the Government that the Board should keep its export regulatory or control activities to a minimum, allowing exporters as much freedom in their operations as is consistent with the interests of the industry as a whole. To ensure that this policy principle is observed, the Board will be required to review the operation of its export controls annually and to report the outcome of its review to the two principal organisations of the honey industry, namely, the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations (FCAAA) and the Honey Packers Association of Australia (HPAA). These organisations are referred to in the Bill as the `producers' organisation' and the `packers' organisation' respectively, and those terms are also used in this speech for the sake of brevity.

To enable the Board to exercise an appropriate degree of control over exports, the Bill provides that exporters of honey must be licensed by the Board. At present, these exporters must also be licensed, but the Board only recommends the issue of licences, while the power to grant them resides with the Minister or his delegate. Criteria for the granting of licences are specified in the Bill, which also provides for recourse to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal where a person is dissatisfied with a decision of the Board in the matter of licensing.

Export licences will be subject to terms and conditions determined by the Board. In this regard, the Board will retain its present power to set minimum prices below which honey may not be exported. Similarly, it will retain the power to appoint agents in overseas countries and to require all exporters to make their transactions through these agents. It will also be open to the new Board, if it deems necessary, to operate other modes of control such as export permits or time limits on forward contracts entered into by exporters. As already noted, however, the Board will be expected to provide reasons for such controls.

In keeping with the Government's policy for statutory marketing authorities, the Board will be required to prepare a five-year corporate plan and to review it at least once a year. Similarly, it will have to prepare annual operational plans. In both cases, the Board will have to consult with the producers' and packers' organisations in the preparation of these plans. The plans will require the Minister's approval and form the basis of the Board's operations. As a further accountability requirement, the annual reports of the Board will, amongst other things, have to assess the extent to which the Board's corporate and operational plan objectives were met.

The Board will also be formally accountable to the peak industry bodies, namely, the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists Associations and the Honey Packers Association of Australia. The Board's chairperson will be required to report to meetings of these bodies after presentation of the Board's annual report to the Minister.

With regard to the structure of the new Board, it will be made up of eight members, namely, a chairperson and a government member who will both be chosen and appointed by the Minister, and six other members who will be selected and nominated for appointment by a selection committee to be established as specified in the Bill. These six members will be selected for their expertise in a range of fields relevant to the functions of the Board.

Selection committee membership will consist of six persons appointed by the Minister, namely, a chairperson independent of any particular interest, two nominees each from the producer and packer sectors of the honey industry, and a person with professional staff selection experience who is to be nominated by the four industry members of the committee.

Transitional provisions are included in the Bill which will ensure that existing Board membership and export controls will continue until the proposed new structure is fully in place and operational. It is expected that this stage will be reached not later than 1 January next.

It is the intention of the Government that the operation of the reconstituted Honey Board be reviewed after five years in a fundamental way and accordingly, the Bill provides for termination of its constituting legislation after six years from its commencement.

Mention was made earlier of proposed amendments to the honey levy and export charge Acts. These Acts generate the funds which finance the Board, and the projected amendments will give the peak organisations of the honey industry a formal right to influence the level of funding to be provided to the Board. In addition, they will create scope in the levy Acts to increase that funding beyond the present limit if the industry decides to seek an increase in the future.
The new arrangements I have outlined are not expected to impose any additional costs on the Commonwealth. Little change is anticipated in the cost to the industry of maintaining the Board.
I am confident that this Bill and associated legislation will establish a more effective institutional basis for the honey industry with which to respond to future marketing challenges.
HONEY LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Honey Levy Act (No 1) 1962, under which a levy is imposed on honey sold in Australia. Income from the levy is used in part for the financing of the Australian Honey Board and in part for the financing of honey research programs. It complements the revenue obtained for these purposes under the Honey Levy Act (No. 2) 1962 and the Honey Export Charge Act 1973.

The principal Act specifies maximum rates for the Honey Board and research components of the levy, and operative rates are prescribed by regulation. In the case of the Honey Board component, the Board recommends to the Minister the rates to be set.

Under the proposed amendments, the Australian Honey Board will in future be required to consult with the national organisations of honey producers and honey packers before recommending to the Minister any change in the rate of levy imposed to finance the Board's operations. At present, the Board is not obliged to do so. A further provision will prevent the Board from recommending a levy rate higher than that agreed to by the producers' organisation. The object is to enhance the Board's accountability to industry.

It is further proposed to increase the maximum rate of levy that can be imposed to finance the activities of the Board from 2.2c to 5c per kilogram of honey. The operative rate as prescribed by regulation is now at the maximum permissible level, and a higher levy maximum will provide scope for raising the present operative rate as and when recommended by the industry in the future.

While the increased levy maximum will create scope for increasing the rate of the Honey Board component of the levy beyond its present level, no increase will take place until such time as the honey industry and the Board recommend that a higher rate be prescribed and the recommendation is implemented. The Bill has no financial implications for the Government.
HONEY LEVY (No. 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Honey Levy Act (No. 2) 1962, under which a levy is imposed on honey used in the production of other goods. Apart from covering honey disposed of by this particular method, the Act is identical in its provisions with the Honey Levy Act (No. 1) 1962.

The amendments proposed by this Bill to the Honey Levy Act (No. 2) 1962 are the same as those which have been proposed to the Honey Levy Act (No. 1), and have been explained in the second reading speech on the Honey Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988. The comment made in that speech on financial implications of the amendments applies also to this Bill.
HONEY EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Honey Export Charge Act 1973, under which a charge is imposed on honey exported from Australia. Income derived from the export charge is used in part for the financing of the Australian Honey Board and in part for the financing of honey research programs. It complements the revenue obtained for these purposes under the Honey Levy Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1962, which apply to honey disposed of on the home market.

The principal Act specifies maximum rates for the Honey Board and research components of the export charge, and operative rates are prescribed by regulation. In the case of the Honey Board component, the Board recommends to the Minister the rates to be set.

Under the proposed amendments the Australian Honey Board will be required to consult with the honey producers' and honey packers' organisations prior to recommending to the Minister any change in the rate of the export charge component which funds Board activities. The Board will be precluded from recommending a rate higher than that agreed to by the producers' or packers' organisation.
The amendments, which will enhance the accountability of the Australian Honey Board to the honey industry, have no financial implications for the Government or the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill implements, apparently for the last time, the practice of introducing a general omnibus Bill into each sitting of the Parliament as allegedly an expeditious way of making minor amendments to `tidy up' legislation. Since this Government came into office the results have seldom been expeditious and frequently they have stretched the guidelines beyond reasonable limits. The guidelines for statute law Bills included, firstly, correcting drafting errors; secondly, connection and updating, including modernisation of style-honourable senators will recall the number of Bills we saw with the phrase `and she' added to the word `he' and so on-thirdly, routine administrative changes; and, fourthly, with the approval of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), changes of so-called minor political significance. The guidelines excluded matters involving taxes or appropriations, lengthy matters, matters constituting change to the national companies and securities legislation, contentious issues, complex drafting, and substantial policy issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill, which amends 31 different Acts and repeals 10 Acts, is not opposed by the Opposition. The amendments are not contentious and do not involve any substantial policy issues, although some border on the lengthy. The Government has decided to discontinue Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills and proposes instead a system of statute law revision Bills and portfolio omnibus Bills. The Government has indicated that major new policy proposals will continue to be implemented, in the first instance, by separate Bills. Also, in future, wherever possible, consequential amendments will be included in the principal Bill rather than in a separate consequential provisions Bill.

In his second reading speech the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) indicated that the Government's objective is to enhance further opportunities for parliamentary scrutiny of proposed legislation. I can only hope that that objective is put into practice. To date, the record of the Government in allowing adequate scrutiny or consideration of complex legislation has been abysmal, with much legislation being rushed into the other place before any real opportunity for the consideration that much of that legislation deserves has been given. On occasions, the coalition parties have been able to join with the Australian Democrats to defer consideration of some of this legislation, just to give people, particularly those outside the chamber with a vital interest in the legislation, an opportunity to consider it and express their views.

It is also noted that the Government has agreed to new guidelines for the inclusion of matters in portfolio Bills, which will enable it to include amendments of all legislation with a ministerial portfolio or of related legislation within the portfolio. I am grateful for the undertaking that the Minister has given my office that he will table the guidelines. While the guidelines may ensure that these amendments are limited to technical and administrative changes of a minor nature, the record of this Government in introducing lengthy and sometimes complex amendments in omnibus Bills of this nature has not been good.

The Minister will no doubt recollect the occasion when 60 amendments were made to the Trade Union Training Authority Bill in May 1985 which substantially altered the rights and responsibilities of both the individuals and groups involved and which clearly was an abuse of the use of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill guidelines. The Opposition will be closely scrutinising this change of policy which transfers minor policy amendments from the statute law Bills to portfolio Bills to see whether the Government's performance matches its rhetoric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This, thankfully, is the last of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills, as Senator Lewis has already said. There have been quite a number of problems on the way through with this approach, mainly because of the Government's willingness to stretch the guidelines that were originally provided for these types of Bills. In this Bill, for example, we find six pages of amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act, particularly with regard to the Master of the Court. It is an uncontentious matter in anyone's language but, nevertheless, a matter comprising six pages of a Bill cannot be said to be a short one. In fact, it is probably longer than the average Bill that is introduced in this place. So I think it will be useful from now on for those types of amendments to be made in the omnibus Bills. I suppose we will have problems with those as well, but at least we have now separated out statute law revision, that is, amendments relating to technical drafting and repeal of spent or non-operative legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the matter of non-operative or spent legislation, I think it would be useful to include in subsequent statute law revision Bills some reason as to why the laws involved are in fact being repealed. There is absolutely no mention in the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) of why those laws are being repealed. One should be able to find out why they are inoperative, if that is the case. I think a note should be provided on each of the Acts that are to be repealed. For example, why are we now repealing two repeal Acts? I think that is interesting in itself. One of those is a rather interesting Act, namely, the Cities Commission (Repeal) Act of 1975. That certainly dates back to another time. Most of them are of an age that would lead one to believe that there is some reason why they are being repealed or why they have become inoperative, and if that is the case we ought to have the reasons provided to us. I imagine that the two Acts on wool marketing were not picked up last time we went through this exercise and, obviously, the Australian Capital Territory Electricity Supply Amendment Acts are included under another item. However, can the Minister indicate in his reply the reason for the repeal Acts being repealed?

The only other matter that I wish to raise concerns the exercise with regard to the portfolio Bills. Obviously, these Bills, two of which I think are currently before Parliament, if not in this place at least in the other place, can become quite sensitive. They cannot be treated in the way that ordinary legislation is treated. The omnibus Bills will go through this chamber with a minimum of fuss. I believe that a reasonable amount of time needs to be provided and that at least some comment in the second reading speech or in the explanatory memorandum ought to be attached to each of the items in those omnibus Bills. Without that I think there will be some significant problems, given the size of some of those omnibus Bills that are likely to be introduced.

Can the Minister give us some indication of the specific guidelines that the Government intends to follow with the omnibus Bills, so that at least we will have a gauge against which we will be able to check? It may be that the Government does not want to give us that, on the basis of thinking that we should keep to the ones given to us on the statute law. However, I wonder whether we can have those guidelines. Presumably, such guidelines have been drawn up and I think they would be very useful to the Senate in consideration of omnibus Bills introduced in future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be echoing what has already been said about the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1988, but I want to refer specifically to the amendment to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933. The Bill includes substantial amendments to that Act and there is no way that anybody could suggest that the amendments merely tidy something up, or that they do any of the other things that we have been told. It involves a substantial change to the legislation; it provides for the establishment of a Master of the Supreme Court in the Australian Capital Territory. I applaud the establishment of the position of Master of the Supreme Court, but I do not know why this amendment to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act was not brought in in a proper manner.

SPEECH.PARA: I could take the full half hour to which I am entitled to explain how wrong I think it is to make these amendments in the manner proposed. I hope that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) can give a decent explanation for this matter. I would like the Minister to say that he will withdraw this provision from the Bill and that the Government will put it through the Parliament as it should be done. I can assume only that it has something to do with the Government's attitude to the Australian Capital Territory that something as significant as the appointment of a Master of the Supreme Court is shoved into a Bill like this and is not done in the proper manner. I would make a similar comment in relation to the amendments to the Maritime College Act, which go on for some pages and again, clearly, should have been introduced in their own amending Bill.

We continually hear about the high cost of legal proceedings, the high cost of employing a lawyer and the drain on resources of legal aid, yet Bills like this continue to come before Parliament-Bills which make obtaining legal advice more expensive than otherwise would be the case if the law could be presented more simply. Any solicitor who must do research to advise his client and who has to thumb through all these Acts to find out exactly what has happened must spend more time and, therefore, it is more expensive for his client than can be justified.

I think it is outrageous to treat legislation in this way, and I just hope that the Government appreciates what it is doing and mends its ways. Other legislation included in this Bill is treated in the same way. I note that the Government has corresponded with the Australian Capital Territory Law Society about the establishment of a Master of the Supreme Court and that it has substantially agreed to the requests that have been made. As I said, I am not commenting on or criticising the content, but I think that the way that it has been done deserves some explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on what is the last of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills to be introduced into this chamber. I think it should be acknowledged that it was probably the activity of this chamber in particular in sending certain proposals contained in a former Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill to one of its committees which has, in part, led to the Government's decision to abandon this legislative procedure, which has been used for many years, to deal with amendments necessary to a wide range of legislation. I think it is true that the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill has become so wide in its scope and has embraced so many areas that its sheer size has been daunting, and I think it has given an impression, perhaps beyond the actual substance, that indeed it was attempting to achieve something outside the scope suggested in the guidelines. I think on only one or two occasions was there any real transgression, and of course that was pointed out very firmly during this chamber's consideration of those parts of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills which did offend.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators will know, the Government has decided to bring in portfolio legislation Bills. It may be of interest to senators if I table the guidelines for including amendments in portfolio legislation Bills, and I will ensure that a copy goes to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee for its interest. I formally table those guidelines, which state:
1. A portfolio omnibus bill may include amendments of all legislation within a ministerial portfolio or of certain ``related'' legislation within the portfolio.
2. Major new policy proposals not previously included in any legislation should be implemented, in the first instance, by a separate Bill.
3. No provision that imposes a tax may be included (see section 55 of the Constitution).

4. Sensitive policy issues which are likely to raise major political considerations or potentially lengthy debates in one or both Houses of Parliament should be given effect to by a separate amending Bill.

5. Parliamentary Counsel has a discretion to ``close-off'' a bill which is becoming too lengthy when it is required for introduction before either outstanding instructions are available or drafting resources are available to draft the remainder of the Bill.

During debate on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1988 now before us, Senator Macklin asked about the repeal of the Wool Marketing (Loan) Act 1974 and the Wool Marketing (Loan) Act (No. 2) 1974. I am advised that no transactions have been recorded under those Acts since 1978-79 and that the Australian Wool Corporation's reserve price activities are now industry financed and therefore the Act is exhausted.

In relation to the Cities Commission (Repeal) Act 1975, I am advised that its provisions are no longer operative, that its obligations have been fulfilled and hence it is no longer necessary. That is all I have available on that Act at the moment.

In relation to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933 and the proposed amendment providing for the appointment of a Master of the Supreme Court, it is true that this is a rather lengthy provision, and indeed, it was only in that respect that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee found it necessary to pass comment. Indeed, it said that the proposed amendment may not be regarded as contentious and does not involve a substantial policy issue, but it did say that the amendment `borders on the lengthy'. Whether that is the case is a matter of judgment, but it brought that point to our attention. Be that as it may, I do not think it deserved the caning it received from Senator Reid.

I hope that the new portfolio legislation Bill arrangement, when it comes into operation, provides a satisfactory mechanism which allows proper scrutiny of this type of amendment to major legislation within portfolios.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

—There are a number of amendments to this Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Jenkins does not mind, I will precede her in speaking because, as she knows, we will be supporting the Australian Democrat amendment. It might be best that I get my reasoning out of the way so that the Australian Democrats can move their amendment and we can have a vote. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the Australian Democrats' amendment--
—Order! That amendment is not before the Chair at the moment. You will have a chance to move that after these particular amendments have been dealt with.

—In which case, Mr Chairman, I rise to speak against the amendments moved by the Opposition. Mr Chairman, I am not speaking to our amendment, but we will move our amendment because we believe that it more realistically reflects the situation--
—Senator Jenkins, you are perfectly entitled to foreshadow your amendment as an alternative to what is being proposed.

—The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) referred to both, with due respect, Mr Chairman. We believe that our amendment reflects the actual situation-a situation which has existed for some time. Under the Opposition's amendment section 32 (1) (b) would state:

SPEECH.PARA: not fewer than 2 and not more than 3 other persons appointed by the relevant authority, after consultation with the relevant staff organisation.

A person shall not be appointed under paragraph (1) (b) unless the relevant authority and the relevant staff organisation have first agreed that the person is suitable for appointment.

I would like to point out to the Committee that what we are talking about is a series of joint selection committees. These committees change according to the appointments under discussion. Therefore, on each occasion the chairperson appointed by the Minister will be different. It has been indicated to me in consultations with the relevant authorities and with representatives of the staff organisations that the chairperson will be, for the most part, an officer who is at least one grade above the person to be appointed. One of the other persons will be a person who would be in a position of authority above the person applying for the appointment. The third person would be a person recommended by the relevant organisation on behalf of the interviewee.

As far as the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is concerned, these selections are being made under peer assessment and selection criteria. For the interest of the Committee, I have with me the positions advertised in the Supplement to Schools Bulletin No. 324 of 10 March 1988. This supplement states that officers interested in having their names registered for vacancies that may occur in the Authority's Office during 1988 are invited to apply for such positions. One of these positions with vacancies is the Peer Assessment and Selection Section. The joint selection committee would be formed of different persons on each occasion. Of course some of these people will have applied already under these auspices.

A third person may be appointed to join the selection committee. This person might be a member of or employer in a certain trade area if the appointment being examined by the joint selection committee is in such an area. It may indeed be a head of a department of an interstate technical and further education (TAFE) college. It may even be the principal of an interstate TAFE college if the position is a relatively high one. Therefore, what we are talking about are rolling committees-different committees on each occasion. Therefore, it is absolutely essential that the joint selection committees are formed by agreement of the relevant authority and the relevant staff organisation. In fact, they will not work if this is not the case. If agreement cannot be found the interviewee can then go through the normal appeals system. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats cannot agree with clause 7 as printed. On this occasion we agree with the Liberal-National Party coalition that in fact clause 7 amounts to a veto clause rather than an industrial democracy clause, which is what we favour. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, clause 7, proposed subsection 32 (2), lines 10 and 11, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:
`` `(2) A person shall not be appointed under paragraph (1) (b) unless the relevant authority and the relevant staff organisation have first agreed that the person is suitable for appointment.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 7, clause 7, at end of proposed section 33, add the following new subsections:
``(6) A Joint Selection Committee shall not refuse to consider an application on the basis that the applicant is not a member of a relevant staff organisation.

``(7) A Joint Selection Committee, or a member of a Joint Selection Committee, shall not, in assessing the claims of applicants in accordance with subsection 33 (1), take into consideration whether an applicant is a member of a relevant staff organisation.''.

This amendment seeks to add two subclauses to clause 7 to ensure that a joint selection committee will not refuse to consider an application on the basis that the applicant is not a member of a relevant staff organisation and, secondly, that a joint selection committee or a member of it will not, in assessing the claims of applicants in accordance with subsection 33 (1) take into consideration whether an applicant is a member of a relevant staff organisation. This proposed amendment adequately reflects the coalition's view with respect to the priority that ought to be given in any application for a job, promotion or transfer to someone on the basis of whether that person is a member of a union. In other words, we think that no priority should be given to that at all. We see the addition of the proposed new subclauses as simply spelling that out and making it abundantly clear. It seems that no more needs to be added.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment, not because it in any way disagrees with the sentiments expressed but because it is illegal for such a committee to consider the question of whether a person is a unionist. As honourable senators would know from a cursory reading of the statute, proposed section 28 (1) makes it clear that, in promoting or transferring Commonwealth Teaching Service officers, the relevant authority must select the most efficient officer. Proposed section 28 (2) sets out the matters which must be taken into account in determining efficiency. Proposed section 31 authorises the relevant authority to promote or transfer an officer in accordance with the advice of a joint selection committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that, as a matter of law in making its recommendations to the relevant authority, a joint selection committee would be bound by the requirements of section 28 to assess the claims of applicants in terms of relative efficiency. A joint selection committee which had regard to whether an applicant was a union member would not be assessing the relative efficiency of that officer and would be taking an irrelevant consideration into account. Certain legal remedies or consequences would follow. Either the relevant authority could decline, under proposed section 34 (b), to accept the advice of the joint selection committee or a legal challenge could be brought on the basis that, in taking account of irrelevant considerations, the committee was not complying with section 28. In other words, we are saying that under the normal rules of administrative law to take account of such an irrelevant consideration would be to act ultra vires. Therefore, it would be illegal.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are against compulsory unionism. So, on the surface, we certainly support the intent of the Opposition's amendments. I am encouraged by the Minister's words. However, I feel that, as we have, for example, sex discrimination legislation and anti-racial discrimination legislation, the Minister should spell out precisely where in that section it says that it would be absolutely out of the question for anyone to be denied promotion on those particular grounds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One can do all sorts of things out of an abundance of caution, but I do not think it is necessary, otherwise we would have to list negatively all those matters which would be quite irrelevant and improper for the joint selection committee to take into account. The list could become endless. I understand entirely the sentiment which has been expressed; it is well understood. But I can assure honourable senators opposite that the best available advice is that it would be illegal for the committee to take that into account. Proposed section 28, which we have already passed as it is contained in clause 5, makes clear that, in the selection of officers, the committee must take into account the abilities, qualifications, experience, standard of work performance and personal qualities of each officer to the extent that they are relevant to the performance of the duties of the position and the potential of each officer for further career development and so on. We should not try to list by anticipation all the irrelevant matters which might be taken into account, such as whether one belongs to a staff association or union or is of a particular gender or race or some other matter. It would be improper and, more than that, illegal. Therefore, it could be quite adequately challenged.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of the explanation, I simply ask the Democrats and perhaps even Senator Vanstone to accept that that is the case and not to press this particular amendment. I can understand its symbolic value but I assure honourable senators opposite that it is unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the Minister's response. I just ask for one further point of clarification in relation to efficiency: Would it be permissible, within the definition of efficiency, to include an item about the fact that the person is a member of a trade union? In other words, in a fully unionised school would it not be the case that someone who was being promoted as a principal and who was not a unionist might find a great deal of difficulty in operating efficiently? Therefore, is this not a further point to raise now, rather than not at all?

SPEECH.PARA: I take the Minister's point in relation to the other items. I simply say, by way of explanation, that our Party's policy has been against compulsory unionism, but it is very much in favour of a fee for service. We tried to interest the Australian Council of Trade Unions in this on one occasion, but it got rather upset about it. We do not wish to support the bludger syndrome of people who are quite willing for others to pay for an organisation to go before the relevant industrial tribunals, for lawyers and for research which is needed to support pay and conditions issues. We are quite happy for there to be a fee for service, but we think that people have a natural right to refuse to belong to any organisation to which they do not wish to belong. We just want to make sure that a person's promotion would not be jeopardised in any way by the fact that he or she chose, on the grounds of conscience or whatever, not to belong to a particular union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition welcomes the comments of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that the Government is opposed to the question of union membership being taken into account in terms of transfers, promotions and appeals. It understands the points the Minister makes in relation to the guidance offered in section 28 to people involved in assessing others for promotion and transfer, but makes the point that compulsory unionism, whether spelt out in law or used in practice-and it is more often the case that it is used in practice than listed as some sort of legal requirement-has had a negative influence on the Australian economy. We take every opportunity we can to point out the change in direction that will be taken when we become the Government at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the Government agrees that there is no problem with the substantive content of these amendments, I think that it needs to make a better case as to why the two extra subsections should not be added to clause 7. These would give great heart to those who do not really want to belong to a union but do belong because they believe, rightly or wrongly, that their cause will be prejudiced if they do not. Therefore, we consider it appropriate to spell out loud and clear that what the Minister says is the case so that people who wish to avail themselves of the opportunities of the administrative law can do so with some heart, resting on two clear subsections. The matter of compulsory unionism, as opposed to discrimination on gender, race or whatever, spreads throughout and pervades the whole community. On that basis, it deserves to be spelt out-more so than the wide range of other areas where there could be discrimination. I agree with the Minister that it would be inappropriate to list every basis on which a joint selection committee was not permitted to act, but this is such an important and all-pervasive matter that it should be listed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Vanstone whether she knows of instances in the Australian Capital Territory or in the Commonwealth Teaching Service where there has been discrimination on those grounds. I am not aware of any discrimination in my home State of Western Australia, although I certainly know that both members and non-members of the State schoolteachers union are involved in schools and technical and further education colleges. —The Opposition does not see this as being--

SPEECH.PARA: My real concern, though, remains that if one starts to make a list of those matters which are illegally taken into account by reason of their being irrelevant to the considerations properly outlined in proposed section 28 as proper criteria for judging the efficiency of an applicant for a position, under the well known Latin tag expressio unius est exclusio alterius it may well be that the listing of one particular instance of such discrimination could lead to the conclusion that other irrelevant considerations are not to be regarded as so weighty. DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT (SHARE INCREASE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 March, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Government is aware, the Opposition does not oppose the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill 1988. I propose to take a moment or two to comment on what the Bill actually does. As the second reading speech indicates, the Bill really has a rather lengthy history. It began back in 1984 when the governors of the World Bank, or the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)-that was its original title but usually these days it is called the World Bank-agreed to undertake an increase of $US7 billion in the capital of that international financial institution. At the same time, for somewhat complex technical reasons, which I will not bother to go into, the governors agreed upon the first phase of a related share allocation in the capital of the bank between the members of the bank of which, of course, Australia is one. This was related to the substantive capital increase itself. The Australian Government has already completed action on both of those major elements of the decisions taken in 1984 with legislation that passed through the Parliament in 1986, and the payment arrangements relating to that are already in train.

SPEECH.PARA: What the present Bill does is to tidy up the very small remaining element of the matter which was agreed upon by the governors of the World Bank in 1986 in what was called the second and, indeed, final phase of that supplementary share allocation. Under this proposal Australia is entitled, but not obliged, to take up, I think, an additional 178 shares in the capital of the bank, involving a total amount of something over $US21m of which 8.75 per cent or $US1.88m is so-called paid up capital-and I will come back to that momentarily-and the other 91.25 per cent is capital at call, and I will also return to that.

The paid up portion, which is the portion to which in particular the immediate financial aspects of this Bill relate, is paid, first of all, by the Australian Government, as it is entitled to do by the resolution of the Board of Governors, in the form of a promissory note which will be drawn down by arrangement between the World Bank and the Australian authorities over what is expected to be a term of four years from the date of the passage of this legislation.

The remaining element of the contingent financial obligation for the Australian Government-the other 91.25 per cent of the total capital raising involved-is, as I said, capital at call. It is worth while pausing at that point for a moment and taking note of what is actually involved there. The International Bank-the World Bank-borrows very large sums in the international capital markets. Up to June of last year-that is, the end of its last fully completed financial year-the World Bank had lent altogether, since its inception, about $US120 billion, to its various member countries, including Australia back in the 1950s. I think we have now fully paid off the few World Bank loans that were on our books back in the 1950s. Almost the whole of that $US120 billion worth of lending to member countries has been financed by the World Bank from borrowings in its own name in the international financial markets.

The importance of the uncalled capital of the bank, which we will now be adding to slightly, is that it is uncalled capital which represents in effect the guarantee, or the joint guarantees, of all the member countries of the bank for those borrowers. The bank has never defaulted on the repayment of any borrowing it has made in international markets. I think I am correct in saying that, while there may have been one or two occasions on which, in anything but technical terms, member countries of the bank have defaulted on loans it has made to them, in the end the bank has never had a bad debt from any of its member countries. So the question of actually falling back upon the guarantees of the members has never arisen. Nevertheless, the financial markets regard it as extremely important to have standing behind the borrowing prospectuses that the bank issues when it makes large loan raisings in the international capital markets the names and guarantees of the member countries of the bank, particularly the highly developed and, if you like, richer countries, such as the United States of America, Britain, Germany, Canada, Japan and, in the last resort, even Australia, because in the end that is the guarantee that the lenders in those markets to the World Bank will get their money, if they have to do so.

What the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill does, in effect, is complete the last little bit of unfinished business arising out of events in 1984 and 1986 and, as I have said, the Opposition does not oppose it. Under this Bill, Australia will pay up the last portion of its share in that enterprise. Because the Bill concerns the World Bank, it leads immediately into consideration of the general state of that part of the world to which the bank's activities these days principally-one might almost say wholly-relate. I refer, of course, to the so-called Third World. At the end of last year, total Third World debt-there are various estimates of this, but there is some degree of consensus-amounted to about $US1,080 billion. That was an increase of roughly two-thirds-66 per cent-in the seven years since 1980.

These days we are depressingly familiar with the topic of Third World debt, not merely because of the quite proper concern that many people in more fortunate countries, such as Australia, have for the plight of people living in Third World countries, often in conditions of extreme poverty, but also because, as we have become uncomfortably aware in the past few years, of the potential risks of default on much of that debt. Those risks carry possible dangers to the stability of the whole of the international financial system, including the domestic financial systems of many of the highly developed countries, such as the United States, Britain and Germany.

I remind the Senate that this question first surfaced most acutely in July or August 1982 at the time of the Mexican debt crisis. It suddenly appeared to a startled world that Mexico had acquired a great deal more debt than most people had understood and it looked as though Mexico would not be able to meet the interest on those debts. I can vividly recall attending-I think in September of that year-the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which were held in Toronto. To say the least, there was no other topic of conversation but the Mexican debt crisis which had just occurred and with which the major financial powers were just beginning to grapple, under the leadership of a very great public servant, Mr Paul Volker, who retired recently after a long period of extremely distinguished service as the Chairman of the United States Federal Reserve system, or the Federal Reserve Bank as it is generally known.

That seems a long time ago but, in fact, it was less than six years ago. I think that the implications of those events, even now, probably are not generally fully understood. One implication was that a few months later, immediately following that meeting in Toronto, there was a major change in United States monetary policy. That major change was from a policy of monetary restraint to a policy of monetary relaxation. Mr Volker saw not merely the dangers for borrowers such as Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Peru, Bolivia and many others at that time-not merely Latin America-but also the dangers to the United States banking system if those countries were to default on their debts to United States banks, among others, which were heavily involved in the lending which had been going on to those countries in the aftermath of the first and second oil shocks in the 1970s.

Today, roughly 5 1/2 years later, the economic upswing in the United States which was initiated in late 1982 principally by that major policy change-I do not say that it was the only thing; a lot of budgetary stimulus was going on too, because of what has come to be called Reaganomics-is still proceeding, although I think it is fair to add that in the view of many people a tendency to falter has been beginning to appear in the last six months or so. That was notably signalled at the time of the crash on Wall Street on 19 October last year.

Nevertheless, that 5 1/2-year period has provided the world, and was meant to provide it, as a matter of conscious decision-making-one might almost call it international economic policy decision-making-by the United States authorities, aided by the authorities in some other countries but led by the United States, with a breathing space. That breathing space was intended to provide a number of parts of the world with an opportunity to get their respective houses in order. It might be worth while reflecting for a moment or two on how well or, I regret to say in some cases, how badly that breathing space has been used.

First, I turn to the world banking system. I think it is true to say that not all major world banks have been as successful as others in putting their individual houses in order. For example, the Bank of America is a very different and much diminished bank from what it was. I think that at that time it was the No. 2, or perhaps the No. 1, bank in the world. Today it is only a shadow of that. On the other hand, other major American banks have come through those difficult years rather well. They have restored their balance sheets and have either written off, or at least largely provided against, debts on their books which they regarded as being either doubtful or potentially bad in relation to many of the debtor countries concerned. Even if some kind of catastrophic or chain default situation developed in those countries today, they would be able to stand the shock to their profit and loss accounts, and hence to their balance sheets that that would entail. They would not, of course, welcome that. Nevertheless they are now much more able to handle such a potential situation than they would have been 5 1/2 years ago.

I think it is generally true to say that the European banks-the Swiss banks and the German banks-have much more quickly moved to that situation, the British banks perhaps being somewhere in between. If one may make a generalisation, I would say that the world banking system has made more or less effective use of that 5 1/2 year breathing space to put itself in a position where it is no longer at anything like the same degree of risk that it would have been at had other decisions been taken in the aftermath of the Mexican debt crisis breaking out in July or August 1982.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank itself, to take other players involved in the game, if we can call it a game, have been seen throughout this period as major participants in the restructuring process and in the handling of this potential crisis which has built up in the system. Both of them have made their contributions, although I think it is fair to say that neither has made nearly as large a contribution as some of the initial suggestions for their role in the scheme of things might have had them make. Each has gone about its task in, I think, a characteristically workmanlike manner, but neither has played a particularly large role in the scheme of things. In fact, the World Bank, the institution which is the subject of this Bill and which the now Secretary of the United States Treasury, Mr James Baker, proposed for a major role at the annual general meeting in Seoul, I think 2 1/2 years ago, has actually not been able to perform that role, partly because it has not been able to get the agreement of the other parties to cooperate with Mr Baker's plan in bringing about the changes for which he had hoped. I think we would have to say, as far as the IMF and the IBRD have been concerned, that their performance, while workmanlike, has been in some senses perhaps a little disappointing.

I come to perhaps the most important participants or players on the stage-namely, the Third World countries themselves, the indebted developing countries. I think one has to say that whilst experience has been mixed, the overall result, looking back on the last 5 1/2 years, has been rather depressing. A few of the countries concerned have taken advantage of the period. South Korea is a notable example. At the time, in mid-1982, South Korea had debt ratios which were amongst the highest in the world. They were well and truly up with many of the Latin American basket-case economies, as we have rather slightingly come to describe them. But the South Korean authorities have moved with determination and, I must say, with great effectiveness during the past 5 1/2 years to put that to right. They have radically amended their budgetary and balance of payments positions, and hence, as a consequence, of course, their debt position. From a situation where, 5 1/2 years ago, South Korea was regarded as one of the countries over which a large question mark temporarily hung, I think it is fair to say that that country today no longer has such a question mark hanging over it at all, from a purely financial viewpoint, that is.

That is a success story. I wish there were more of them. There are very few such success stories in Latin America. Countries such as Brazil, I think, have made some progress, but there has been a continual tendency to lapse back, to take two steps forwards and one step or 1 1/2 steps backwards. So the progress in those countries has been slow at best. It must be said that in most countries-this is particularly true when one comes to black Africa, which is the other centre of great indebtedness, at least in relative terms, in the world-there has been no progress, or virtually none at all. In fact, many of those countries are in a worse state of indebtedness today than they were at the time the breathing space period began. I have to say that it is rather depressing.

It is particularly depressing because during this time the actions of the United States and of the developed countries more generally, whatever we may have thought of this in Australia, have nevertheless held up the world. I know we have had a government here which two years ago was bewailing the fact that our terms of trade had deteriorated dramatically and that therefore our balance of payments was adversely affected by that, with consequences which the Government was then not finding comfortable. I will not digress into saying that there were more reasons than that for the state of our economy at that time, but that was certainly one of the arguments being strongly advanced by the Government at that time. Today, a year or so later, we have a situation where, as is common knowledge, international commodity prices have been rising very strongly for the last 9 to 12 months, particularly many of those commodities of which Australia is an exporter, such as wool, nickel and others which have made outstanding price gains.

The Government has not been quite so eager to tell us about the improvement in our terms of trade as it was some time ago to tell us about the deterioration. The relevance of that is that if and when-I think it might be fair to say `when'-the cycle again turns, as I think everyone expects it to do at some point, although there may be differences of opinion about the timing, there will be consequences not merely for Australia, which is not the subject of my remarks tonight, but particularly for these Third World developing countries which are the clients of the World Bank. We sometimes talk of Australia as being a commodity exporting country, and that is true; but if Australia is dependent upon exports of commodities, a fortiori most of those developing countries certainly are. If most of those countries today are showing very little improvement in their state of indebtedness after what has been, from a broad viewpoint, not a bad period of world economic growth, what can we look forward to when that world economic growth slows down or perhaps for a time goes into reverse? I think we can expect at that time that there will be a fall in commodity prices. The countries concerned will suddenly find that the value of their exports is much diminished, and their capacity to service their debts will have fallen commensurately. While, as I say, there have been no formal defaults to date, unfortunately I do not think we will be able to expect that to continue when that day arrives. As I have said, although I am not particularly directing my remarks to our own situation, it is nevertheless noteworthy that that situation will also be fraught with some similar difficulties for another commodity exporting country, namely Australia.
We have said that we will not oppose this Bill, and I conclude my remarks on that note.
