SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill. As has already been said in this debate, this Bill seeks to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up an increase in its capital subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, commonly known as the World Bank. The Australian Democrats will be supporting this Bill. The Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, said in his second reading speech that the bank was `an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance' to the Third World countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Community groups in Australia concerned with aid, represented, for example, by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, recognise that the bank is a major source of finance for development. They support the bank. Nevertheless, they are critical of certain aspects of its operation. I wish to focus on some of these criticisms. Generally, they revolve around whether the bank takes sufficient account of social and environmental aspects of development. I hope to look at the degree to which the World Bank is likely effectively to incorporate these types of concerns. The criticisms of the bank probably were neatly summarised in a letter sent on behalf of members of this Parliament to the President of the bank. That letter was circulated to honourable senators by Senator Hill, who will be speaking in this debate after me. A similar letter was sent by members of the United States Congress and the parliaments of Canada and the United Kingdom. I seek to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr. Barber Conable
President
The World Bank
1818 H Street, N.W.
Washington, DC 20433
Dear Mr. Conable,

We join our colleagues from other countries to convey to you our concern for the growing numbers of people living in absolute poverty. As you know, the source of popular support for the World Bank is for its work in assisting the world's poor. Statements that you have made since becoming president of the Bank, and your establishment of the high level task force on poverty, make it clear that you share our concerns. We note particularly your comments in Nairobi earlier this year:
In developing nations . . . too many women are at the bottom. Their arms hold the family together. Their hands build the foundation of stable growing communities.
But development efforts have not lent enough strengths to those arms, have not entrusted enough resources to those hands. And, along with women, development itself has suffered.

We are pleased that the Bank intends to provide more support for the efforts of poor women. We note the proposed increase in the number of professional staff members devoted to women in development. However, the Bank's lending-in agriculture and rural development for example-does not yet adequately involve poor women in planning and implementation. As the Bank proceeds with restructuring, and attempts to focus more on women, it is important that it work with and through organizations that represent poor women.

We commend the Bank's plans to increase its lending for primary health care and for primary education. This type of lending certainly can benefit some of the poorest people in developing countries. However, even with the proposed doubling of funding for population, health and nutrition, it would still represent only 2%-3% of the Bank's loan portfolio. Further increases in primary health lending are needed if we are to reach the World Health Assembly's goal of `Health for All by the Year 2000'.

A crucial area in which the Bank could take steps to protect the interests of the poorest people is in adjustment lending. We do not believe that it is sufficient to merely cushion the impact of structural adjustment on the poor. The policies need to be re-thought. Recent studies sponsored by the Bank and by Unicef suggest a variety of ways in which policies could be tailored to the needs of the poor. For example, when government spending on health care is to be reduced, shifting spending from expensive curative health care, such as hospitals, to primary health care, can benefit more people at less cost. We also hope that the Bank will persevere with introducing adjustment lending in social sectors to improve the services most needed by the poor.

In developing adjustment lending policy, in working with poor women mentioned earlier and in many other areas, the input of the poor themselves is too often overlooked. While it would be impractical for Bank staff to interview large numbers of very poor people prior to project identification, there are a rapidly growing number of non-governmental organizations (NGO's) in developing countries that can and do represent the poor. We consider it imperative that the Bank should involve these NGO's in the preplanning, execution and monitoring of projects to a much greater extent, as well as to involve them in discussions of policy and policy dialogue.

Another area where Bank-indigenous NGO involvement must expand includes the protection of the environment. Although there has been a considerable awakening in the Bank with regard to the importance of environmental issues, there is still a great deal that must be changed. The environmental quality and economic sustainability of specific Bank projects must be assured.

Finally, it concerns us that so little of the Bank's lending focuses on the needs of the poorest people. The ``Focus on Poverty'' report (1986) states that currently only 29% of Bank lending is directly poverty oriented. We suggest that the Bank establish the goal of targeting 60% of its lending directly to projects whose primary purpose is to assist the poorest 40% of people. The Bank's own evaluations have shown that its poverty oriented projects have often shown the highest rates of return.

We wish you well as you seek to utilize the considerable resources of the Bank in the battle against world poverty. You can anticipate the continued support of the undersigned for the policies outlined above.
Sincerely,
Member of Parliament

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The letter suggests that more attention be given to the question of what to do with women, for example, in development. The bank's lending in agriculture and rural development does not yet adequately involve poor women in planning and implementation. More attention should be given to population, health and nutrition projects. A doubling of the funding here would represent only 2 to 3 per cent of the bank's loan portfolio. There is a danger that adjustment lending to assist countries alter their structure of the economies can simply result in a cycling of World Bank money to First World banks to pay the debts of Third World countries without any real contribution to development and the alleviation of poverty in those countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Adjustment layers are tied to conditions on matters such as tariffs and other forms of protection-exchange rate management, government fiscal and monetary policies and the scale of public sector involvement in an economy. In all these things there is a danger in adjustment lending that the bank can overstep its brief and impose what is, in fact, a political ideology, such as the degree of public sector activity in a country's economy. Greater efforts should certainly be made by the bank to involve the rapidly growing number of non-governmental organisations in developing countries which can and do represent the poor.

It is interesting to note that this Government, in terms of its aid, has moved to give more of that aid to non-government organisations. The environmental quality of specific bank projects must be assured. This is a crucial issue. In our own region, the Asian Development Bank warns in its just released annual report that demand for natural resources will rise greatly in the next 15 years because of population and economic growth, amongst other things. The bank points to the loss of about 11 per cent or 80 million hectares of current forest cover in the region, endangering critical watersheds and increasing soil erosion and the frequency of flooding and drought. Allied to environmental concerns is the impact of development projects in Third World countries on indigenous peoples. One could consider the impact of the growth of tourism, for example, in northern Thailand and the difficulty that the indigenous hill tribes are having in what has almost become a flood of tourists turning the area into nothing less than a human zoo.

An example of a specific World Bank project giving rise to serious concerns in these regions is its funding for Indonesia's transmigration program from Java to Borneo and Irian Jaya. According to community aid groups, the massive immigration into Irian Jaya, for instance, is leading to the clearance of great tracts of jungle and the alienation of the indigenous Melanesian peoples. The letter to which I referred previously concludes by urging that the bank focus much more of its lending on the needs of the poorest people. The letter suggests:
the Bank establish the goal of targeting 60% of its lending directly to projects whose primary purpose is to assist the poorest 40% of people.

I should point out that it is the notion that aid goes to alleviate the poor and the suffering in this world that sustains public support in Australia for the various aid groups that operate out of this country. I understand that to varying degrees the World Bank is responding to these concerns. Last year the bank set up a department to examine environmental issues. It is now headed by a New Zealander, Ken Piddington, who, I believe, used to head the New Zealand Department of Environment. He is well known not only in his own country but also outside it for fundamental and basic concerns to do with the environment and the progress of peoples.

My question is: To what extent are these concerns incorporated into the development of Australia's policy towards the bank and to the administration of our contributions and representations? Given that a great many parliamentarians from all parties endorsed and signed the letter that I have alluded to, there should be some guarantee from the Government that these concerns will be incorporated in our policy towards the bank. Yet it is my understanding that there is very little of a wider development perspective in Australia's policy towards the bank. The development of policy and the carriage of Australia's interest in the bank are almost exclusively the province of Treasury and so it is with Australia's relations with other international financial agencies. Treasury has long guarded its interest in this area. This has been documented by, amongst others, Peter Wilenski, a former private secretary to Gough Whitlam, more recently the former head of the Public Service Board and now head of the Department of Transport and Communications, in an essay entitled `Infanticide in the Bureaucracy: The case of the Australian Development Assistance Agency' and in his book Public Power and Public Administration. Wilenski describes how the Treasury resisted transferring any of its aid responsibilities to the new body established by the Whitlam Government to aggregate the many strands of Australia's development program. Wilenski says:

Treasury, despite the wording of the announced Cabinet decision that the agency `was to absorb the aid functions of the Treasury' refused to surrender its functions, and there was nothing that other departments could do.

Australia's representative on the bank's Board of Governors is the Treasurer. Australia's representative on the bank's Executive Board is a Treasury official. Australia alternates every two years between having the Executive Director and a Deputy Executive Director on the Board.

When a brief is prepared for the Treasurer on the bank-say, prior to his attendance at a meeting of the bank's Board of Governors-I understand that broader aid perspectives are included only as a secondary consideration. After the brief has been drafted by Treasury, it will be sent to the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for any additional comment. The Government will suggest that broader development concerns are represented through Australia's Deputy Governor at the bank, who is the head of AIDAB, and the fact is that the second to the Treasury officer on the Executive Board is also an AIDAB officer. However, the development of advice on the bank is, as I understand it, still almost exclusively flowing from the Treasury building. What I am suggesting is that there be a better bureaucratic arrangement to ensure that wider views on the development process are incorporated in this advice and that instructions are then issued to Australia's representatives at the bank. I am not in any way condemning the expertise of Treasury officials. What I am saying is that it cannot be expected that they, expert as they may be in economic matters, will be expert in health, educational and environmental aspects of development.

Australia can have significant input in day-to-day monitoring of the sorts of concerns I and many honourable senators have raised in the parliamentary letter. The bank's Board of Executive Directors must approve all the bank's loan proposals. Australia's representative should insist that all loan proposals are accompanied by environmental impact statements. If this is not the case at present, it is at least one area in which advancement may be made. For example, what are the guidelines followed by Australia's representatives at the bank in Washington? What are their goals? What does the Government see as Australia's objective from an aid perspective, as distinct from a financial or banking perspective? We are, after all, discussing further support that Australia desires to give the bank. I would have thought it appropriate in such a debate for the Government to have canvassed its philosophy towards the bank and the bank's work in the development of those parts of the world to which we are all dedicated.

It is a pity that this opportunity has been missed and one hopes that at some early stage the Government will provide the Senate with a clear enunciation of its view with regard to the matters I have raised and the matters which have been raised so succinctly and so well in the letter circulated by Senator Hill to honourable senators for their signature towards the end of last year. I hope the Government will see this as an opportunity to spell out not only to Australians, who after all are footing the bill, but to others around the world that our concern is that development be undertaken in such a way that the people are developed in an independent and human way and that the imposition of inhumane or environmentally destructive or uncaring policies is not something Australia would support.

There have been a number of instances in the past, for example, where Australian aid has gone to support policies which would not form part of the policies of any government that could conceivably be elected in this country. The majority of Australians would find such policies abhorrent. The World Bank is a very important organ for the development of those parts of the world that are in need, the poorest areas of the world where people are suffering. I had hoped that we would have seen a succinct statement of the Government's position. It is a pity that we have not, because the Government's philosophy in regard to this bank will tell us a lot about the developing policy of this Government towards aid not only in that area but through its other agencies. I hope that the Senate will not have to wait too long for a detailed philosophy of what the Government intends to do in supporting this important organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill 1988. I wish to take part in this debate because I, too, am concerned with the superficial contribution of the Government in this debate, as indicated by the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). It seems that we shall not have the benefit of contributions by any other Government senators, except no doubt the Minister in reply to the debate. But it is an important debate, not solely because of the fact that Australia is making a further contribution to the World Bank but because it leads to all the ongoing issues which should concern us about the methods of operation at the bank and the effectiveness of its programs.

SPEECH.PARA: To be specific, this Bill empowers the Treasurer to make necessary agreements to allow Australia to purchase an additional 178 shares in the capital stock of the bank, the cost of which subscription is to be $US1.88m. Australia is making a further direct contribution to the funds. Also we should bear in mind, as Senator Stone reminded us, that it is not only our contribution in shares that we take up, but in effect the guarantees that we give as a capital contributor, that give us a vested interest in our concern as to the appropriateness of the bank's investments.

These major issues which have been around for some time concern the internal operations of the bank, its efficiency, its internal auditing and accountability, and its methods of operation, and at a wider level concern the effectiveness of the bank's work, particularly in its contributions to development in developing countries, and whether programs have been successful. As I shall indicate later, a large number of the programs have been unsuccessful. If programs have been successful, one must consider whether the poor in these communities benefit, and whether the trickle-down effect which the bank has adopted in the past takes effect or whether we, or the bank through our support, are benefiting the minority, the well-off, in Third World communities. I would have thought that these important issues would be canvassed in this debate, but one sees in the second reading speech statements that are all-encompassing and rather unhelpful. The Minister in his speech said:
The IBRD is an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries . . .

What is the authority for that? It is unhelpful for the Minister simply to assert it, when we know that for many years there have been critical analyses as to whether it is an effective and efficient institution. If this Government is running counter to a widely held view in the international community, the least it can do is to provide us with evidence to support its claim.

The Government went on to indicate that the bank had lent about $US120 billion to its member countries. That gives some indication of the very major role that it plays in the world financial community. It has said that this money was largely borrowed from international financial markets and that the cost to taxpayers in terms of paid in capital subscriptions was only $US7.2 billion. The Government then told us that projects financed covered all the major sectors of economic development, with an emphasis on infrastructure facilities in the transport and communications, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply. That is interesting but it does not help us a great deal when we try to analyse whether the funds of the bank are in fact being expended wisely.

The Government has said that 85 per cent of evaluated projects achieved all or most of their objectives. What are these objectives? It is not helpful to us for the Government simply to say that 85 per cent of objectives have been achieved without giving us any indication of what they are. If the objective is simply to build a road, then it is clearly easily assessed whether the road has been built, but it is much more difficult to assess whether the road has contributed to the well-being of the community of that developing country. It tends to be even more difficult to assess whether it has been of benefit to the poor in that country.

I suppose the Government does give us the warm feeling that, in any event, our investment is more than balanced by procurements by the IBRD, including the International Development Association; that our contributions are more than covered. So, from a purely materialistic point of view, in that regard I suppose we should be pleased; but, of course, we are looking at the primary role of this international development bank and at our contribution as amounting to something greater than that, namely, to make a constructive and worthwhile contribution to developing countries so that their communities as a whole can benefit and so that they can play a more active part in the international economic community. I would like to have seen in the Minister's second reading speech on this Bill an analysis of whether that goal is being achieved.

The World Bank group includes a number of different arms, and the guidelines for each will obviously be slightly different. I recall that I have spoken previously about contributions to the soft lending arm of the organisation, the International Development Association. Of course, the IBRD is not the soft lending arm; its real function is to make contributions to countries that are perhaps now not in the category of being the least developed or the most poor and to help them build their economies. Thus, as I indicated previously, slightly different criteria might be expected.

It is interesting to note that we seem to have fallen into this category and, as Senator Stone reminded us, loans have been made to Australia. In fact, there seems to be some dispute as to whether we still owe money on those loans. I note that the summary of the statement of loans in the 1987 annual report of the World Bank indicates that we still owe $26m-although some other authorities, and the Government also, I understand, indicate that all our debts have now been repaid. We should look at this bank as playing a leadership role in providing development aid in the world. It is the most influential aid development institution and therefore, obviously, its pattern of loans and the priorities that it sets tend to be followed by others. I would have thought that that was all the more reason for the Government to have taken this new contribution and its obligation to the Senate seriously, and to have done a proper evaluation of the work that is being done by this body.

Mr Deputy President, as you would also be aware, changes have been made recently and the World Bank seems to have made an effort to recognise some of its failures of the past and to look at undertaking worthwhile reforms. Something of a purge and a restructuring has taken place. I respectfully suggest that there are now some promising signs under the leadership of the new President, Mr Conable. It is interesting therefore to look now at the type of goals that the bank is setting itself and the criteria that it is setting as its objectives. I am pleased to note that at a seminar sponsored by the Australian Development Studies Network, held only in the last few days in Canberra, Mr Donaldson of the World Bank outlined the five principal criteria for the objectives of World Bank policy as: growth, stability, sustainability, efficiency and equity. I would have thought that in general terms they are the type of objectives that we would be looking for, although one would very quickly acknowledge that to achieve all such objectives simultaneously is in fact a great challenge.

Who is receiving the benefits of loans from this arm of the World Bank group? It is interesting to note that seven countries receive over 50 per cent of such loans. They are: Brazil, Colombia, Indonesia, the Republic of Korea, Mexico, the Philippines and Turkey. These countries contain less than 10 per cent of the world's population, yet, as I have said, over 50 per cent of loans are devoted to them. Also, none of those countries is in the category comprising the poorest countries in the world, those low income economies that are mentioned in the 1987 World Bank annual report. Upon some reflection perhaps that makes sense because there is little point in simply making further loans on commercial terms to the poorest countries, which will not be able to repay those loans and which will go further into debt, as has happened in the past.

In relation to the poorest countries, perhaps the emphasis should be on grants and, where necessary, on soft arm loans, that is, subsidised loans. Perhaps we should be looking at other types of developing countries. Certainly, I accept totally what Senator Stone said in his contribution that Korea is an example of a country which has taken up the bit and which is really showing that it is able to turn from being an undeveloped nation into what it looks as though it will become, namely, an economic powerhouse of not only the region but the world. So the examples are there. Achievements can be made and financial support through organisations such as the World Bank can make a significant contribution towards those goals.

Senator Macklin mentioned that some of us in this place think that the criteria for assessing loans should not be simply on economic terms and that, in fact, if economic considerations are solely taken into account without other considerations the effect can be counterproductive. It can be counterproductive in social and political terms and in respect of the impact on the cultural fabric of the societies which are to receive funding. I respectfully submit that in the past the World Bank has not sufficiently taken into account criteria other than that which is purely economic, and in the long term that failure has shown itself in economic terms. Therefore, as Senator Macklin indicated, I have recently joined with other parliamentarians of this Parliament and those of Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States of America in writing to Mr Conable and stating that in the loan making procedures we believe greater consideration should be given to environmental and poverty indicators. In other words, we wish to see loans made for economic developments that are consistent with the local environment and which properly take into account real levels of poverty and hopefully can benefit those who are suffering most in these developing countries.

We are pleased that we have received a positive response from Mr Conable, and I indicate that we intend to continue that challenge in our own small way-although I suppose it is not so small when one considers that it is a group comprising of parliamentarians from throughout the world-to attempt to guide the World Bank in what we see as a better direction. I only regret that the Australian Government has not been able to take a leaf from that book in that it has not been prepared to act in similar fashion to that example and take up the challenge itself. There again, I guess the superficial nature of this contribution by the Minister is somewhat consistent with this Government's whole attitude to aid development or otherwise, and of course aid is significantly reduced under this Government.

I refer to comments made by Mr Conable, and again I think this gives us reason for some confidence in the future, which is why I am on my feet tonight. I believe that the new trends should be spoken about positively because with encouragement they may continue. When wrestling with the task of setting down the five priorities of the World Bank, which is under his stewardship, the President said:
They are to maintain and strengthen the Bank:
- as a central force for development and in the struggle against poverty;
- as a major influence of economic adjustment and growth, for debt rescheduling and trade liberalisation;
- as a steady source of project lending-especially in advancing agriculture beyond subsistence levels;
- as a sensitive advocate of the importance of population, environmental and women's concerns in the developing world and in the development process; and
- as a responsive institution quick to adjust to new needs and to adapt its strength to new challenges.

If in practice the bank is able to meet that rhetoric, I will certainly be pleased with its direction. I am pleased that Mr Conable has given some indication that it is more than just rhetoric, a point that was also mentioned by Senator Macklin. In the World Bank's 1987 report Mr Conable indicated that it had established a special poverty task force composed of senior staff to review the bank's poverty work and propose new activities. He said that it has recommended strengthening of the bank's poverty programs and also said that they will be discussed with executive directors of the bank in 1988. So it would appear, although I must concede on somewhat superficial analysis at the moment, that the bank will match its rhetoric with action-and that is pleasing.

I would like to see the Government acknowledge that it has been somewhat remiss and now take up the challenge as the Australian Government to ensure that within its responsibility and influence the World Bank continues down this path. I understand that some of the recent internal evaluations by the bank have shown a very large number of failed projects and that there has been very little evaluation. For example, I understand that in relation to the rural development program, on which $12.6 billion was expended in 1980-86-and as you would be well aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, a considerable portion of that has been in Africa-it has now been assessed that two-thirds of sub-Saharan African projects have failed. Failure is one thing, but I find equally disturbing this apparent lack of evaluation over the years. In fact, I understand that this program has been in place for some 20 years, during which time there has been inadequate evaluation, so in fact the extent of the failure and of the loss of these huge sums of money is only now coming to light.

I commend Mr Conable for at least bringing these matters to light and for looking for ways to improve future programs. I guess we would say that some of the evidence that is coming forward is pretty obvious when we look at the sort of things that need to be taken into account to make a rural development program work. However, it seems that in the past these matters have not been sufficiently considered, and they include such things as first obtaining a commitment from the local government. By that I mean a real commitment-not just a statement that it wants more soft loans or more development loans from the World Bank, but a real indication that the Government, through its internal policies, is prepared to cooperate and be part of these projects. It also requires evidence in that, if you are working down the path of, for example, land reform, which will be an integral part of this program, the local government is prepared to be part of it. Of course, that is one of the reasons for the partial failure of many programs under Marcos in the Philippines; and it is part of the reason for the partial failure of many programs in Ethiopia.

Apart from obtaining a real commitment from the local government it is now evident that there is a need for advisers who help set up these programs to not simply disappear once they are completed but to stay around to make sure that the local people are in a position to continue them. I have had the experience, as no doubt have other senators, in Africa of where rural development programs have worked marvellously while advisers have been present, but as soon as they have left the programs have collapsed. Therefore, what is needed is more emphasis on education and training of the local people so that when the advisers leave the local people are in a position to continue the projects.

It is these types of matters that are coming out of the evaluation which is now being done by the World Bank. As I indicated, I would have thought that they were obvious, but apparently the agencies are only now publicly recognising that they are necessary and that there has been a failure to meet such obvious needs in the past. So I commend the direction that the bank is now taking and the attitude of its President, Mr Conable. I express concern and disappointment that the Australian Government is not seriously participating in this debate and is not putting an attitude to the World Bank or, if it is, certainly it is not taking us into its confidence in relation to the attitude that it is putting to the World Bank. I would like to see the Government be more constructive and productive in this area than it has been in the past, and perhaps when we get to the next of these Bills-and they tend to turn up every session or two-we might see a more worthwhile contribution from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill 1988 is, as you would certainly be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, a non-controversial Bill. It constitutes a technical alteration to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act, the principal Act, which has been necessitated because of the change in the status of Australian Airlines from a statutory authority to a public company, effected in recent months by the Government with the support, I may say, of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the principal Act which this Bill seeks to amend was debated here only last October or thereabouts. That Act imposes a charge on Commonwealth authorities-a charge for the use of either an explicit Commonwealth Government guarantee for borrowings by such authorities or, for that matter, an implicit Commonwealth Government guarantee on such borrowings, that implicit guarantee deriving, of course, from the fact that all Commonwealth authorities are by definition wholly owned by the Commonwealth and therefore, whether there be an explicit guarantee or not, the Commonwealth effectively stands behind any borrowings by such authorities in the event of financial calamity overtaking them.

The Opposition will not oppose this Bill as such. However, we wish to move an amendment at the second reading stage of the Bill in the terms which I have caused to be circulated to the Senate and which I shall now refer to. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate endorses the sale of Australian Airlines, and therefore supports the Prime Minister's statement that `I believe that an Australian Airlines, whether totally in private hands or an Australian Airlines with a significant private holding, with therefore correspondingly diminished demands upon public resources, could perform the function of Australian Airlines at least as well as they are now and, I would say, arguably, better'. ''.

The truth is that we cannot allow this Bill to pass before us without taking the opportunity to give the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) some support on this matter of the privatisation of Australian Airlines. Goodness knows, he needs all the support he can get on that subject from honourable senators and honourable members on his own side of the respective chambers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly with this conference coming up.

—As I am reminded by Senator Tambling, particularly with the National Conference of the Australian Labor Party coming up on 6 June. Indeed, I am glad that my colleague Senator Tambling reminded me of that because we have been told in recent days that for once the Senate will be able to plan on a certain date of rising-or certain latest date of rising-namely, 2 June. Upon inquiry as to why this very welcome additional element of certainty should have been injected into our lives on this particular occasion, we have been told that the reason is that Government Ministers will all wish to spend all of Friday, 3 June, preparing themselves busily for the opening of their Party's biennial National Conference on Monday, 6 June. It is, of course, very comforting to understand that this Government has its priorities right: it puts the Party first and the Parliament second. As I say, in this case it has had the very welcome effect that we can at least pencil into our diaries a date of final Senate sitting of, at the latest, 2 June. I should not allow myself to be diverted in this way by interjections from behind me, welcome though they are.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the interjection I was saying that the Prime Minister needs all the support he can get on this matter. But, quite apart from that, the fact is that we totally agree with the Prime Minister in his remarks which are contained in the amendment that I have circulated. We know that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) supports those remarks too. I have to say that Senator Evans at any rate has been remarkably consistent about this matter of the privatisation of Australian Airlines and, indeed, the privatisation of several other government business enterprises. I would like to take this opportunity of congratulating Senator Evans for his stance on those matters-a stance which has received and which will continue to receive the full support of the Opposition. I can only hope and trust that he and his colleague the Prime Minister will be able to carry the day with them when they come to debate these matters in the smoke-filled rooms and, of course, the public auditoriums of the Labor Party biennial National Conference in the week beginning 6 June. I do have to say, however, that this consistency to which I referred in Senator Evans's case has not always been true in the case of the Prime Minister. It pains me to have to draw the attention of the Senate to some earlier views expressed by the Prime Minister. In fact, as recently as 23 May 1985, which is not so very long ago-less than three years ago-he said, when specifically referring to what was then Trans Australia Airlines, now Australian Airlines:

No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics, except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.

Those were the views of the Prime Minister in May 1985. Fortunately and naturally we welcome this change of mind, of heart or of political perception on the part of the Prime Minister in that he should now apparently believe, and be working assiduously to persuade his Party to believe, that it is now entirely desirable that Australian Airlines should be subjected to this Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try to destroy that authority by privatising it. We welcome the Prime Minister's conversion. Of course, from time to time one wishes that the Prime Minister would be more consistent in these matters.

Of course, we are assuming, having moved this amendment and having employed in it words spoken very recently by the Prime Minister himself, that when it comes to dividing the Senate on the amendment we shall receive the support on the affirmative side of the chamber of at least a substantial proportion of the Government senators who sit there. Naturally we are not so optimistic or unreal as to believe that we will receive the support of, say, Senator Childs and other members of the Left faction of the Australian Labor Party. However, we would expect to find an appreciable number of members of other factions of the Labor Party sitting with us on this amendment because, so we are assured, they too will be supporting their Prime Minister in his opinions as expressed in the amendment. Therefore, we very much trust that they will not confuse the public by voting against such an amendment on this occasion. The fact is that the Prime Minister's successive volte-faces on this subject-and, indeed, on a great many other subjects-have already confused the Australian public a great deal, so I suppose it would not be altogether surprising if Government senators opposite were to add just a touch more confusion to that which has already occurred in this respect.

I wish to reinforce my case, and the case put in the amendment, for the full privatisation of Australian Airlines by again bringing forward some recent remarks of the Prime Minister in support of that view. In fact, on the very same occasion on which the Prime Minister used the words contained in the amendment before the Senate, he also went on to discuss the matter more extensively. I hesitate to say it but the particular quote I put to the Senate now would have to be described as somewhat less than eloquent in the manner in which it is framed. Some less kindly persons than I might describe it as `Hawkespeak'. However that may be, the Prime Minister said:

I think there is a case, a very strong case, for arguing that given the demands that there are and will increasingly be on government, for instance in the provision of facilities and income for the aged, I find it difficult to justify as a matter of priority utilisation of scarce public resources to provide a funding base for running an airline as compared to the provision of those same resources for those things which I say only government can and ever will provide.

Again, I feel sure that, given that form of appeal to the sentiments of all factions of the Labor Party, perhaps with that addition, we might even be able to induce Left faction senators, such as Senator Childs, to at least consider their position on this matter. I am not holding my breath, but I think that would be not an unreasonable expectation.

The truth is that tonight we have, because of the nature of the Bill before us, a matter which rather pointedly serves to illustrate the total hypocrisy that the Labor Party has brought to this whole question of the treatment, standing, position and role of Australian Airlines in our community. Less than three years ago the Prime Minister was ranting-I think, in the context of the South Australian election; I am not absolutely certain about that but, if not, he certainly did so in that same connection-against any suggestion of the privatisation of Australian Government business enterprises. Here, for the past six months or so-ever since the last election-we have had the Prime Minister leading the charge to have these same bodies privatised. It is true that the charge has been a good deal blunted and rebuffed in more recent times by the forces gathering within the Labor Party against it and, of course, not least, in the aftermath of the recent defeat of the Labor Party in New South Wales and on a number of other more scattered electoral occasions. The truth is that we have had these extraordinary weathercock performances on the part of people such as the Prime Minister and others.

It is not only the Prime Minister who has been undergoing this extraordinary conversion. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) also has. It is true that the Treasurer has not been exactly eloquent in coming to the defence of the Prime Minister on this matter in recent times; nevertheless, he is known to be in favour of privatisation. It is simply that he has not found it politically convenient to make his views very fully or publicly available because, as now seems to be common knowledge-and it is common knowledge only because the Treasurer himself has made it such in several interviews-the Treasurer has his eye on the prime ministerial succession. Because he has his eye on the prime ministerial succession, he naturally seeks not to offend, at least unnecessarily, any more people in the parliamentary Labor Party Caucus then he needs to. So he has been lying doggo on this whole question of privatisation and on several other somewhat contentious questions. Nevertheless, he is known to be in favour of the privatisation of Australian Airlines-and I am sure I will not be contradicted in this assertion-which is being strongly proposed by the leader of his Government.

Yet the fact is that the Treasurer on previous occasions had made it very plain that he was totally opposed to such action. Take also the case of the Minister for Transport and Communications Support, Mr Peter Morris. When Mr Morris was last on the record on this matter in 1981-at that time the Labor Party was in Opposition-he said:
It is the policy of the Labor Party to ensure that TAA remains a 100 per cent government-owned enterprise.
In fact, Mr Morris went further at that time. He went on to say:
Converting TAA into a public company will simplify its sale and it meets the prime demands of this Government's-
that is, the then Fraser Government's-
backers, the multimillionaire proprietors of Ansett.

This statement was being made by a member of the House of Representatives who is now a Minister and who has since participated in, or has at least been a member of the Government which early this year actually participated in, a move to transform Australian Airlines into a public company-the very matter against which he was so strongly inveighing in 1981.

The fact of the matter is, of course, that Australian Airlines is desperately in need of privatisation. It is in need of it for all the very good reasons which the present Minister for Transport and Communications adduced in his recent Caucus discussion paper on the subject, which he circulated not only to his parliamentary colleagues but, by doing so, of course, more publicly. In that paper Senator Evans noted that Australian Airlines had had a net impact on the Budget since 1981-82 of about $115m in payments to the Budget, although no dividends had been paid since 1981-82. I think I am right in saying that a small one is expected in the current fiscal year.

Meanwhile, the debt to equity ratio of Australian Airlines has been deteriorating more or less consistently to the point where it is now in a rather grievous condition. It has certainly gone way beyond what the present management of the airline itself considers to be, and what I think disinterested and objective outside consultants would agree to be, an appropriate debt to equity ratio. What that means, as Senator Evans's paper tells us, is that to have the airline remain competitive, which will involve it in a significant-in fact, a major-re-equipment program involving very large capital sums, there will need to be an appropriate borrowing program. If there is to be an appropriate borrowing program and at the same time the current debt to equity ratio is to be repaired, there will have to be, from one source or another, very significant injections of equity capital into the balance sheet of Australian Airlines.

The figures which Senator Evans himself suggests as being required are $250m in the next financial year, 1988-89, and $50m in the following financial year, 1989-90. Of course, there are only two conceivable sources from which this can come. One is the Budget if Australian Airlines is to remain a wholly government owned public company-in other words, the taxpayer. The other would be private capital from the market if Australian Airlines were to be privatised. The position of this side of the chamber as between those two choices is quite clear. We are totally of the view that there is now only one satisfactory course to be adopted in the case of Australian Airlines, and that is to do what its own executives want done and what I think, increasingly, the general body of staff wants done-to put this airline into the private sector and give it a chance to compete.

We have a situation at present where not only the difficulties of the future capital requirements of Australian Airlines have become a significant hurdle in terms of the airline's performance but also its operations are continually being hamstrung by the restrictions which result from the fact that it is a government instrumentality, even though it is now a public company-a wholly owned government public company. There are restrictions on the remunerations of senior executives. After all, the airline has to compete in the private sector with Ansett Airlines of Australia, another very effective airline. It also has to participate in a non-commercial government superannuation scheme and, perhaps most importantly of all, when considering industrial relations questions it needs at all times to work under the umbrella and, I would say, under the dictate, of the increasingly depressing Department of Industrial Relations.

Our position on this matter will now, I hope, have been made perfectly clear. While we certainly do not oppose this amending Bill, we believe that the instrumentality, the change of status of which has brought about the need for this Bill, has problems that go far beyond its capacity to borrow or not to borrow with a government guarantee and that those problems can be addressed only by privatising that once proud, and I hope still proud, company, Australian Airlines, to give it a chance to survive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill 1988 imposes, as Senator Stone has already pointed out, a levy on borrowings by a public enterprise-in this case Australian Airlines. It does this, as do other Commonwealth borrowing levy amendment Bills, partly as an acknowledgment that government authorities and public enterprises are able to borrow more cheaply than other institutions and, in particular, private sector bodies, because statutory authorities and public enterprises are government guaranteed. So, without a levy imposed in this way, it could be argued that organisations and enterprises such as Australian Airlines or statutory authorities have an unfair advantage over private sector borrowers. The Government imposes a levy of a percentage point or two-it is rarely more than that-to ensure that this interest rate advantage is offset and that statutory authorities and private enterprises do not compete unfairly with private sector borrowers on the open market.

SPEECH.PARA: All of that is fair enough. All sides of the Senate support such a mechanism because it makes for equity and fairness in the borrowing area. Given the Opposition's keenness to see the deficit transferred into surplus, however small, I find the amendment moved by Senator Stone rather extraordinary. His amendment, which proposes an attachment to the second reading motion, reads as follows:

. . . but the Senate endorses the sale of Australian Airlines, and therefore supports the Prime Minister's statement that `I believe that an Australian Airlines, whether totally in private hands or an Australian Airlines with a significant private holding, with therefore correspondingly diminished demands upon public resources, could perform the function of Australian Airlines at least as well as they are now and, I would say, arguably, better'.

This is a typical tortuous piece of Hawkespeak. Nevertheless, it is an endorsement for privatising Australian Airlines, an endorsement of an action enthusiastically supported by the Opposition parties. This conflicts, of course, with earlier statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that I will refer to in a minute. It also, I would suggest, conflicts somewhat with commonsense. At the moment, as both Senator Stone and I have pointed out, the reason that a levy is imposed on enterprises such as Australian Airlines is that they are able to borrow at a smaller interest rate. A levy is thereby imposed in order to offset any unfair advantage over the private sector, whose borrowings are at a higher interest rate level. The revenue from the levy goes into Consolidated Revenue and the government-guaranteed organisation borrows at a smaller interest rate than a private sector organisation in a similar position would be able to do.

If Australian Airlines is privatised, future borrowings by that company as a private company will no longer be guaranteed by the government. Therefore, borrowings will not be able to be made at the lower interest rates that Australian Airlines and other government guaranteed organisations are able to borrow at. So there will be an increased cost to the consumer and, presumably, increased fares and so on charged by the company once it has gone private. Worse, however, as happens with all borrowings by the private sector, the interest repayments will be tax deductible; in other words, negative gearing will apply because the borrower is in the private sector. That means there will be a considerable cost to taxpayers who are essentially subsidising the borrowers in the private sector and, therefore, there will be a considerable cost to Consolidated Revenue. Clearly, the Opposition has to make up its mind what its priorities are. Either it wants a Budget surplus or it wants public enterprises such as Australian Airlines privatised, and at a cost to the taxpayer, even though organisations such as Australian Airlines are making a profit and, as a consequence, are revenue-raising concerns.

Senator Stone justifies his amendment by quoting recent comments by the Prime Minister, namely, as I said a moment ago, his belief that an Australian airline, whether totally in private hands or with a significant private holding, could do as well as, if not better than, Australian Airlines does currently as a public company. Senator Stone picked up some recent comments by the Prime Minister. That was not particularly surprising because the Prime Minister is moving about as far to the right as it is possible to go without actually bumping into Senator Stone. So it is quite likely that there will be increasing areas of agreement between those two individuals. I do not know who feels the more uncomfortable about that-Senator Stone or the Prime Minister-but I suspect that it ought to be the Prime Minister since he is the one making the shift voluntarily.

TALK.START.PARA: —There must be a conspiracy somewhere, I am sure.

—I do not know, Senator. Around this place, if it is a choice between a conspiracy and an absolute muck-up, one goes for the muck-up. That is certainly what would happen if we privatised willy-nilly in the way that some Opposition people would have us think is justified. Not surprisingly, therefore, the Australian Democrats will be opposing Senator Stone's amendment.
—I thought you always agreed with the Prime Minister.

—I ask Senator Stone to cast his mind back to last year when he first became a member of this place and was absolutely astonished at the number of times we actually voted with him. I can recall sitting next to him on many occasions in divisions. In September last year both of us became embarrassed about it. If he is at a loss to remember, I suggest that he go back and look how we all behaved on the Loans Bill for a start. I have recollections of Senator Stone expressing absolute amazement, not to say admiration, at the fact that we supported his stance on the Loans Bill. But at the moment on more and more occasions the Opposition parties are supporting Australian Labor Party legislation and we are seeing, increasingly, the shifting position of the Prime Minister on things such as privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: We will not support the amendment because we are much more in tune with earlier comments by the Prime Minister and others regarding the pitfalls of privatisation, comments to which I refer honourable senators who are at all interested in finding out what the Prime Minister used to think, or said he used to think, as distinct from what he is saying at the moment. I do not know whether this falls into the same category as `there will be no child in poverty in 1990'-that is, he actually said it but did not mean it when he said it-whether we all misinterpreted him, or whether his use of the words is somewhat different from everybody else's. In any event, back in 1985, in an article in the Melbourne Herald of 29 August headed `A con that benefits corporate raiders', the Prime Minister said, among other things:
The reality is that privatisation is a con job-it purports to sell to the people something that is already their own.
Privatisation will see profitable areas of government activity transferred to wealthy private shareholders. Taxpayers will be left subsidising the loss-making activities of government.

Privatisation will not lead to lower taxation. In the main, government corporations are financed by selling their services. Privatisation, by contrast, would probably see a lift in taxes as the Government would be forced into subsidising uneconomic services. It is especially shortsighted to give up future dividends and interest flows in return for a one-off realisation of capital sums now.

The fact of the matter is that privatisation is an entirely inappropriate approach to the social, economic and community needs of a country such as Australia. It is an approach promoted by vested interests, sustained by blinkered ideological obsessions and entirely lacking in logic and commonsense.

The Prime Minister has had a change of heart in the 2 1/2 years since then and now argues that privatising Australian Airlines will mean that the service provided will be at least as good and, he says, arguably better. I am afraid that we do not subscribe to the Opposition's variation on the comments in Orwell's Animal Farm. We do not accept that in every instance private enterprise is good and public enterprise is bad. I think that we have to weigh up the merits in each case. We have to look at the service that is provided, the costing of that service, the cost to the taxpayer of variations in the service, the cost if the service is provided by the government sector and the cost if it is provided by the private sector.

There are costs to the taxpayer from services provided by the private sector. More importantly, in a country the size of Australia, with the population spread of Australia, when it comes to services such as airlines, communications-through Telecom Australia and Australia Post-and so on, we need to look at what likely diminution in service there is if only the private sector provides those services. We need to remember that the main aim of the private sector is to provide the maximum return to shareholders. If that means leaving certain groups in the community in isolation, charging them more than others, that is precisely what the private sector does. It does so by justifying itself with the argument that I have just put-that is, its priority commitment is to its shareholders. An Australian government of any persuasion must have as its priority commitment the appropriate, adequate and good servicing of all Australians. If that means cross subsidisation and forcing the private sector to provide services to rural Australia, to isolated Australians, and so on, that is something that we have to accept and be prepared to pay the costs of.

A successful private enterprise of the sort that Australian Airlines is can ensure competition and the provision of adequate, appropriate and affordable services to everyone-not just those that private sector enterprises believe are the most profitable. I suggest that anybody who is a promoter of wholesale privatisation consider that we are not a country such as the United States whose population is large enough and densely enough packed to be able to have a plethora of private organisations providing the sort of competition that can keep prices down. In instances such as Australian Airlines it is necessary to have a government competitor, a public enterprise competitor, there keeping the private sector on its toes and on the straight and narrow and providing the services that Australians need and deserve at prices that everyone can afford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. I have not followed some of the earlier sections of the debate with great diligence. SPEECH.PARA: I know that sometimes annoys the conservatives of politics, who say that the decisions should be made only by the people's representatives as elected to the national Parliament.
