DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 March, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980 to incorporate in the Act the tariff proposal tabled as part of the 1987-88 Budget. The coalition will not oppose the Bill as it results from a decision made in the Budget context. However the coalition will be moving an amendment at the second reading stage

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill increases the export duty on uranium concentrate produced from the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram as from 15 September 1987. The proposed new rate will cover approximately 75 per cent of the annual cost of the uranium related monitoring and research activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) for the Alligator Rivers region. The mining industry is totally opposed to this levy which significantly adds to export costs and the industry in general fears that the principle in this Bill could be extended in future to other forms of mining.

The 75 per cent funding of the OSS through this Bill is discriminatory and is funding an office which seems to be based on Parkinson's law. There is no quarrel with the establishment of the Office of Supervising Scientist. It was an initiative of the Fraser Government in 1978 to implement the recommendations of the Ranger uranium environmental inquiries to establish a major national park in the Alligator Rivers region; to appoint a supervising scientist to coordinate environmental protection in the region; to set up a research institute to provide a centre where research and monitoring staff can work together; to establish a coordinating committee to include representatives of all agencies involved in research and monitoring activities, the mining industry and other relevant bodies; to develop a uniform national code of practice to apply to uranium mining and milling in Australia; and to adopt strict environmental controls and standards in relation to uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region.

That was 10 years ago. I must say that I am disappointed that Senator Walsh is not the Minister on duty in the chamber at present because I am sure he would take a great interest in the matters that I am about to raise. But, as I was saying, this Office was established 10 years ago when the Ranger commissioners decided that a completely different outlook to mining company proposals was needed. They found that the following were largely unknown: first, the final type of concentration and chemical form of mine pollutants in the environment; secondly, changes in toxicity with time or place; thirdly, sensitivity of the environment to toxic substances; and, fourthly, effects of other non-toxic factors such as eutrophication.

Now we are 10 years down the track and the office has grown and grown, despite being cut back by the Fraser Government's razor gang and on two occasions by this Government. It would seem that it is far easier for governments of both persuasions to provide funds for the OSS than it is to explain to the people the simple truths about uranium-in particular, the simple truth that we export uranium for the purpose of generating electricity. It would, of course, be much better if we enriched our uranium and exported the enriched product. That would discourage other nations which buy our fuel from building costly enrichment plants that might later be utilised for enrichment to nuclear weapon levels. Instead, a large proportion of our yellowcake is exported to Canada, where it is enriched and then exported to other destinations. Canada, of course, has no need for our uranium, being rich in this resource.

Now back to the Office of the Supervising Scientist. At 30 June 1979 there was a permanent staff of 14 with six additional positions to be filled, making a total of 20. The Department of Science and the Environment provided management services and the scientific work was being carried out almost entirely by contract. According to the 1986-87 annual report of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, the actual staff numbers at 30 June 1987 were 58 permanent officers and 11 temporary employees, after having been exposed to a 15 per cent cut over two years. However, because of the implications of OSS involvement in the newly proclaimed conservation zone, Kakadu stage 3, the office was provided with one more staff member in the 1986-87 Additional Estimates and sought a further eight staff for 1987-88. At 30 June 1987, 41.5 staff were based at Jabiru, 26.2 in Sydney and one in Darwin, a total of 68.7 persons. I hope Senator Walsh is listening.

The decision to base the Supervising Scientist, Policy and Administration Division, Supervisory and Assessment Branch, Policy Co-ordination Branch and Management Services Branch, in Sydney may have been argued on the grounds that the management services of the Department of Science and the Environment were utilised and the Northern Territory lacked tertiary institutions. In other words, what I am saying is that this could have been the argument in 1979, under the Fraser Government, for setting up the office in Sydney. But the simple truth is that the reason that the office was set up in Sydney was that the first Supervising Scientist, Mr Fry, wanted to remain in Sydney-so the office was established in Sydney and has remained there ever since. Whatever the merits of the case at that time, that argument that the office remain in Sydney can no longer be sustained. The Northern Territory now has a university college, self-government and a Minister for Mines and Energy.

The 1986-87 annual report of the OSS indicates the need for staff regularly to liaise with the Northern Territory supervising authority on matters related to the formulation of authorisations, industrial health and safety and environmental protection measures and with the Northern Land Council. In addition, Sydney based staff visit Darwin and the region on an approximately monthly basis arranged to coincide with meetings of one or other of a number of standing or ad hoc committees and working groups that meet regularly in the Northern Territory. It is clear that the administration should now be Darwin based. This would result in substantial savings in travel and administrative costs alone. In addition, there is clearly an opportunity for the University College of the Northern Territory to be closely involved, probably on a contract basis, in providing many of the operational and administrative services currently provided by the Alligator Rivers Research Institute.

On 28 October 1981 the Fraser Government's Minister for Home Affairs, the Hon. Ian Wilson, supported moves to the Northern Territory and made it clear that government moves to hand control of nuclear regulation to the States and Northern Territory `did not in any way reduce its level of commitment to ensuring the most comprehensive and effective regulations and controls with respect to all matters regarding the uranium and nuclear industries'. In other words, under self-government the Northern Territory can look after this matter, as can Queensland, Western Australia or any other State government, with the Commonwealth still having supervisory overall control. Northern Territory law regulates mining operations in the Alligator Rivers region and the Supervising Scientist exercises supervisory, coordinating, research, standards development and reporting roles under Commonwealth law.

The role of the Supervising Scientist should, of course, have diminished over the 10 years as the unknowns have been resolved. There were many unknowns when this position was established, but most have been resolved. Some of his original functions, such as standards development, should have been firmly established and others become merely routine. If this is not so, the Supervising Scientist has not been doing his job-and I do not suggest that he has not been doing his job.

Also, it should now be possible for the Office of the Supervising Scientist to determine whether all of the original recommendations of the Ranger commissioners remain valid. Furthermore, there is need for a review to ensure there is no duplication between departments of the Northern Territory Government and the OSS. If the Sydney Office was moved to Darwin, there should be a significant reduction in administrative costs. A review such as I have suggested should be carried out by an independent consultant charged with merging as many functions as possible with Northern Territory agencies and tertiary institutions while retaining the integrity and legitimate purpose of the OSS. I repeat that we are not talking about doing away with the Office of the Supervising Scientist, but of retaining the integrity and legitimate purposes of that Office.

I now turn to the subject of research. The 1986-87 annual report details some 52 publications, papers and monographs, papers to conferences and symposia, reports and papers to conferences and symposia. That number raises the question of national priorities in scientific research. This issue has been consistently raised by Senator Puplick in Senate Estimates committees. The integrity and dedication of the scientists in the Office of the Supervising Scientist are not in question. In no way do I make any comments about their integrity and their dedication. That is not what I am about to talk about. What I do raise is the question of the priorities of their research, considering the limited funds that are available in Australia for scientific research. Some of the research seems to be peripheral to the Office. I point, for example, to research in the following fields: a simple model for rapidly computing terrestrial solar flux and global mean surface temperature--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that again?

—Don't worry about that one. Let us take the next one: sexual differences in morphology and niche utilisation in an aquatic snake. Another piece of research relates to food habits, habitats and reproductive biology of four sympatric species of varanid lizards in tropical Australia. It is clear that what is happening is that people who are in the Office have these matters that they can see are related in some way or other to the Office, and no doubt from time to time they have spare time while they are doing their duties perhaps up at Jabiru to go on and do this sort of research.
—The trouble is they spend all their time in Sydney.

—Well, Senator Crichton-Browne, they probably spend too much time in Sydney, too-I do not know. But in any event it is clear that they must have some time to devote to these matters. We question whether their research merits the national priority it is accorded through current funding arrangements. The question is whether that decision that is-the national priority of their research-should rest with the Office of the Supervising Scientist, as it does at present, or with the Australian Research Council, which is the national body responsible for overall national research priorities. In many respects these scientists are, or should be, firemen whose function should be to deal with any emergency that arises in this regard. When not on alert, clearly there is the opportunity for them to carry out other research, but that must be secondary to their primary role. These issues all indicate that the Office of the Supervising Scientist clearly needs to be reviewed by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the levy. It is clear from Senator Gareth Evans's statement that uranium can already be purchased more cheaply from other sources. Thus, the introduction of an increased levy is an astonishing additional burden to impose on our uranium exporters at a time when they are attempting to compete in a buyers' market. The Liberal and National parties are very concerned about this substantial increase in the levy, an increase of about 25 per cent, and we probably would have opposed this Bill but the Government brought it in as part of the Budget measures. Therefore, in accordance with our principles, we will not oppose it. But I move the following amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Hawke Government should be condemned:

(a) for its failure to limit the role, the duties and the accountability of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the light of 10 years' experience in its monitoring of the Alligator Rivers region, the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory and the establishment of the University College of the Northern Territory; and
(b) for the imposition of this additional levy on uranium at a time when Australian uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive on world markets''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill proposes, as Senator Lewis has indicated, an increase from 80c to $1.02 in the duty payable by uranium miners operating in the Alligator Rivers region, the purpose of which duty is to support the Office of the Supervising Scientist. That Office monitors before, during and after the operation of uranium mines in that region to ensure that that absolutely superb World Heritage area is not damaged and is left in as good a state as possible. Senator Lewis has also correctly pointed out that the Office of the Supervising Scientist was established as a result of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry in the 1975-76 era, the commission headed by Mr Justice Fox, which recommended that such an office be established.

SPEECH.PARA: We have abundant evidence in Australia that uranium mining carried on elsewhere and other operations associated with that mining have resulted in very serious environmental damage of a long term nature and that that may continue for many decades-and we already have experience of this-after the operation has been completed. The purpose of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill, as explained by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), is to bring the levy up to 75 per cent of the costs of the operation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. It is surprising to hear Senator Lewis-and presumably the Government, because it has put up this Bill-argue that in this respect the user should not pay and that 25 per cent of the cost should be borne by the general public. In a moment I shall move an amendment, which I believe has been circulated, proposing that the duty payable be increased to cover the full costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, and that would be up to a level of $1.36 per kilogram. That is justified, as Senator Stone has pointed out several times in recent days, on the grounds of producing a level playing field; and, as both the Opposition and the Government have pointed out repeatedly, the user should pay and the market should be allowed to operate. Let the market operate and let those who choose to mine in an extremely sensitive environmental area, namely, in the middle of a World Heritage park, pay the full cost and compete with those who choose to mine uranium somewhere else in Australia, in an area which does not involve that necessary protection.

In defence of paying only the 75 per cent it may be argued, of course, that the Office of the Supervising Scientist has carried out other work, and I think that Senator Lewis alluded to some other projects. One can instance the proposal by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to mine gold at Coronation Hill. It is doubtful whether that operation will get off the ground. One hopes that it will not, because it is upstream of the important parts of the surrounding park and, therefore, is in a potentially very dangerous area in relation to contamination. If it does not get off the ground, clearly no fee can be charged against the production from that operation. Moreover, the Office of the Supervising Scientist came into existence as a direct consequence of the proposal to mine uranium, which was later brought into operation. Clearly, that is where the basic maintenance of the cost should fall. If other mines were to be established, they should be looked on as a bonus and perhaps further down the track some adjustment might be made.

Senator Lewis has also alluded to work which may be carried out by the University of the Northern Territory. We are aware, of course, that much work in the Alligator Rivers Region has been carried out by the Northern Division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. However, to the extent that that work relieves the Office of the Supervising Scientist of work which would have to be done in relation to potential contamination from uranium mining, that cost is being borne by the public and should be picked up by the Office of the Supervising Scientist. This duty is charged only against the year on year returns from uranium mining. In our proposal it is $1.36 per kilogram of uranium that is mined and exported. At the point when uranium mining ceases that money will simply disappear. As I have already mentioned, a number of former uranium mines and treatment plants around Australia have involved the public in enormous expense. Last year the Government had to set aside $7m in relation to contamination of the Finniss River from the mining of uranium at Rum Jungle, which ceased some 30 years ago. That is a continuing drain on the public purse, so to ask for $1.36 per kilogram year on year, bearing in mind that no money will be flowing into the Office of the Supervising Scientist when uranium mining ceases, is surely little enough to ask, because quite clearly that Office will have to continue for many years into the future, not the least simply to look after the massive tailings dams which have been built in the area and which, one hopes, will not leak into Magela Creek and other waterways-but one can never be too certain of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has leaked.

—Senator Sanders has just pointed out to me that it has already leaked. That brings into disrepute another point that Senator Lewis made when he said that all the unknowns should be resolved. I take it from Senator Lewis's remarks that he has never worked in a research laboratory and has very little idea of the way in which this research needs to be conducted. In pointing to the measurement of solar flux, he presumably has no understanding of the way in which solar flux relates to water evaporation and, therefore, to the size of the tailings ponds; the maintenance of levels of water over the tailings so that radon gas does not escape; the problem of flood return times; and the suggested need from time to time to release water from tailings ponds and from other areas.
—I would be careful about what you presume about the knowledge of any senator in this place.

—In Senator Lewis's questioning of some of the research projects that have been carried out by the Office of the Supervising Scientist the implication seemed absolutely clear that he was saying that it was no business of the Supervising Scientist to get involved in that type of research.
—You ought to read what I said then; I suggest that you read the Hansard.

—That was the clear implication. In terms of the breeding habits of various animals-lizards and so on-that exist in that area, I again remind the Senate that we are talking about a World Heritage area, an area which is recognisably one of the few places in the world that are still in pretty much a pristine state but which has a very large uranium mine slap bang in the middle of it. That is a very good reason why we need to know a great deal about the breeding habits of animals in that region, especially when we know that radiation is a known mutagenic agent. It was discovered in 1928 that radiation caused mutation and could clearly interfere with the breeding habits of animals. Those animals that are having great difficulty in maintaining themselves in a changing environment might well be pushed over the edge if the mutation rate were to significantly change.

SPEECH.PARA: There was also in what Senator Lewis said an implication that reports to international symposia were somehow beyond the pale and that these were things that the Office of the Supervising Scientist should not be involved with. We know that the uranium we send overseas goes into a nuclear fuel cycle which produces very long lived isotopes. Indeed, in mining we have the exhuming of deeply buried radioactive ores which are brought up to the surface and which then cause significant increases in radiation levels in the atmosphere. Thus, it is vitally important that we properly understand the role of these radiation sources in relation to a whole range of living things, and we have a distinct responsibility to share this knowledge with people around the world. It is entirely appropriate that the Office of the Supervising Scientist should go to other countries and share this knowledge with others.

As I have indicated, the Democrats propose an amendment to increase the duty payable, not from 80c to $1.02 but to $1.36, to cover the full costs associated with maintaining the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Because of the way that this Bill is worded, namely that the increase from 80c to $1.02 is effective from 15 September 1987-and presumably as this was mentioned in the Budget the uranium miners have been forewarned that this extra duty will be levied when the Bill becomes law-and because we propose an increase in the levy to a higher amount it is necessary as a consequence of our amendment to move a further amendment so that the second increase, the increase that we are recommending, is not made retrospective to 15 September but, if our amendment is accepted, is made prospective to the date on which the Bill receives royal assent.

Finally, we are really looking at quite a small amount if we take a floor price of $31 per pound which works out at $A91 a kilogram. So at $1.36 it is 1.5 per cent duty on the uranium mined in this very sensitive environmental area simply to look after and retain without damage the pristine nature of the Kakadu National Park. I note the second part of Senator Lewis's proposed amendment which states:
. . . for the imposition of this additional levy on uranium at a time when Australian uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive on world markets.''

We have debated in this place very often the fact that we cannot maintain safeguards and prices at the same time. If the state of the uranium market is so parlous that the imposition of a 1.5 per cent levy to look after the environment places the industry in jeopardy, the Democrats would suggest that it is not an industry that this nation should support. If, on the other hand, it is the buoyant, magnificently productive industry which is bringing in the foreign exchange that both the Opposition and the Government have been telling us about for so long, no one can complain that a 1.5 per cent levy is too much for the industry to pay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are addressing the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill and several amendments proposed by honourable senators. I strongly support the amendment moved by Senator Lewis this evening and also draw the Senate's attention to the debate in the House of Representatives on 25 February and, in particular, the contribution by the shadow Minister for Science and Energy, the honourable member for Bass, Warwick Smith. He made a thoughtful and thought provoking contribution to the debate, very much in contrast with the rather boring diatribe that we have just had from Senator Coulter. I also draw attention to the debate in the House of Representatives on 15 March and the contribution by the member for Sturt, the Hon. Ian Wilson, who, as a Fraser Government Minister, was responsible for the early introduction of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the very important role that it has played.

SPEECH.PARA: I will address the specifics of Senator Lewis's amendment a little later in the debate, but at this stage I express my surprise at the blatantly political and uncaring move of the Australian Democrats this evening with respect to their proposed amendment. Anyone would think that the Australian Democrats were destined to take the front benches in executive government in Australia. Lord preserve us! What an ultra contradiction that is. They are in no way entitled to look at how the Budget should be framed through the eyes of the Executive. The effect of their amendment is a blatant move to increase the contribution from mining companies. Of course, this comes at a time when mining companies are experiencing financial constraints and financial difficulties like so many areas of the community. Basically, the Democrats are seeking to increase the burden on mining companies when this struggle is going on, and that means that it will cost jobs in the community. Of course, the Democrats can afford to be open and honest in their policies because they do not believe in jobs. Their amendment to this Bill backs up their recent record in this place.

Who else should feel threatened by the Democrats move tonight? I would say that the research establishment in Australia will recoil completely from moves of this nature which would, wherever feasible, switch all of the costs into the research areas. Senator Coulter has just said that he wants to see 100 per cent funding by the mining companies of the research cost-just because it happens to be in the uranium province and because it is easy to dip into the tin if there is a bit more in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It happens to be in a World Heritage area.

—I am not denying the significance of Kakadu or the World Heritage area or the importance of the research projects going on in that area. If we look at what this legislation will do, it is most important to recognise that the facts and figures bear out that there is extensive funding of the projects of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. In fact, 75 per cent of the annual cost is being raised through these Budget measures. The Kakadu area and its geography is very significant to the Northern Territory, to Australia and the world and it is an area that is well worth preserving. The important functions and roles being fulfilled are in no way detracted from by what is going on. However, the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist must be put in its proper context.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the original five functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The first is to carry out research into the effects of uranium and other mining operations on the environment of the Alligator Rivers region-research within a narrow frame into the effects of mining in that region. The second is to supervise the implementation of the Commonwealth's environmental requirements and others. The third is to develop and promote standards, procedures and measures for the protection and restoration of the environment from the effect of mining operations. The fourth is to coordinate environment protection, research and supervisory activities relating to the uranium mining industry in the region. The fifth is to advise the Minister on these matters. So research, supervision, monitoring and coordination are the keys to projects in this area.

We are 10 years down the line and we have accumulated 10 years of experience in this area. In that time a number of other significant events have also happened. One of those, of course, is the progress of the Northern Territory towards statehood; the progress to self-government of a body politic in the Northern Territory. The success of that body politic, particularly in the area of mining, whether it is in research or operations, or in education, whether in research or in the community advancement, is something that we ought to be properly reviewing and putting into the context of federalism and the system in which we operate. It is therefore vitally important that the Northern Territory's role and involvement be picked up and looked at.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist, as a Federal Government instrumentality, is the issue that ought to be under review. In fact, I would go much further than saying that we ought just to be reviewing the research functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. There are many other institutes that should be looked at in the same context. There are many others in the same department. For example, what functions currently carried out by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the North Australian Research Unit of the Australian National University, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and many other academic institutions around Australia, should be reviewed and looked at in the context in which they ought very properly to be looked at-as Mr Smith and Senator Lewis said, under the umbrella of the new University College of the Northern Territory? That is the appropriate body, and given the Government's intention of moving in the area of higher education advancement policies in the very near future, it is timely that we call for this review now.

It is timely that the institution that should have the control ought to be the new University College of the Northern Territory. It needs to be looked at under the education umbrella. It needs to be looked at under the proper governmental functions of the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. There is no need to have arm's length and remote groups operating from headquarters in Bondi controlling the destiny of the Northern Territory, particularly in functional areas that apply more properly in this regard.

I believe that if honourable senators took the time to go up and talk very closely to Aboriginals with specific interests in this area, they would find that there is a great deal of sympathy for the fact that it is the Northern Territory Government that they talk to most frequently, with which they enjoy the financial and close working relationships on a day to day basis. They would be very happy to see the sort of changes that have been proposed by Mr Smith, Senator Lewis and me.

In the House of Representatives the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones, said in responding to the debate there that he was looking at the Bondi functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. He pointed out that the staff there carried out the vital computer and mathematical modelling and other administrative functions which could not be done on site. They certainly could be done in the Northern Territory. They do not need to be done in Bondi, at remote arm's length. If one looks at the last annual report, for 1986-87, of the Supervising Scientist and progresses through the report, particularly in the area of research programs, one will see many of these projects listed. I will cover each of the areas. There is the aquatic biology research program, the environmental radioactivity research program, the environmental modelling research program, the environmental chemistry research program, the plant ecology research program, the geomorphology research program and a proposed hydrology research program. All of those programs are currently under way in the Northern Territory in other proper Territory government instrumentalities, either departments or institutes. They do not have to be duplicated. They certainly do not have to be duplicated by a central, controlled office, from Canberra. The coordination that must go on, the administrative inflexibility that must result, and the additional financing that has to come through the Federal Budget, make for a complex web of issues and laws.

This evening I am certainly arguing very strongly from a parochial and Northern Territory standpoint, because the uranium industry, and in fact anything to do with nuclear policy in Australia, needs to be put in the proper context of how it should be administered. That is a co-operative arrangement between the State governments, in this case the Territory Government, and the Commonwealth Government. There is a time for review after 10 years. I would argue that that time is now. It is in fact picked up in Senator Lewis's amendment. If we are looking to the future, no matter whether it is this year, next year, or 10 years or 20 years from now, control will inevitably be by the Northern Territory Government. That is where appropriately it should be. The sooner we can get to that position the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard some debate on this issue. We have heard the Opposition, through Senator Lewis, state that the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) should actually be reduced because it has been in action for 10 years and therefore should presumably have learnt all there is to know about uranium mining at Ranger and in the Kakadu National Park. In fact, of course the Office of the Supervising Scientist is still needed. In essence uranium mining is a very new type of mining. We have had coal mining, copper mining and iron mining for a very long time. Uranium mining is entirely new. It is entirely confined to our century. We know very little about the overall result of uranium mining on any environmental system. We find more and more impacts-impacts that we never predicted or were never foreseen. Therefore, the Office of the Supervising Scientist is very justified not only in maintaining its efforts but in increasing its efforts and following leads, any leads, which would be indicated in dealing with the environmental problems of uranium mining.

SPEECH.PARA: Ranger has had a number of difficulties in the past years-difficulties that were not predicted at all; difficulties in the release of water and the amount of water it had in the first place. It actually stored water in the early days because of miscalculation of the amount of rainfall and how much water problem it would actually have. Now, of course, that stored water has become an embarrassment. Ranger has to keep it in dams and transfer it from one pit to another in order to mine. It has made mistakes; it continues to make mistakes. Therefore, the Office of the Supervising Scientist, instead of having its operations curtailed, should actually have its operations expanded.

Senator Lewis fails to see the value of basic research. Basic research is valuable in itself. We cannot predict the results of basic research. As Senator Coulter has pointed out, when one goes into an area as sensitive as Kakadu National Park one must know the environmental parameters. We do not know them. We have never identified them. We must identify them in terms of the breeding habits of snakes, the solar flux, and any number of factors. We must know these things. Senator Lewis said that the role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist should be that of a fireman. Those were his exact words. In other words the OSS should run, after a disaster has already started, to try to stop the disaster. It should put out the fire. This is not good enough with uranium. It is really not good enough with anything. Any fireman will tell us that the best type of fire fighting is to prevent the fire in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree.
—Senator Lewis agrees with that.
—That is what being a fireman is.

—That is what being a fireman is. The Office of the Supervising Scientist must identify the dangers and stop the disasters before they occur. In order to do this the OSS must engage in basic research. Perhaps Senator Lewis agrees with this. Perhaps we have misinterpreted his statement. I hope he does agree. The OSS should actually prevent the fires. It should not be called in to put out the fires after they have already started.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling has criticised our amendment for suggesting that the full costs of the Office of the Supervising Scientist should be paid by the uranium miners. He said that this was a blatant move to increase the burden on mining companies. Blatant? I do not think it is blatant; I think it is necessary and logical. After all, these mining companies are making a profit on their activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is blatantly necessary and logical. It is a blatant, discrete, overt charge.

—The Minister says it is a blatant, discrete, overt charge. I will have to investigate that with my thesaurus later. It is blatant, it is obvious and it is necessary. I believe in cost recovery. I think that both the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia believe in cost recovery so I am somewhat puzzled at this approach of Senator Tambling that there should not be full cost recovery. The mining companies are benefiting from the activities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, and in any other country they would be required to do this research themselves. Certainly that would be the case in the United States of America, as it would be in most other parts of the world. The companies are benefiting. The OSS activities are of benefit to their commercial operations so they should pay the full cost of operating the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

SPEECH.PARA: In amongst all this came the gratuitous charge that the Australian Democrats were anti jobs. We are not anti jobs, we are pro future. We are pro future employment, we are pro future environmental opportunities for our kids; we want the world to be livable in the future. If some jobs prove to be hazardous to our future occupation of this earth then we are anti those jobs, but basically we want to see workers engaged in productive and healthy pursuits. We are not anti jobs; we are anti destruction.

Senator Tambling said that research areas would suffer because of this levy. How can a research area suffer because of an increased amount of funding? One of the tragedies in Australia is the lack of funding for research, the lack of availability of funds. Of all the developed countries Australia is at the bottom in the amount of money spent on basic research. We still have a cultural cringe. We still expect other people to do our research for us. As long as we do that we will never be a first rate nation. We must have the confidence in ourselves to utilise our skills in research for our own wellbeing. When I was in the aerospace industry in the United States I was amazed at the number of Australian engineers who were my co-workers. I thought that Australia must be full of great engineers if it could afford to send so many overseas. But of course the answer is that Australian engineers must go overseas because that is where the grants are. In Australia we simply do not fund our basic research. So how can Senator Tambling say that an increased levy on a uranium company will cause research areas to suffer? That is a nonsense.

Senator Tambling also made a plea for Northern Territory involvement. I would be happy to see the Northern Territory have more involvement if it were a positive involvement. Over the years that I have watched what is happening in the Northern Territory I have found that the Northern Territory approach is to support the mining industry at the expense of the environment. I do not think that kind of involvement would be at all productive.

I turn to the amendment moved by Senator Lewis. The Australian Democrats will not support it because of its avowed intention to limit the role, the duties and accountability of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. As I said earlier, we feel that the OSS is performing a very necessary function and should continue to do so. Senator Lewis echoed Senator Tambling's concern about the imposition of this additional levy on uranium at a time when Australian uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive on world markets. Well, so what? Why should not the uranium producers pay the costs of their operations? Why not? If they are struggling on world markets, as Senator Coulter says, perhaps they are not a viable commercial operation anyway. Is it not the policy of the Labor Party and the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen the annual report of ERA?
—Senator Collins refers me to the annual report of Energy Resources of Australia. I have not had the opportunity to see it.
—It is a viable industry.
—Senator Collins assures me that it is a viable industry. If that is so, it can certainly afford the levy.
—I agree.
—Senator Collins agrees and he has a detailed knowledge of the area. Perhaps he and Senator Tambling are at odds in this matter.
—That is right; we are.

—Senator Collins says that they are. So, the mining companies can pay the costs and I think they should do so. I would like to expand this in the area of Kakadu. It is not really reasonable that uranium miners should bear the total cost of running the Office of the Supervising Scientist, given that Office's new responsibilities to supervise gold mining in stage 3 of Kakadu. It would be reasonable only if in fact they also paid a levy in response to the gold mining in stage 3 of Kakadu at Coronation Hill. Will this happen? Will the Government also charge a levy in relation to gold mining? The OSS has been asked to supervise that as well. Gold mining at Coronation Hill can be just as environmentally hazardous to the headwaters of the Alligator River as uranium mining at Ranger is to Magela Creek. I feel that both uranium and gold miners should be required to meet all the infrastructure costs of uranium and gold mining-not only the costs to the Office of the Supervising Scientist but also the infrastructure costs. Why should the taxpayers of Australia pay for infrastructure, roads and all the costs of managing these areas? Why should the mining companies not pay for this? Under the total cost recovery schemes of the Liberal and National parties this would certainly be logical. The proposed mines at Coronation Hill will involve the expenditure of huge sums of taxpayers' money for bridges, roads and other infrastructure. This is particularly important in the case of gold because no tax is paid on it. Therefore the recovery of the levy should be extended to the gold miners at Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: No work has been done to protect the environment as a result of the new mine. There have been no cost benefit studies and no socio-economic studies. We are operating in the dark. Perhaps this is something the OSS could look at, at least in part. The Government and Coronation Hill are accepting the word of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) about the value of gold without any independent assessment. BHP has refused to give the Bureau of Mineral Resources any access in order to verify the results at Coronation Hill. The situation is completely unacceptable because of the risks to the environment and the potential economic damage to the tourist industry. Mining should not be allowed to proceed.

Another difficulty at Coronation Hill involves uranium. There is uranium there. From our information and from that of the OSS, there is a major uranium ore body there. The Government has denied this in this chamber, but in fact it does exist. This is an embarrassment for the Government because uranium has to be mined as an adjunct to gold and this will thus impinge on the Government's three-mine policy. So this is a problem for the Government.

We have a number of factors involved in the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill. We have the Office of the Supervising Scientist; we have the environment itself; and we have the need to protect the environment. The environment of the area is very fragile; it is part of the Kakadu National Park. We have a responsibility not only to the people of Australia but to the people of the world to protect this sensitive environment. If we followed the route of the Opposition-of Senator Lewis and Senator Tambling-we would merely allow the uranium miners to do what they will as cheaply as they can and despoil the environment, and the future of our children and of our country will be the loser.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Lord Michael Ramsey-Sydney Dance Company: Sponsorship-Taxation Funds: Expenditure on Defence

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I shall detain the Senate only briefly this evening. I wish to place on record some comments about the passing last weekend in England of an important figure in Christian history. Last weekend in England Lord Michael Ramsey, the one-hundredth Archbishop of Canterbury, passed away. Michael Ramsey was the one-hundredth successor to the Seat of St Augustine. He was one of the most important figures in Christian history in the post-war period. He was born in 1904. Without reciting his lengthy and distinguished career, let me simply say that he was Professor of Divinity at the University of Durham from 1940 to 1950. He was Regius Professor of Divinity at the University of Cambridge from 1950 to 1952. He was Lord Bishop of Durham from 1952 to 1956, the Archbishop of York from 1956 to 1961 and the Archbishop of Canterbury from 1961 to 1974. As such, he was the spiritual leader of my church. He was the world spiritual leader of those of us who regard ourselves as Anglicans or members of the Church of England. He was also President of the World Council of Churches from 1962 to 1968.

SPEECH.PARA: The passing of so eminent a figure in Christian history should not be ignored by this Parliament. It should not be ignored in terms of at least being recorded for the millions of people in this country who profess the Anglican faith or who describe themselves in somewhat more old-fashioned terms as members of the Church of England. He was a remarkable man. I had the opportunity to meet him when I was still a student at school in London. At that stage Michael Ramsey was the Archbishop of York-the Primate of England, not yet the Primate of All England, as the church has it in that country. It was he who, not just on that occasion but on numerous occasions, in what was in fact a unique contribution to theology in the United Kingdom and, indeed, to an understanding of a Christian perspective on world affairs, actually persuaded me as a young adolescent in the United Kingdom of the validity of the Christian faith.

During the period in which he was the Archbishop of Canterbury he played a most distinguished role in a number of areas. First, it was he who was primarily responsible for establishing the debate in Great Britain on the question of immigration on sound and decent lines. He made it a moral issue-not an economic issue, but an issue of one's Christian principles. He indicated in the time he served, under the prime ministership of Harold Wilson, as the Chairman of the National Committee for Commonwealth Immigrants a view about the way in which the immigration debate should be handled which I think would benefit many Australians, were they to go back to that debate and reread what the Archbishop of Canterbury said at that stage.

In 1965 in Aberdeen he made a speech in which he said that, if Harold Wilson used force to stop Ian Smith's Unilateral Declaration of Independence in Rhodesia, Christian people ought to support him. He believed that the establishment of another racist regime in southern Africa was something which Christians in good conscience could not tolerate. He drew that extraordinarily difficult line for people who professed to be Christians on the question of when the use of force is justified and when it is not.

He led the debate in the House of Lords on establishing a Christian position in favour of the abolition of capital punishment. I well remember that particular debate in the United Kingdom. He supported his predecessor, Geoffrey Fisher, the ninety-ninth Archbishop of Canterbury, in moving in the House of Lords for the repeal of laws which discriminated against homosexual behaviour in the United Kingdom. When this debate has arisen, I have frequently had the opportunity to quote the then Archbishop of Canterbury, Geoffrey Fisher, and the then Archbishop of York, Michael Ramsey, on why it was that a decent Christian position requires one not to make a judgment about homosexual behaviour and turn it into repressive laws.

He also pioneered the support in the House of Lords for reform of the divorce laws, again going very much against a large part of community opinion. Nevertheless, he pioneered that and played a significant role in changing community opinion. In 1966 he visited Rome and established a particular friendship with the then Pontiff, Paul VI. He worked tirelessly for the attempt to reunify Christian churches throughout the world. In the United Kingdom he pressed for unity with the Methodist Church. He was disappointed that that did not come to pass.

He was a man of true spirituality and at the same time a man of extraordinarily good humour. I well remember one of those famous Oxford Union debates in which he was a witty, erudite man who demonstrated that a love of life, a sense of humour and a sense of enjoyment were in no sense incompatible with the true meaning of Christian vocation. He was a very learned man. His books are well remembered. In particular his 1964 publication entitled Canterbury Essays and Addresses is one which I think again pays a great deal of rereading and a great deal of study.

As an obituary in the Sunday Times described him, he was a thinker with a learned knowledge of past faiths; a lover of the Bible; and full of affection for the human race. The Sunday Times report concluded:
He had a warm heart and was so near to God that, to be near him, was to be near Someone behind and above him.

Michael Ramsey was, I think, a nonpareil of the church, a person of spirituality, a person who believed in ecumenism and the unity of the Christian church. In particular, may I say, and I suppose one should be both humble and contrite in these circumstances, that the Church of England, the Anglican Church in the Diocese of Sydney, which has driven so many Christians out of the church as active participants in the church-people like myself who cannot tolerate a church which is based fundamentally on the assertion of authority rather than the proclamation of love-would do well to pause and to consider Michael Ramsey's contribution to Christian faith and Michael Ramsey's contribution to that sort of spiritual development which I believe is extraordinarily important in public life.

I would not want the opportunity to pass without putting on record that the Christian churches, the Anglican Church, the Church of England, in particular, have lost one of their finest examples. After 83 years of productive life, Michael Ramsey has been called to his reward. I have no doubt that his reward will be entirely commensurate with the Christian principles which he upheld and which he so eloquently advocated throughout his long and distinguished career both in the church and, indeed, in the political service of his nation in the period of time which he spent as a member of the House of Lords.

Mr President, I know it passes I suppose from almost the sublime, not to the ridiculous but certainly to a level far less sublime, to raise one other matter on the adjournment this evening. I do so simply in order not to detain the Senate later in the week by raising another matter. I want to make passing mention of a matter concerning the portfolio of the arts for which I have a responsibility. A few days ago the Wang computer company announced that it was entering into an agreement with the Sydney Dance Company to provide sponsorship of up to $1m over the next three years. This is the largest single sponsorship, I think, which has ever been announced for the performing arts in Australia. I do not think that I should allow it to pass without making reference to it on this occasion. The Sydney Dance Company is, I believe, one of the most monumental adornments of the arts scene in Australia. Anybody who has seen its productions, particularly its bicentennial production Vast, would agree with that.

The sponsorship between Wang Australia and the Sydney Dance Company dates back to 1983. In 1985 a $750,000 three-year agreement was announced which at that time was the largest sponsorship ever announced. The support which Wang has given to the Sydney Dance Company has assisted it in the production of such notable events as Some Rooms in 1983, After Venice in 1984, Boxes in 1985, which incorporated some of the most terrific modern music in Australia, produced by Icehouse, and Shining in 1987. I believe the example which Wang Australia has demonstrated to the rest of the corporate sector in this country is quite notable. I congratulate that company, its Managing Director, Michael Clarkin, and those associated with it on this sponsorship deal.

If we could have a little more of return to Australian arts and return to the Australian community of the profits which are made by large corporations in Australia, because of the sort of climate which exists in this country, that would be not only a notable contribution but also a notable return to Australia, particularly by companies which are essentially non-Australian companies. It would be a real investment in something other than bricks and mortar and land speculation. It would be a real investment in the young people of Australia, many of whom will find their careers through the Sydney Dance Company.

I take this opportunity to congratulate Wang on this outstanding achievement on its part and to say that I think it has set an enormously high example for other corporations and companies in Australia to follow. I believe that it has invested in one of the most exciting, interesting and dynamic performing arts companies in Australia, one which is also prepared to tour and take its work to the rest of the people of Australia, which so few of our companies are these days. I wish to put that very much on the record, as I did when I spoke briefly some time ago about the bicentennial dance event Vast.

Mr President, I thank you and fellow senators for your patience in allowing me the opportunity this evening to put those two matters on the public record. Funnily enough, they are related at some remote distance. They are related in that both Michael Ramsey and the Sydney Dance Company want to express something about the essential qualities of human nature, about the celebration, about the joy and about the spirituality of life. Those things rarely get mentioned in politics. When one does mention them one tends to get bucketed for one's trouble. That is a pity, but that is the current situation. Nevertheless, I think both of those matters were worth putting on the public record this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciated Senator Puplick's final remarks. I know only too well about the public bucketing that follows whenever people talk in this place about spiritual matters. I think they are a very important part of our personal lives which should also enter into our public lives. I want to explain to the Senate an action I took last Friday, 23 April, which could also be related to a spiritual dimension of life, certainly to a feeling about the future. It is a subject which is very important to me.

SPEECH.PARA: On that day I redirected 10 per cent of my additional tax bill to the Peace and Development Foundation in Melbourne, having paid the balance of the money already owed to the Australian Taxation Office in Perth with a letter to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation explaining why I had taken that action. This figure of 10 per cent represents the percentage of tax money spent on supporting Australia's defence establishment. As an Australian citizen and a senator in the Australian Parliament, I intend to redirect 10 per cent of extra taxes due to the Tax Office as long as Australia is involved in a military alliance with the United States Government and as long as Australia is involved in the mining and export of uranium; therefore, I believe, involving us in preparations for nuclear war. This involvement is a morally unacceptable position and I am challenging it because, under international law, nuclear weapons clearly are illegal.

I am taking this action in the hope that it will encourage people to think of security in non-military terms. We cannot buy security with weapons. We need to seek non-violent resolutions to international conflicts by encouraging negotiation and mediation skills and by putting research moneys into peace seeking, rather than promoting the continued escalation of the arms race. In Australia, the Peace and Development Foundation has been set up to receive funds from people who do not wish their tax moneys to be spent on preparations for war. Internationally, a peace tax campaign has existed for many years. The purpose of the campaign is to highlight the immorality of the world's annual expenditure on armaments-about $US930 billion a year-while the basic social needs of millions of the world's people remain unmet. I hope that my action will cause people to think about Australia's current defence position. My action is carefully considered and I hope that the Taxation Office will respect it.

I wish to expand on several points. First of all, the point about highlighting the immorality of the world's arms expenditure while millions of people's social needs remain unmet. It is a sum that is almost too large for an individual to comprehend-$US930 billion spent annually on weapons systems of all kinds. As a world community we are condoning that and allowing it to happen. We are allowing it to happen in our names while, at the same time, we know that a fraction of that expenditure could relieve many of the problems which the world's peoples face in terms of a lack of basic commodities, such as fresh drinking water, housing and education for children. It is a great blight on the international community that we allow that situation to continue. We need to continue to look at how the tax cakes are carved up in each individual country and suggest to our governments that there are other ways that we would like to see our tax dollars spent-that is, in more socially productive ways.

As I have said, this is part of an international peace tax campaign. It is an encouragement to the world's governments to allow conscientious objectors to redirect taxes usually spent on defence to these socially more useful projects. It is important for us to realise that this has come on to the agenda in Australia only recently-it has been happening in Australia for the last few years-and it has not reached the large proportions it has in other countries, such as Belgium, Canada, West Germany, France, Italy, Japan, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Switzerland, the United States and the United Kingdom. All have been part of this international peace tax campaign for a number of years.

All those campaigns have a common philosophical basis of conscientious or religious objection to tax funds being used for war or military expenditure. Many of these campaigns have the establishment of a peace tax fund as a related and central aim. The purpose of a peace tax fund would be to allow individuals to nominate on their income tax return that they wish the proportion of their tax normally used for military expenditure to be allocated to the peace tax fund. The peace tax fund campaigns in the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom are particularly active and have some support at congressional and parliamentary level. For example, in the United States, the World Peace Tax Fund Bill has been submitted to Congress every year since 1972, when it got one vote, but by 1984 it had attracted 50 supporters in the House of Representatives and three in the Senate. The aim of the World Peace Tax Fund Bill is to establish a special trust fund in the United States Treasury for deposits from those taxpayers who conscientiously oppose war and military expenditure.

I am indebted for that information to Robert Burrowes, who is Australia's best known war tax resister. One year he paid his taxation to the Taxation Office in the form of shovels for Eritrea, acknowledging that Eritrean people needed basic assistance, such as shovels, in order to provide food in that war torn country. This year he tried to pay his tax in the form of trees, and he presented 104 native trees to the Australian Taxation Office in Melbourne. They were actually rejected by the Taxation Office, which said that trees were not legal tender-in other words, that money does not grow on trees. No doubt the 104 native trees have gone to very good homes, but the point has been made by Robert Burrowes, in two very creative ways, that there are more socially useful projects that we could be spending our money on rather than weapons which can actually kill people. The objectives of the Peace and Development Foundation set up in Melbourne last year with the intention of holding and redistributing money for war tax resisters needs to be clarified. I will read its statement of purposes and objectives, which is not very long, so that it is clearly laid before the Senate. There is no intention whatsoever on the part of people who wish to resist paying a war tax to get out of paying any taxes. That is not the point at all. The point is that the percentage of tax which is presently allocated to the defence budget should be spent on more socially useful projects. These people are not in any way, and should not be misconstrued in any way as, trying to evade paying their full tax bill. The Peace and Development Foundation was set up in Melbourne in the latter part of 1987. Its purposes include the following:
1. To raise community awareness of the nonviolent means of achieving global security.
2. To raise community awareness of the fact that personal, company and other forms of taxation are used to finance Australia's military expenditure.
3. To support campaigns seeking legislative changes which will allow people to ensure by legal means that their taxes are applied to non-military purposes.
4. To generate funds for the promotion of peace, development, ecological harmony, social justice and political participation by nonviolent means.
I think they are very laudable purposes indeed. The specific objectives of the organisation are as follows:
1. To hold in a secure account:
(a) monies deposited with the Foundation by War Tax Resisters (called `war tax deposits') until such time as the return of these deposits is requested or they are donated to the Foundation.
(b) monies donated to the Foundation (called `donations') by supporters who have a conscientious objection to war and the arms race.
(c) interest earned on the deposits and donations.
2. To use donations and interest from the Foundation's account:

(a) to financially support initiatives consistent with the promotion of peace, development, ecological harmony, social justice and political participation by nonviolent means, and in particular: (i) to develop nonviolent methods of resolving conflict within and between peoples (ii) to educate the community about those methods.

(b) to financially support the preparation and presentation in court of arguments intended to establish the legal right of individuals to resist paying taxes for war and the arms race given their rights and duties under international law.
(c) to provide financial relief for War Tax Resisters.

I want to correct a statement in which I was misquoted in the West Australian on Saturday, 24 April, in which it said that I had said at a Press conference in Melbourne on Friday that some members of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party could soon join me. That was an exaggeration of a comment made by somebody else. In fact, the co-convenor of the Peace and Development Foundation said that she was aware that some members of the Australian Labor Party who were also members of the new Peace and Development Foundation had suggested that they would put the idea of a war tax resistance and a peace tax fund instituted by the Government on the agenda at the local branch level of the Labor Party. So that needs to be clarified. I am sure that the Australian Democrats are interested in the proposal, but I have not canvassed this and I have not suggested that other people should follow my lead in making this statement of civil disobedience.

It is important to put into perspective the defence expenditure of this country. In 1985-86 we spent 9.9 per cent of our expenditure on defence, 9.8 per cent on health and 7 per cent on education. I think it is very important that people in the Australian community understand the relationship between these various areas of expenditure and that defence actually gets more than both health and education. At the same time, we spent 0.36 per cent on foreign aid. So, in dollar terms, $7.5 billion was spent on defence and $7m on peacekeeping efforts-for example, Australia's efforts at the United Nations (UN). At the same time $1 billion was spent on foreign aid, which is only half of the United Nations recommended figure for expenditure on foreign aid. So Australia is sliding down the scale and approaching the status of mean nations as far as its foreign aid expenditure is concerned. Although I know there are many problems within Australia that need to be addressed-I do not want to denigrate the problems that we have here or the minority groups within Australia that need more attention from the Government-I think it is important that we see foreign aid as a way of building security. It is much more positively and socially useful to spend money on foreign aid rather than on weapons systems which can be seen by our neighbours as a threat to them. I think it is very important to put that into perspective.

My personal position is that I wish to withhold this 10 per cent of my tax, which is additional to the pay as you earn tax already taken from my salary, as long as the Australian Government supports the United States nuclear alliance and as long as we mine and export uranium. To be involved in preparations for the use of nuclear weapons is morally unacceptable, and under international law I feel an obligation to reject that complicity. This is another form of civil disobedience. It is most important that it is seen as such, because civil disobedience is a very powerful tool of civil change.

When we consider the appropriateness of a war tax resistance campaign for Australia, it is important to consider the individual's moral rights and legal responsibilities in relation to war preparation under international law. For example, it is evident that nuclear weapons have the properties of weapons outlawed by international law. Briefly, their effects include the indiscriminate dispersal of toxic and carcinogenic chemicals; the exposure of combatants and civilians alike to irreversible biological and genetic damage; and the creation of unpredictable, uncontrollable and unprecedented environmental destruction of such temporal longevity as to threaten the biological identity of the human race and even the physical integrity of the planet. Several international treaties outlaw weapons which have such effects. Yet states manufacture and threaten to use these outlawed weapons. States like Australia provide uranium and support the intelligence and command structures-that is, the American bases on Australian soil-for their use. What, then, is the moral and legal position of the individual in such circumstances? Article 18 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states:
Everyone shall have the right of freedom of . . . conscience . . . This right shall include freedom to . . . manifest (their) . . . belief in . . . practice.

There is an equivalent article in the Universal Declaration on Human Rights. The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seattle, Raymond Hunthausen, is a well-known war tax resister. Explaining his `witness of faith', Hunthausen proclaimed his commitment to a moral principle higher than the law of the state. He said-I quote from Peace Dossier No. 6, put out by the Victorian Association for Peace Studies:

It is true that as a general rule the laws of the state must be obeyed. However, we may peacefully disobey certain laws under serious conditions . . . The point is that civil law is not absolute . . . where issues of great moral importance are at stake, disobedience to a law in a peaceful manner . . . may be . . . an obligation of conscience. I am saying by my action that in conscience I cannot support or acquiesce in a nuclear arms buildup which I consider a grave moral evil.

But while international law confers certain rights, it also entails a series of responsibilities. International law is not confined to the relations among states. An individual who commits an act which is a crime under international law is responsible and consequently liable to punishment.

The International Law Commission (ILC), which was set up by the United Nations General Assembly to promote the progressive development and codification of international law, was asked to formulate the principles of international law recognised in the Charter of the Nuremberg Tribunal and to prepare a draft code of offences against the peace and security of humankind. The ILC formulated seven principles which were adopted by the UN in 1950. The fourth principle, based on article 8 of the Nuremberg Charter, stipulated:

The fact that a person acted pursuant to order of (their) government or of a superior does not relieve (them) from responsibility under international law, provided a moral choice was in fact possible to (them).

I think that question of choice being made available to the people is very important. Certainly, in the democratic state in which we live, I believe choices are available. That is why I have chosen twice in Australia to commit civil disobedience on this important question of our involvement with preparations for the use of nuclear weapons.

Individuals have the right to freedom of conscience but they also have the legal responsibility to make a moral choice which may conflict with the laws of the state. Laws have often been created to support the will of a government; the apartheid laws of South Africa are a good example. In national law, what is morally wrong is not necessarily illegal. What is right is not necessarily legal.

The order of a government to pay military taxes does not, under international law, absolve the individual of responsibility for the use of those taxes. Military taxes finance preparation for, and participation in, war beyond the legitimate if still moral use of force-defined in international law as cases of self-defence or under the enforcement provisions of the United Nations Charter. They are used to produce not only defensive but offensive weapons and technologies, especially those related to the nuclear arms race and to finance overseas military aid. It may thus be argued that the refusal to pay military taxes is not only an act of conscience but an obligation under international law. I am indebted to that material and also to Robert Burrowes.

I am very aware of the consequences of taking such action. I realise that the Australian Taxation Office, under section 207 and section 218, has the ability to retrieve unpaid taxes. First, it can levy a 20 per cent per annum fee on unpaid taxes cumulatively, as with compound interest, and, under section 218, notices can be served to the effect that money can be withdrawn from bank accounts and so on and fines are imposed.

I am quite aware of all that and am willing to take the consequences of my actions. This is a very important aspect of civil disobedience, that people are not trying to get out of their civilian responsibilities by taking such actions. It is also important to note that with the build-up of the peace tax campaign in Australia-and people may remember, it was sometime last year, that a very large petition was presented to the Senate on the question of the Government setting up a peace tax campaign-I am currently investigating the possibilities of an amendment to the taxation Act to make legal provision for conscientious objectors available to Australian taxpayers.
